Table 2 presents these statistics. According to Ellington's (2021) study, as these statistics increase, the model's fit is better. It is important to take into account serial correlation, stochastic volatility, and heavy tails. According to our findings, network measures derived from BHVAR-t-CSV-MA(1) or BHVAR-t-CSV have the most significant values of log marginal likelihoods. Additionally, it is important to make comparisons between networks formed from BHVAR-CSV and BHVAR-CSV-MA(1). 4.2 Network linkages 4.2.1 Time-horizon linkages In the following analysis, the particular network interlinkages are obtained from Eq. (3), in which d refers to short-run (between one day and one week), medium-run (from 1-week to 1-month), and long-term (larger than 1-month) horizons. The one-standard deviation and the posterior median percentile in terms of specific network interlinkage metrics are displayed in Fig. 1 . A network's short-, medium-, and long-term interlinkages are displayed in the top, middle, and bottom panels. Three key findings have been identified. Firstly, the long-run interlinkages between artificial intelligence development and green energy dynamics show the most strength, and they decrease sharply compared to the sample in the wars, in particular, peaking in July 2019 (COVID-19 pandemic outbreak), then fluctuations rise persistently and decline when new virus strains penetrate during the COVID-19 pandemic. Finally, it decreased sharply before increasing again at the end of the sample due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict (in February 2022). As a second point, error bands refer to the fact that interlinkages occur over the long-run, and significant differences occur over the short-run and medium-run interlinkages. This significant difference emerged at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic (from July 2019) and the Russia-Ukraine conflict (in February 2022). Thirdly, July 2019 is the month when there is a peak in short- and medium-run interlinkages. The trend also declined at the end of 2021 after experiencing considerable surges in 2021. COVID-19 pandemic strains spread through the global economy again at the end of 2020 and mid-2021, with severe consequences for a number of economies. Moreover, in the short term, the interlinkage became strong at the beginning of the Russia-Ukraine conflict occurs. Consequently, the world economy became extremely volatile during that time. Under uncertain conditions, short- and medium-term interconnections between markets will probably become stronger. As a temporary pandemic subsided in 2021, these interlinkages weakened slightly and continued to link when the Russia-Ukraine conflict occurred. Overall, network interconnections exhibit considerable differences at different time horizons. Over the short, medium, and long term, transient market events increase network interlinkages. Notably, we indicate the adverse impact of global uncertainty. A persistent COVID-19 health crisis has caused Baumeister et al. (2020) to emphasize the importance of long-term network interlinkages. 4.2.2 Net-directional linkages In the following step, we will study the net-directional connections between commodity prices and financial goods prices at different time horizons. Initially, we focus on the short run and the medium run. Short-term net-directional interlinkages, as shown in Figs. 2 and 3 , are posterior medians and one-standard deviation percentiles. It is noteworthy that the positive (negative) values of series j indicate its role as a shock transmitter (receiver). Note that variables j = {ROBT(IRBO, BOTZ), SPGB, SPGTCLEN, GWE, SUNIDX, NGF, OVX}. It is important to emphasize a few points here. All three Panels in Figs. 2 and 3 show a similar trend of the ROBT, BOTZ, and IRBO with green energy markets. BOTZ acted as a shock receiver from other markets two times, particularly at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic (at the end of 2019) and the Russia-Ukraine conflict (at the start of 2022). Meanwhile, ROBT and IRBO are shock transmitters before receiving a shock from the outside markets at the beginning of the disease outbreak. Notably, the role of ROBT, BOTZ, and IRBO become more apparent during uncertain times as the value means of indicators are more considerably volatile at that time. By contrast, the green energy markets mostly played the role of shock transmitters during our studied time, except for the natural gas market. However, the solar energy market turned out to be a shock receiver during the Russia-Ukraine conflict (starting in early 2022) as the mean value of SUNIDX became negative. Besides, clean energy and wind energy also became shock receivers during the COVID-19 pandemic crisis (from the beginning to mid-2021) but immediately returned to shock transmitters and, along with the green bonds market, became important channels to transmit shock during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. In general, artificial intelligence development and the green energy market play more significant roles during uncertain times. Especially during the COVID-19 struck the globe and the Russia-Ukraine conflict, the artificial intelligence development markets received a very strong shock from the wind energy, clean energy, and green bonds markets. Afterward, we examine the long-horizon net-directional linkages shown in Fig. 4 . Notably, the mean values of variables in our system fluctuated during our studied period, suggesting that the role of artificial intelligence development and the green energy market is inconsistent in the long term. Their roles are exchanged constantly. Furthermore, the importance of artificial intelligence development and the green energy market became more critical when the global economy was hit by some serious crises. Specifically, throughout the sample (from May 2019 to January 2022), the solar energy and clean energy markets demonstrate relatively similar time dynamics in the period of COVID-19 (from January 2020 to January 2021), and the Russia-Ukraine conflict (in early 2022), both act as a conventional transmission. They have become shock receivers from January 2021- December 2021, while the green bonds and natural gas markets operate in contrast to transmit shock. During the research stage, all three artificial intelligence development markets serve as a vital shock received. Suddenly, it became a shock transmitter during the illness crisis of COVID-19 (from May 2019 to January 2020) and the Russia-Ukraine conflict (from early 2022). These results support those of Ren and Lucey (2022), who found a tenuous link between clean energy and the spread of digital technology, indicating that clean energy may someday be employed as a hedging and diversification strategy for the use of digital technology. The growth of some commodity markets has been noted before in conjunction with various financial crises (2007–2009), as indicated by Balcilar et al. (2021) and Zhang and Broadstock (2020). To gauge the model's forecasting power, we calcuate mean absolute forecast errors (MAFE) and log predictive scores as in Ellington (2021). Table 3 outlines these statistics. The results indicate that BHVAR-CSV model fit to all dataset. On the other hand, BHVAR-t-CSV-MA (1) model fit to the bseline dataset make up the model condifence set. 4.2.3 Robustness check In order to verify our findings, we take logs of all series and analyze them as described in Section 4.2.2. A few of our results are reported in the Appendix, and the others can be provided upon request in order to save space. Generally, we find the same conclusions as we did previously, indicating the conclusions regarding dynamic network interlinkages are valid and robust. 5 Conclusion and policy implications This paper aims to explore fat tails and connections between artificial intelligence (AI) development and green energy markets. While regarding AI development, we use ROBT, BOTZ and IRBO, and the green energy market, including Green Bonds, Clean Energy, Wind Energy, Solar Energy, Natural Gas, and Crude Oil, in a seven-fold Bayesian vector heterogeneous autoregression model. It differentiates between shorter-run, medium-run, and longer-run network interlinkages among these markets. Our time series covers from May 01, 2019, to October 28, 2022. The following two points deserve special attention. As a first step, it is crucial that the artificial intelligence development and green energy markets are more statistically and remarkedly interconnected in the long run. Additionally, the pattern of long-run network interlinkages differs from the pattern of short-run and medium-run interlinkages. After the COVID-19 pandemic spreads out, the Russia-Ukraine conflict occurs, and these distinctions become more evident. During uncertain times, network interlinkages among various types of markets are also likely to increase in size. Second, market directional links indicate a shift in roles (from shock receiver to shock transmitter) before the Russia-Ukraine conflict, whereas these roles persist during the COVID-19 pandemic. The short- and medium-horizon measures indicate that during COVID-19 struck the globe and the Russia-Ukraine conflict, the artificial intelligence development markets received a very strong shock from the wind energy, clean energy, and green bonds markets. During the pandemic period of COVID-19 begin to settle, the artificial intelligence development markets become shocking transmit. The natural gas market is less volatile in the short- and medium-run, while according to long-horizon measures, it is shock transmitters from January 2020 to January 2021. At the beginning of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, solar energy and clean energy markets act as shock receptors (transmitters). 5.1 Theoretical improvements In our research, we are the first to offer a unique deep explanation of the interconnectedness between AI development and the energy market, specifically in chaotic events like the COVID-19 epidemic or the global political conflict in the short-, medium-, and long-run. Using the special method, the short-, medium-, and long-run pairwise connectedness estimate spread channels between the AI, FinTech, Robotic development and the dynamic of energy market. We contribute crucial information and warnings about the spread of uncertain occurrences and policies for regulators and investors (Figs. A.1–A.4). 5.2 Practical applications Findings from our study have important consequences for financial institutions and government agencies, as well as practices from the contagions in different markets, as well as their interconnectedness on the policy front. Policymakers can also design appropriate policies to reduce the vulnerabilities of such markets and prevent risk spread and instability if they know the crucial antecedents of contagions among them, including oil, gold, commodities, and cryptocurrencies. Based on our findings, there are strong links between the four market segments, which emphasize investor risks associated with low and high diversification. As a result of our results, it is becoming increasingly clear that unpredictable events are interconnected. It is evident that a sudden change in a traditional market impacts a network as a whole, suggesting that investors and managers should be more cautious in managing the investment portfolio, which includes gold, oil in futures contracts, stocks, and cryptocurrency. An early warning signal would be the contagions of uncertainty and risk that should be considered when making an investment decision. In addition, this paper's findings can also be useful in enhancing public welfare, which is a direct result of financialization, oil, cryptocurrency, and gold. The crucial insights that there are ambiguities and risks in the energy sector must be applied to financial markets reversely. Consequently, designing policies to enhance the welfare of a vulnerable group must take these factors into account. 5.3 Limitations and directions for future research Three limitations remain with the research results. We must first emphasize that no general principle or pattern can be found that applies to all cases regarding how risk occurrences impact total, net, or pairwise spillovers in the short-, medium-, and long-run. Secondly, the extent of the spread is significant from the perspective of indicator association. In the case of a large spread, changes and shocks brought about by other indicators will have a significant impact on a particular market system. A variety of measures must be taken by the government in order to lessen the negative effects of external shocks. Authorities should concentrate on frequency-specific danger sources. In integrating global regulatory guidelines for different metrics, more emphasis should be placed on reducing the negative consequences of long-term fluctuation spreads and short-term return spreads. Furthermore, since many researchers consider the spillover effect across multiple metrics, evaluating the portfolio advantages of diversity is a significant step forward. As a result, it was placed on hold for the time being.
