Table 4 Summary of findings. Table 4 Statement Supporting arguments Future research AI will impact the tasks of mental healthcare workers 1) Observed need for task improvement; 2) Only four out of 46 papers concluded their system is not ready for real-world adoption; 3) Although small datasets were used, the majority of systems were machine learning methods (rather deep learning), which require less data and were thus the suitable method employed. 1) Study the consequences of the implementation of these technologies in real-world scenarios; 2) How to implement these systems considering the work context of professionals, by, for instance, exploring possible training programs, their social impact on workers, and other related practicalities. AI systems will be incorporated into the tasks of mental healthcare workers more than replacing them. 1) Given that datasets were small, they are limited in their ability to function indepedently, given many unseen examples still exist. Thus, requiring collaboration between the human and the system; 2) The majority of systems were produced with the goal of assisting in mind, rather than functioning independently. Compare systems' performance to that of human beings and to test their accuracy in hybrid contexts, in order to gain deeper insight into the benefit of the use of these technologies. AI systems will aid in the task of Assessment by (1) improved efficiency and accuracy in diagnosing patients and (2) supporting further assessment tasks. Based on 1) The two previous statements and; 2) The results of the reviewed papers, we can conclude that the task of Assessment will be transformed by employing AI systems for diagnosis and further assessment tasks. 1) To compare different AI's systems performance for assessment tasks; 2) To develop new AI systems for assessment tasks that have been less explored, such as burnout and obssessive compulsive disorder; 3) Identify barries and enablers concerning the use of AI systems in monitoring processes. AI will be used to monitor patient's responsiveness to treatment/internal state and predict treatment outcomes. Based on: 1) The first two statements, and; 2) The results of the reviewed papers, we can conclude that the task of Monitoring will be transformed by employing AI systems for monitoring patients' responsiveness to treatment and internal state and predicting treatment outcomes. Identify barries and enablers concerning the use of AI systems in monitoring processes. The task of Therapy will be transformed by employing AI for providing live feedback throughout therapeutic sessions, such as therapeutic alliance and patients' emotional state. Based on: 1) The first two statements, and; 2) The results of the reviewed papers, we can conclude that the task of Therapy will be transformed by applying AI for providing live feedback throughout therapeutic sessions, such as therapeutic alliance and patients' emotional state. 1) To look into ways of safeguarding empathy in the context of AI-supported mental healthcare and to measure the implications of autonomous AI-driven therapy systems; 2) Identify barries and enablers concerning the use of AI systems in monitoring processes. The tasks of Prescription and Documentation were not explored. Missing in the literature. To explore the application of Artificial Intelligence for tasks such as Medical Prescription and Documentation The impact of artificial intelligence on the tasks of mental healthcare workers: A scoping review Ana Daniela Rebelo a ∗ Damion E. Verboom a Nuno Rebelo dos Santos b Jan Willem de Graaf a a Saxion University of Applied Sciences, Deventer, the Netherlands Saxion University of Applied Sciences Deventer the Netherlands Saxion University of Applied Sciences, Deventer, the Netherlands b Research Centre in Education and Psychology (CIEP-UÉ), School of Social Sciences, Universidade de Évora, Évora, Portugal Research Centre in Education and Psychology (CIEP-UÉ) School of Social Sciences Universidade de Évora Évora Portugal Research Centre in Education and Psychology (CIEP-UE), School of Social Sciences, Universidade de Evora, Evora, Portugal ∗ Corresponding author. Background Artificial Intelligence (AI) is expected to transform the work context deeply. Currently, multiple AI systems are being studied and applied in the mental healthcare field, challenging traditional ways of performing tasks by professionals. Objectives This study aims to verify to what extent AI impacts mental healthcare workers’ tasks, describe how AI impacts those tasks, and identify which tasks are impacted. Design Two databases were used to find empirical research published between 2019 and December 2022. A total of 46 papers were included in the review. Results AI was most often employed for assessment tasks, in which it is generated to support physicians in the diagnostic process. Patient monitoring was also explored by a few papers, which applied intelligent systems to aid professionals by identifying variables that can predict the outcome of the therapeutic process and detect the patients' mood. Regarding therapy, AI systems can contribute by providing insights into patient-therapist interaction and the patient's emotional states. Finally, documentation and medical prescriptions were addressed by one article which measured physicians' opinions on the impact of AI on their jobs. Conclusion Artificial Intelligence systems impact the tasks of mental healthcare workers by providing support and enabling greater insights. Most systems aimed to aid mental healthcare workers instead of replacing them. These results highlight the relevance of training professionals to enable hybrid intelligence. Keywords Mental healthcare Artificial intelligence Psychologist Psychiatrist Therapist Mental healthcare worker 1 Introduction Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a quickly advancing and promising field, which is believed to yield great societal benefits, such as the eradication of disease and poverty (Russell, Dewey, & Tegmark, 2015; Wahl, Cossy-Gantner, Germann, & Schwalbe, 2018). Research in AI concerns itself with enabling computers to emulate human reasoning (Millington, 2019). Artificial intelligence can be defined through the concept of intelligent systems presented by (Artificial Intelligence). According to the authors, most definitions of these systems can be summarized through the following list: (1) Technologies that comprise thinking abilities comparable to those present in human beings; (2) Technologies that perform actions alike humans; (3) Technologies that hold the ability for rational thinking, and; (4) Technologies that have the capacity to act rationally. Machine Learning (ML) refers to systems that “learn” from information. In other words, they increase in performance measured on a task as experience increases. As such, ML can be defined very broadly, where a large range of different systems possessing such traits could be defined as ML. Examples of ML systems include bayesian networks, regression models, decision trees, and Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) (Janiesch, Zschech, & Heinrich, 2021). ANNs are systems that are inspired by biology, functioning on the activation of units called artificial neurons. These neurons are connected and they signal each other mathematically. The strength of the signal a neuron sends depends on the strength of the input signals the neuron receives. The influence neurons have on each other is constantly tuned during the training process in order to optimize the performance on a task (Zhang, Yang, Lin, Ji, & Gupta, 2018). Within this class of systems, further distinctions are possible. For instance, a Neural Network consists of three layers: (1) An input layer that receives the information: (2) One or more hidden layers that analyze the information; (3) An output layer that returns the result of that analysis (Patterson & Gibson, 2017). However, another commonly used subcategory is Deep Learning (DL). DL refers to Artificial Neural Networks consisting of more than one hidden layer, in addition to other network architectures. Other DL systems alter the neuron's connectivity and functioning, resulting in different structures and operations which mitigate some of the weaknesses from other architectures. Common architectures include Convolutional Neural Networks and Recurrent Neural Networks. However, there exists no sharp border between algorithms that can be classified as deep or non-deep learning. What Artificial Neural Networks tends to separate from other ML algorithms is their capability to discover representations suitable for the task at hand (Janiesch et al., 2021). As the distinction is not sharply defined in the literature, the current paper categorizes ANNs of any shape or form as DL systems. More categorizations in ML exist. Some AI technologies employ what is referred to as symbolic AI. Here, instead of learning from a series of data instances, the system works based on a set of previously-defined knowledge rules. This functioning makes the outcome interpretable, contrasting with many machine learning techniques (Hoehndorf & Queralt-Rosinach, 2017). Next, there are Fuzzy Systems (FS), a type of symbolic AI that works based on logic, more specifically fuzzy sets and fuzzy logic (Czabanski et al., 2017 pp. 23–43). Fuzzy logic makes use of probabilities to compute the likelihoods. An example of this would be estimating the likelihood of an individual having a disease based on his symptoms (Venkata Subba Reddy, 2017). These types of systems (ANN, ML, symbolic AI, and FS) differ regarding the extent to which their outcomes can be interpreted and suitable use cases. ANNs are able to uncover much more complicated patterns but simultaneously operate as a black box, where the system's output cannot be reasoned upon. ANNs function well on large datasets and are in general much more data-hungry. In contrast, typical, and generally older, ML methods (such as decision tree, random forests, and Support Vector Machines) work well on smaller datasets and are easier to grasp and reason about (Janiesch et al., 2021). In the case of ANNs, questions such as why a prediction is given, as of today, cannot be answered reliably if at all. In contrast, a decision tree's output can simply be visualized, while a random forest can be understood as a majority vote from multiple decision trees. This is not to say that all ML methods are equally interpretable, nor are all models of the same type of ML. For instance, a decision tree, given that it is large enough, can become hard or impossible to interpret. AI is currently one of the most popular fields of study. For instance, six out of the ten most popular search terms on IEEE Xplore's database (https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/), as of October 2022, are either Artificial Intelligence or related terms, such as Image Processing, Data Mining, Machine Learning, Big Data, and Deep Learning. Currently, AI systems are being researched for mental health applications. Some areas of focus include the improvement of tasks, such as in (Horn & Weisz, 2020) in which AI is explored for the enhancement of psychotherapy. Another topic of study is the support of the healthcare system by aiding the allocation of resources (van Mens et al., 2022). A concern, however, is that while AI systems are already being adopted in healthcare, different stakeholder groups (such as government policymakers, hospital managers/doctors, and IT firm managers) sometimes exhibit contradictory viewpoints concerning this adoption. From one perspective, the implementation of Artificial Intelligence is perceived as an important innovative step that will bring about great contributions to the work context, increasing efficiency in completing tasks (Sun & Medaglia, 2019). One of the ways AI could aid professionals is through the application of Hybrid Intelligence systems (Dellermann, Lipusch, Ebel, & Marco Leimeister, 2018). This concept refers to systems that combine both human and computational intelligence (Kamar, 2016). Conversely, potential negative consequences such as job losses and privacy issues raise concerns regarding its application (Sun & Medaglia, 2019). An increasing amount of jobs are being replaced by AI systems. Given this trend toward automation, it is reasonable to think AI could eventually emulate mental health professionals (David and Luxton, 2016). Al-Sabhan, Mahmud and Khaled (Al-Sabhan and MahmudNada, 2020) address AI use in healthcare, defending that the positive implications and opportunities brought by the use of Artificial Intelligence systems are greater than the possible negative outcomes, particularly when those outcomes are dealt with properly and prevented. Therefore, it is relevant to develop a more in-depth understanding of how the use of this technology will impact healthcare workers to contribute to the beneficial application of these systems. Researchers have already addressed their concerns regarding the safety of the applicability of these technologies and the possibility of their replacement of healthcare workers in some of their roles (Loh, 2018). The application of AI systems for mental healthcare tasks, such as counseling, is already being explored (Russell, 2019). Furthermore, it is suggested that some job positions in other fields, such as helpline workers, are already experiencing job loss derived from the application of AI (Modliński & Bartosiak, 2021). Due to AI's rapid learning abilities, compared to that of humans, it is expected that these technologies will also affect the jobs of mental healthcare professionals (David, 2014). In this context, it is crucial to gain insight into how these technologies will impact the mental healthcare sector, specifically, the workers' tasks. Studying that impact enables prospective human resource management in the mental healthcare sector, allowing gains in effectiveness, performance, and well-being of professionals and managers, leading them to deliver better services to society. This scoping review intends to systematize the empirical research that focuses on the impact already witnessed in the field. 1.1 Artificial intelligence for mental healthcare Currently, many Artificial Intelligence systems have been created for application in mental health (Tom, Miles, Cowie, & Ridge, 2019). Chatbots are an example of an application of AI being explored for use in healthcare. Abd-alrazaq et al. (Abd-alrazaq et al., 2019) conducted an overview of different chatbots employed for mental healthcare. To do this, the authors made use of seven bibliographic databases to explore existing chatbots and their key features. The different systems were classified based on their purpose, the platforms they were built in, how they responded, and the initiative regarding their dialogues. Further, it was examined how they generated responses, types of input/output, the disorders they deal with, and if the chatbots were embodied or not. From the observed systems, 47 aimed to provide therapy, 12 were built for training, and 10 for screening. The authors observed that most chatbots only allowed the user to interact by writing and that the most common way of providing feedback was a mix of text, audio, and imagery. The mental disorders the chatbots most frequently targeted were depression and autism. It was concluded that the use of chatbots for mental health is an expanding field and that it is important to conduct more studies on these systems in order to understand how effective these are or can be for mental health. Is it also relevant to know what is the level of acceptance of stakeholders regarding these technologies. Another important study was the one conducted by European Commission and Joint Research Centre, Gómez-González, and Gómez (European Commission Joint Research Centre et al., 2020). The authors briefly present the uses of AI systems for healthcare until the present day and consider some of the possible applications of this software, as well as the social and ethical impact of these technologies. These authors state that these systems could contribute to what they call “extended personalized medicine” (p.2). The goal of this type of medicine is to adapt the diagnosis and treatment to the individual's needs, making use of data such as their genetic features. This connects to the concept of “precision medicine” (p.7), which can be described by the use of a series of data sources, such as demographic data, societal data, and mood recognition, through AI-mediated systems, in order to process, connect and analyze this data. Information technology tools have been demonstrated to alleviate the burden on health services. Artificial Intelligence and data mining techniques were identified as among the most promising approaches to support healthcare administration by augmenting clinical care and lessening administrative demands on clinicians (Reddy, Fox, & Purohit, 2019). When properly applied, AI systems could greatly benefit patients by, for instance, supplementing the doctors’ expertise and decreasing medical error (Aung, Wong, & Ting, 2021). AI is expected to be a transformational tool in the workforce, deeply changing the ways people work (Bughin et al., 2017) and diminishing the strain on the healthcare system (Naseem, Akhund, Arshad, & Ibrahim, 2020). Given the potential for the application of these technologies, it is important to address how these will impact the tasks of healthcare workers. Presently, AI-mediated software is still “weak AI”, and can only perform a limited amount of tasks. While some argue that due to the speed of processing allowed by Artificial Intelligence systems, these could highly influence and possibly replace the doctor's performance (European Commission Joint Research Centre et al., 2020), others highlight the importance of certain elements, such as empathy in therapeutic care (Moudatsou, Stavropoulou, Philalithis, & Koukouli, 2020) which are a limitation of AI systems (Montemayor, Halpern, & Fairweather, 2022). 1.2 Mental healthcare workers The following mental healthcare workers were selected for the present study: (a) Psychologists; (b) Therapists/Counselors; (c) Psychiatrists. This selection was based on the mental healthcare workers’ categories defined by the Anxiety & Depression Association of America (Anxiety & Depression Association of America, 2023). Social workers and general practitioners were excluded. The rationale for the exclusions is the following. Regarding social workers, part of their tasks can include therapy or counseling. However, the general description of the tasks of social workers is broad, in the sense that it ranges over a variety of topics. A great portion of these topics does not (directly) contribute to mental health specifically, such as policy formulation and political intervention (International Federation of Social Workers, 2023). This is in contrast with psychologists, psychiatrists, and counselors, whose tasks are clearly in the function of mental health. Likewise, although general practitioners (GP) are involved in the mental health field, it is not their expertise. According to the UK's National Health Services (NHS, 2023a), GPs offer treatment for common medical issues. Besides this, they function as a link between patients and hospitals, referring them to specialists and urgent care. For this reason, general practitioners were not included in this study. Regarding the included mental healthcare professionals, psychologists are versed in the understanding of behavioral and emotional components of human beings. They hold knowledge about the conceptual world of individuals and their thoughts (Anxiety & Depression Association of America, 2023). Scientific knowledge is at the base of this understanding (Canadian Psychological Association, 2023). Some branches of psychology are not closely related to mental health. That is the case for organizational psychologists, sports psychologists, economic psychologists, marketing psychologists, and others. Therefore, only psychologists whose job is directly related to mental health were included. Psychologists can practice in schools, hospitals, clinics, private offices, and other spaces and are commonly involved in research alongside their practice. Some examples of topics addressed by these professionals include managing stress, dealing with relationship issues, treating addictions, and mental health problems (Canadian Psychological Association, 2023). The terms counselors/therapists are broader titles often used to describe mental healthcare workers that can give psychotherapy and (or) counseling, such as psychologists, social workers, and psychiatric nurses. These sessions can include one person (individual) or multiple people (like families, couples, and groups). Some of the topics which can be addressed by therapists/counselors include stress, addiction, and issues within a family or marriage (Anxiety & Depression Association of America, 2023). For the context of this research the title “counselors” was chosen to describe mental healthcare workers within this category. According to the UK's National Health Services, a psychiatrist is tasked with diagnosing patients and treating them. Furthermore, the prevention of mental health issues is another role of these professionals. Contrary to psychologists and counselors, psychiatrists are considered doctors and prescribe medication. Psychiatrists can practice in spaces such as outpatient clinics and hospitals. Regarding the type of health issues these mental health professionals tackle, these can include but are not limited to: addictions, obsessive-compulsive disorder, dementia, and schizophrenia (NHS, 2023b). 1.2.1 Mental healthcare workers’ tasks Based on the task descriptions by the American National Alliance on Mental Illness (National Alliance on Mental Illness, 2020) and the American Professional Agency (American Professional Agency, 2023), the authors selected five mental healthcare workers’ tasks to be analyzed in the context of this study (see Table 1 ): (1) assessment, (2) therapy, (3) prescription, (4) documentation, and (5) monitoring. The American Psychological Association (American Psychological Association, 2023) defines assessment as a process in which information regarding the patient's behaviors and other relevant data is assembled. The goal of this collection is to allow mental healthcare workers to gain insight into the patient's context and gather data that will be useful for the next steps of the therapeutic process. The assessment can be performed in the form of tests, interviews, observations, and other approaches. Therapy is a term used in several fields. Within the context of this study, the word therapy refers to psychotherapy. Psychotherapy is a general concept assigned to therapy in which the patient speaks to a mental healthcare professional with the goal of treating mental health issues (Mayo Clinic, 2016). According to the US National Institute of Mental Health (National Insitute of Mental Health, 2023), psychotherapy encompasses tasks such as: giving the patient emotional support, identifying causes of stress, and applying techniques to decrease it. During psychotherapy the mental healthcare professional can provide help through the analysis of the patient's inner world and life context, guiding them in the understanding of their emotions and problem-solving together. Prescription (also referred to as medical prescription) pertains to a written order of medication. This order can be made by a medical professional and includes a set of instructions for the treatment. The treatment regimen contains the prescription of medication with the goal of diagnosing, treating, and/or preventing a health condition (Panchbhai, 2014). Documentation refers to the stored information regarding the patient by the mental health professional and includes (1) Electronic medical records; (2) Therapy notes; (3) Psychological Reports. According to the US National Cancer Institute (National Cancer Insitute, 2023), an electronic medical record holds patient data. This data is stored digitally and is used for keeping health professionals informed and guiding the care of the patient. A medical record can include information such as (1) The health history; (2) Medication; (3) Diagnosis; and (4) Treatment. The Office for Civil Rights (Office for Civil Rights, 2017) defines therapy notes as notes written by the mental healthcare practitioner which describe and explore the topics addressed during the sessions with the patient. At last, psychological reports comprise data about the patient's mental state and can include information about one or multiple diagnoses, cognitive abilities, skills, and emotional issues, in a way that allows the patients and/or their caregivers to gain a better understanding of the patient's mental functioning. The psychological report also includes advice on aspects that pertain to the treatment of the patient (Wiener & Costaris, 2012). Monitoring can include (1) Progress Monitoring; and (2) Medication Monitoring. The first one relates to tracking the state of the patients to gain insight into their developments throughout treatment (Goodman, Mckay, & DePhilippis, 2013). This monitoring allows healthcare professionals to understand how the patient is responding to the treatment and if changes to the therapeutic approach need to be made (CarlierWessel, 2017). Medication monitoring refers to the supervision of patients’ experiences and reactions to medication. Given the possible side effects and the need to find the right dose, tracking these patients is a crucial task (Southwestern Medical Clinic of Lakeland, 2023). Table 1 provides an overview of the relevant tasks per group of workers. As can be seen, the main differences can be found regarding medical prescription, which is exclusively done by a psychiatrist, and therapy, which is exclusively not done by psychiatrists. 1.3 Objectives Due to the speed at which the field of AI is advancing, the authors opted by focusing on papers published in the last 4 years, so that the conclusions of the research are based on the most recent findings. The researchers selected empirical studies as sources in order to synthesize and further develop the existing evidence. In light of the possible changes in the work context of mental healthcare workers brought about by Artificial Intelligence systems, the goal of this research was defined as the following: • To characterize the impact of Artificial Intelligence on the tasks of mental healthcare workers according to empirical research published between 2019 and December 2022. Here, impact is considered as the applicability of the AI systems created for the tasks of mental healthcare workers. This applicability concerns how well these technologies translate to real-world scenarios based on: (1) The amount of data used to train the model (i.e. the number of unique instances); (2) The original author's evaluation of the systems' contributions to developments in the field and (or) employment readiness. In order to reach the previously defined goal three objectives were specified: • To verify to what extent the application of Artificial Intelligence systems impacts the tasks of mental healthcare workers; • To describe how Artificial Intelligence systems impact the tasks of mental healthcare workers; • To identify, what are the tasks that the use of Artificial Intelligence systems impacts. The uncertainty regarding the impact of the application of AI technologies on the tasks of mental healthcare professionals emphasizes the importance of shedding light on this influence. In this context, a scoping review was the selected approach to address the objectives. 2 Method 2.1 Protocol and registration The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR) checklist was used as the review protocol (Prisma extension for scoping reviews, 2018). 2.2 Eligibility criteria Regarding inclusion eligibility, the researchers agreed on the following criteria: (1) Research papers; (2) Peer-reviewed, in order to preserve the quality of the results of the study; (3) Empirical papers; (4) Publication dates from 2019 to December 2022 since AI is a quickly developing field, in order to guarantee that the conclusions were based on the most recently developed research; (5) Written in English, in order to be accessible to a wide public; (6) Includes a description of the dataset (number of participants and details); (7) Not retracted; and (8) Inside the scope of the study. The dataset had to be described allowing the researchers to verify the validity of the results of the study. Considering these criteria, conference proceedings, books, case reports, reviews, working papers, and opinion pieces were excluded. 2.3 Information sources The search was conducted on two databases: EBSCOhost with access through a Dutch public university of applied sciences and Worldcat with access through another Dutch public university. Both database sources automatically removed duplicates. However, a few duplicates still remained which were later removed manually. The search strategy was conceived and discussed by the research team. 2.4 Search Boolean phrases were constructed to filter through the articles’ titles and abstracts using relevant search terms (see Table 2 ). Additionally, three filters were applied: (1) Publication date of 2019-12/2022 time frame; (2) Publication in peer-reviewed journals; (3) Written in English; (4) Publication type of “Journal Article”. 2.5 Selection of sources of evidence Initially, a total of 139 articles were collected. Two researchers screened the articles together starting with the title, followed by the abstract and the conclusion. The researchers discussed the inclusion/exclusion of the articles based on the research goals and inclusion criteria. In cases of uncertainty regarding the inclusion of the article, a third researcher with a background in psychology was involved in the decision process and further sections of the paper were read. During this stage, reviewing articles for eligibility involved (1) checking the publication type, (2) screening the title, abstract, and conclusion, and (3) checking the type of study. If after these steps eligibility remained undetermined (for instance, the researchers were unable to confirm a study was empirical, based on title, abstract, and conclusion), the papers were kept for a more in-depth review at a later stage. During this phase, the following data was recorded (separately for each database) in Microsoft Excel: (1) Full citations (i.e., authors, year, title, publication, and DOI); (2) Type of study (empirical/not empirical); (3) In- or excluded; (4) Reason for exclusion (if applicable) and; (5) Comments. 2.6 Data charting process The data charting was inspired by the one presented by (Pisani & Ricart, 2016). The antecedents-phenomenon-consequences model was used to gain insight into the connections between Artificial Intelligence systems and the mental healthcare worker's tasks. It allows the identification of themes regarding key factors that trigger (antecedents) the implementations (phenomenon) and implications for practice (consequences). Since the antecedents, phenomenon and consequences are documented separately paper, they can be critically assessed to determine the impact. The process was conducted by two researchers individually. When a question regarding a data item emerged, both researchers discussed the issue. When an agreement was not reached upon discussion, feedback was requested from a third researcher. Fig. 1 represents the process. 2.7 Data items In the antecedents-phenomenon-consequences ‘Antecedents’ refer to the key factors which trigger the ‘The Phenomenon’. This phenomenon pertains to the main aspects of the implementation. Lastly, ‘Consequences’ describe the Outcomes of the previously described phenomenon (Pisani & Ricart, 2016). The levels of analysis, as defined by Berg (David, 2023), were also added to the table, in order to get an overview of the focal point of the research, these included: (1) The individual level of analysis, which refers to studies that analyze phenomena through the exploration of aspects pertaining to the individual; (2) The Interpersonal level of analysis, that connects to research which examines the topic through studying the relationship between two persons; (3) The group level of analysis, which studies the topic through the exploration of features common to specific groups of people and; (4) The intergroup level of analysis that investigates phenomena through the assessment of the relation between two groups or the representatives of those groups. A table was created during this phase, which included the following information for each paper: (1) ID, a unique identifying code given to each article; (2) N, the number of data instances/participants; (3) Description, including extra information regarding the data sources: (4) Reference; (5) DOI; (6) Level of analysis; (7) Context includes the mental healthcare tasks. Here, each task was coded as a letter: Assessment (A), Therapy (T), Prescription (P), Documentation (D), and Monitoring (M). Antecedents, in which the (8) triggers are presented, pertaining to the objective of the studies. The Phenomenon covers the (8) Field of AI and (9) Key Relationships. The AI field includes Artificial Intelligence in General (AI), Machine Learning (ML), Deep Learning (DL), Symbolic AI (SA), and Fuzzy Systems (FS). Key relationships concern relationships/variables explored by the paper. Finally, the outcomes are covered, including (10) Outcomes of the tasks produced by the AI system(s) and; (11) Practical implications. 3 Results 3.1 Selection of sources of evidence From the 139 collected articles, 22 were excluded due to being duplicates. Following the selection criteria previously presented, 20 papers were excluded due to not pertaining to empirical research. A total of 44 papers were excluded for being outside of the scope of this project (not in the mental health context). This was the case for papers that approached other healthcare topics such as speech therapy, and radiotherapy, or topics that relate to important mental tasks, such as learning and decision-making, but that were analyzed outside of the mental healthcare sphere. Additionally, 3 articles were excluded due to describing research that did not directly connect with mental healthcare workers’ tasks. Moreover, in two of the articles, insufficient information regarding the dataset was available therefore, in accordance with the inclusion criteria, the papers were removed from the project. A research proposal was also excluded, due to not including a concluded study. Finally, one article was removed due to having been retracted. A sum of 46 articles remained to be analyzed by the researchers. Fig. 1 provides an overview of the entire process. 3.2 Characteristics of sources of evidence A systematic analysis of the content of the articles was conducted. The table below presents the research papers and corresponding data. 3.2.1 Instances and data types The minimum number of instances used in the collected literature was 12 (Tsai et al., 2021) and the maximum number of instances in a data source was 275843 (Zhong et al., 2019). The interquartile range (IQR) is 1317, where the 25th percentile (Q1) number of instances was 147.5 and 75th percentile (Q3) 1464.5. From this it can be concluded that the maximum number of instances observed (275843) is an extreme outlier, skewing the summary statistics (M = 8488.83, SD = 41945.32). Noteworthy on this outlier (Zhong et al., 2019) is that the initial data source contained 275843 instances, however, for model development 400 instances were used (200 for training and 200 for validating the models and parameters) and 9331 for evaluation purposes. Removing this outlier is justified given that the dataset for the authors’ study was sampled from a database containing 275843 instances, but their dataset used differed substantially, thus misrepresenting the summary statistics aimed for in this analysis. Then, removing this outlier (Zhong et al., 2019) results in a minimum and maximum sample size of 12 and 20000 respectively, with a lower quartile (IQ1) of 100 instances, upper quartile (IQ3) of 1236 instances, and a median of 340 instances These results indicate that any dataset. with more than 2943.75 (IQ3 + 1.5*(IQ3-IQ1)) instances can be considered an outlier. The figure below (Fig. 2 ) shows the resulting boxplot for the sizes of the datasets used in the described studies. The majority of articles collected data through questionnaires (18 articles), followed by images (12 articles) as the second most used source of data and textual data sources (11 articles). Survey (questionnaire) data sources included responses from individuals in a therapeutic role ((Aktan, Turhan, & Dolu, 2022; Murali Doraiswamy, Blease, & Bodner, 2020; Zhang, Zhang, Ren, & Jiang, 2021), individuals with one or more diagnoses, such as depression (Gómez Penedo et al., 2022; Solomonov et al., 2021), affective disorders (Schwartz et al., 2021), anxiety (Gómez Penedo et al., 2022; Schwartz et al., 2021) and schizophrenia (Fond et al., 2019) and individuals with alcohol dependence (SymonsGerald et al., 2019, 2020). Image data consisted mainly of EEG images (Kumar Rout, Sahani, Dora, Kumar Biswal, & Biswal, 2022; LeiAbdelkader Nasreddine Belkacem et al., 2022; Li et al., 2019; Saeedi, Saeedi, Maghsoudi, & Ahmad, 2021), images of faces (Ahmed et al., 2022; Alsaade & Alzahrani, 2022; Singh & Goyal, 2021), and images related to drawings (Cuerda, Zornoza, Gallud, Tesoriero, & Romero Ayuso, 2022; MoetesumImran et al., 2020; Nolazco-Flores et al., 2022). Regarding the articles using data sources containing texts, it was noted that, of the ten articles which used more than 2000 instances, six fit in the category of using textual data (Dheeraj & Ramakrishnudu, 2021; Ewbank et al., 2020; Levis, Leonard Westgate, Jiang, Watts, & Shiner, 2021; Tanana et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2021; Zhong et al., 2019). Further, textual data originated mainly from therapy session transcripts (Ewbank et al., 2020, 2021; Gunjan et al., 2022; Tanana et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2021), (clinical) notes (Goldberg et al., 2021; Levis et al., 2021; Zhong et al., 2019), and written responses from both online (Dheeraj & Ramakrishnudu, 2021; Huang et al., 2022) and offline (Nolazco-Flores et al., 2022) sources. Other than the above three major data source types, audio was used and automatically converted to text by two articles (Cohen et al., 2020; Goldberg et al., 2020), which is not considered textual source data. One study used behavioral data collected in a virtual environment for the detection of early-stage cognitive impairments (Tsai et al., 2021). One paper extracted information from a database containing medical track records of cancer patients (Günther, Kirchebner, Ben Schulze, von Känel, & Euler, 2022). One article used data for evaluating the user experience of a rule-based AI chatbot (Ardiana, Joni, & Udayana, 2020). Lastly, one article (Marti-Puig, Capra, Vega, Llunas, & Solé-Casals, 2022) used app-activity data in addition to questionnaire data collected through the app (which is included in the questionnaire count). 3.2.2 Levels of analysis and mental healthcare tasks Regarding the level of analysis, all the articles adopted an individual level of analysis, with the exception of Goldberg et al. (Goldberg et al., 2020), which included an interpersonal level of analysis. With respect to the mental healthcare worker's tasks, the vast majority of articles pertain to assessment tasks (28). such as the diagnosis of autism (e.g. Ahmed et al. (Ahmed et al., 2022)), depression (e.g. Victor et al. (Victor, Aghajan, Sewart, & Christian, 2019)), and suicide risk detection (e.g. Levis et al. (Levis et al., 2021)). Monitoring was tackled by 14 research papers, including papers that explored the supervision of a patient's emotional development (e.g. Nolazco-Flores et al. (Nolazco-Flores et al., 2022)), and the prediction of treatment outcomes (e.g. Pearson et al. (Pearson et al., 2019)). Tasks relating to therapy were explored by 7 articles, some of the topics included predicting therapeutic alliance (Goldberg et al., 2020), detecting the therapist's interpersonal skills (Goldberg et al., 2021), providing counseling (Ardiana et al., 2020), and emotion detection systems (Tanana et al., 2021). Finally, prescription and documentation were only studied by one article. Both of these tasks (prescription and documentation) were explored by Doraiswamy, Blease, & Bodner (Murali Doraiswamy et al., 2020), who analyzed perspectives on AI for mental healthcare tasks based on the opinions of physicians, see Fig. 3 . 3.2.3 Goals Regarding the Antecedents, a plurality of goals was explored. A total of 7 articles studied AI for other therapy-related tasks, ranging from more patient-directed approaches such as providing counseling (e.g. Ardiana, Joni, and Udayana (Ardiana et al., 2020)) and personalizing treatment (e.g. Penedo et al. (Gómez Penedo et al., 2022)) to more therapist-based ones. This category includes systems for detecting compassion fatigue in helpline counselors (Zhang et al., 2021) and making emotion extraction from transcripts in psychotherapy easier for therapists (Tanana et al., 2021). The prediction of treatment outcomes or relapse was another frequent objective, with a total of 8 articles. One of these papers was the one by Pearson et al. (Pearson et al., 2019), which employed a machine learning system to predict treatment outcomes for depression. Improvement in the detection of suicide risk and assessment of depression were two explored goals. The first one was the antecedent of 6 papers, most of which focused on supporting the prediction of the risk of suicide (e.g. Xu et al. (Xu et al., 2021)), and the second one focused on the assessment of depression and triggered a sum of 4 research pieces (Li et al., 2019; Saeedi et al., 2021; Singh & Goyal, 2021; Victor et al., 2019). 17 articles studied AI for other assessment tasks, such as the diagnosis of schizophrenia (e.g. Appaji et al. (Appaji et al., 2022)) and dementia (Tsai et al., 2021). Treatment personalization was explored by two research pieces such as Penedo et al. (Gómez Penedo et al., 2022), whom studied AI to personalize treatment in routine care. Lastly, Creed et al. (Creed et al., 2022) explored individuals' perceptions of AI-driven cognitive behavioral therapy, and Doraiswamy et al. (Murali Doraiswamy et al., 2020) focused on physicians' perspectives regarding the use of AI for mental healthcare workers’ tasks. 3.2.4 Artificial intelligence fields Regarding the field of AI, articles most commonly explored Machine Learning techniques, with a sum of 27 articles pertaining to ML systems such as Zhong et al. (Zhong et al., 2019) whom applied Machine Learning to clinical notes, with the goal of predicting suicidal tendencies in pregnant women. The second most employed technique was Deep Learning, explored by a total of 21 research pieces. One of these papers was by Saeedi et al. (Saeedi et al., 2021), whom used DL for the early diagnosis of depression. The field of Artificial Intelligence (in general) was approached by three research papers, all of which aimed at understanding perceptions towards the usage of AI in different mental health contexts, an example is Creed et al. (Creed et al., 2022), which studied the perspectives of stakeholders regarding the application of AI for fidelity measurement in cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). Fuzzy systems were employed three times, such as by Dutt, Ahuja, and Kumar (DuttNeelu Jyothi Ahuja and Kumar, 2022), whom applied FS together with DL for the assessment of students’ disabilities, and Symons et al. (SymonsGerald et al., 2019), who used FS with ML for predicting the outcome of the treatment of alcoholism. Finally, Symbolic Artificial Intelligence was only employed once by Ardiana, Joni, and Udayana (Ardiana et al., 2020) in the creation of an AI chatbot for HIV and AIDS counseling. Fig. 4 shows the number of articles per field of AI, where some articles may utilize systems from multiple fields. Fig. 5 shows the relative frequency of each field of AI given each task. Regarding the task of assessment, 54.5% studied systems in the field of DL, 39.4% ML. The remaining 6.1% is equally divided amongst FS and SA. Note, however, that some articles studied multiple fields of AI, such as Ni et al. (NiDrew et al., 2020) and Lyu and Zhang (Lyu & Zhang, 2019). Regarding monitoring, 73.3% pertained to the field of ML. However, since the total occurrences of the fields within the task of monitoring are 14, of which 11 pertain to ML, it would be misleading to report percentages for single occurrences for the remaining fields. As such, with regards to the task of monitoring, AI in general was the field of AI twice, while FS and DL occurred once each. 3.2.5 Key relationships Regarding the key relationships, 26 articles studied AI in connection with the diagnosis of multiple mental health conditions, including schizophrenia (e.g. Alsaade and Alzahrani (Alsaade & Alzahrani, 2022) and other mental health issues such as Acquired Brain Injuries (Cuerda et al., 2022). A sum of 12 papers explored the prediction of treatment outcomes. Here, two approaches are adopted: while some researchers focused on patient-clinician interactions, such as Ewbank et al. (Ewbank et al., 2021) who used therapy data from communications between patients and therapists to evaluate therapeutic outcomes, others employed assessment (questionnaire) data, such as Solomonov et al. (Solomonov et al., 2021) who used the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (Hamilton, 1960) to assess patients and predict aspects that lead to the patient not responding to the treatment. Two papers analyzed the use of AI for the training of therapists. Goldberg et al. (Goldberg et al., 2021) explored AI for the evaluation of the interpersonal skills of therapists. Creed et al. (Creed et al., 2022) studied the perceptions of stakeholders regarding the use of AI in the measurement of fidelity in cognitive behavioral therapy. Furthermore, two papers studied the use of AI to monitor patients’ moods, one through the use of writing and drawing data (Nolazco-Flores et al., 2022) and the other one through the application of therapy transcripts (Tanana et al., 2021). AI as a support agent for counseling was explored in three papers, such as Ardiana, Joni, and Udayana (Ardiana et al., 2020), through the creation and evaluation of an AI-AIDS HIV counseling chatbot. In this same category, Aktan, Turhan, and Dolu (Aktan et al., 2022) studied the perceptions regarding Artificial Intelligence systems as psychotherapists. Finally, one article (Murali Doraiswamy et al., 2020) researched the perspectives of physicians regarding AI for the replacement of mental healthcare workers in the mental healthcare tasks explored in this paper. 3.2.6 Task outcomes and practical implications The researchers identified three types of task outcomes: (1) Artificial Intelligence systems that contribute to assisting and supporting mental healthcare workers in the performance of their tasks; (2) Artificial Intelligence systems that contribute to the development and application of AI in the replacement of healthcare professionals in some of their tasks and; (3) Understanding of individual's perceptions regarding AI in mental healthcare contexts. Further, the classification of systems as either tools for assisting or replacing mental healthcare workers was conducted systematically. This process was as follows: where the original authors employed terms such as “replacing” and (or) “automating” to describe the artificial intelligence systems, those were considered as tools that replace the mental healthcare worker in one or more particular tasks. Conversely, in contexts where the original authors refer to the systems as tools to “assist” and/or “help”, those are coded as AI systems to support mental healthcare workers in one or more tasks. The first outcome was explored by 26 papers such as (Huang et al., 2022) who successfully applied Deep Learning for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, which could aid medical professionals in identifying the level of severity of the patient's condition. A sum of 17 articles explored AI as an autonomous system for the performance of tasks. One of these articles was the one by Symons et al. (SymonsGerald et al., 2020), where the authors explored AI for the prediction of the outcome of the treatment of alcoholism. Here, AI reached a higher level of accuracy in predicting treatment outcomes compared to healthcare professionals. Finally, three articles provided insight into individuals' perspectives on AI. The paper Aktan, Turhan, and Dolu (Aktan et al., 2022) was one of the pieces that focused on perspectives regarding AI. The authors studied individuals' perceptions and individual towards help-seeking and how those relate to a preference for AI therapy. One of the points observed in this article was that even though most participants hold a higher level of trust toward human counselors, 55% of them showed a preference for AI therapy. Regarding the practical implications, most articles contributed to improvements in the field of research. However, in five instances the performance did not reach satisfactory levels, such as in Symons et al. (SymonsGerald et al., 2019) in which Machine Learning was employed for the prediction of treatment outcomes. Here, in most cases, the system's performance was not higher than chance. 3.3 Results of individual sources of evidence A selection of representative sources of evidence (as described in section 3.2) can be seen in Table 3 .3 for each tasks. Since Documenting and Prescription were only covered by one article, these have been combined. 4 Discussion For this scoping review 46 empirical studies, between the dates of 2019 and December 2022, were analyzed. Considering that the goal of this paper is to characterize the impact of Artificial Intelligence on the tasks of mental healthcare workers, according to empirical research, this section is presented as follows. First, the summary evidence is discussed. Here, each of the subgoals is examined against the results. Additionally, the several tasks of mental healthcare workers are considered, being analyzed to what extent those tasks are affected and the corresponding consequences in terms of human resource management. Second, the limitations of the current literature review are described. Third, the conclusion is presented. Here, conceptual propositions for stimulating future studies are shared. Furthermore, some research gaps are identified and the corresponding future studies are proposed. 4.1 Summary of evidence Artificial Intelligence concerns systems that aim to replicate human reasoning (Millington, 2019). These technologies are expected to greatly transform work contexts (Bughin et al., 2017) and are currently already being explored for mental healthcare tasks (Tom et al., 2019). In light of increasing the understanding of how these systems impact mental healthcare workers’ tasks, this paper examined that impact on tasks of psychologists, therapists/counselors, and psychiatrists. The impact of AI on assessment, therapy, prescription, documentation, and monitoring was explored through the analysis of the literature. Peer-reviewed, empirical research papers written in English were included. Further, it was required that articles include a description of the dataset used. The findings and supporting arguments are summarized in Table 4 and will be discussed next. First, from the antecedents-phenomon-consequence model it is clear that a need for improvement triggered the application studies of AI integrated into the mental health care setting (antecedents). It was found that only four of the reviewed articles state that their systems are not ready for implementation into practice yet. This indicates that AI is currently impacting and may increasingly impact the tasks of mental healthcare workers. However, the majority of articles use few instances to develop their systems, ranging from 100 to 1236 instances. A minority used anywhere between 2944 to upwards of 20000 instances, with an exceptional case with a database consisting of 273843. This large database, however, had yet to be filtered for relevant cases, reducing the final sample size from 273843 to 400 instances for model development. The small sample sizes are an issue, given that if the number of instances is low, while the number of features is relatively large, it becomes increasingly more difficult to reliably capture meaningful information in the feature space, in addition to generalizing to a larger population. However, most AI systems originated from the field of Machine Learning (27) and Deep Learning (21). Machine Learning systems generally perform well on small datasets, while Deep Learning systems perform well when on high-dimensional data (Janiesch et al., 2021). Thus, given that (1) a need for improvement triggered research, (2) the majority of systems originated from within the field of Machine Learning, which require less data than deep learning systems, and (3) only four out of 46 papers stated their systems are not ready for real-world application, it is reasonable to assume that AI has and will have an impact, which answers the first sub-goal of this paper. This leads to the next (second) subgoal, to establish, in case there is an impact, how Artificial Intelligence will affect the tasks of mental healthcare professionals. Firstly, as mentioned, the number of instances used for model development reduces the systems’ capabilities to generalize and capture information in the feature space, thus making them less reliable to function independently. Secondly, most articles (26 in total) were aimed at assisting and supporting mental healthcare workers. This is much more than the number of articles (17 in total) targeting systems capable of replacing mental healthcare workers in their tasks. Following these two points, it is reasonable to assume that AI systems will be incorporated into the tasks of mental healthcare workers more than replacing them, or, at least, the authors show more attention towards aiding professionals versus replacing them. The implication of that to the HRM in mental healthcare is that intensive training interventions are required to make professionals able to use AI in their jobs. Furthermore, since it is a fast pace evolving field, expertise is required for mental healthcare organizations, maybe experts in AI specifically applicable to the mental healthcare context. The remaining (third) subgoal is to identify the tasks that Artificial Intelligence systems impact. The results show that the majority of studies addressed the tasks of assessment (n = 28), monitoring (n = 14), and therapy (n = 7). Medical prescription and documentation were explored by only one article (Murali Doraiswamy et al., 2020), which was a survey study and, as such, not focused on developing an AI system. In it, the authors found that physicians rated the likelihood of AI systems replacing psychiatrists in a series of tasks, of which documentation-related tasks were estimated as most likely. This contrasts with what the aforementioned results suggest: research is disproportionately focused on assessment tasks. Monitoring and therapy were less explored, but still present in some of the articles. Thus, it is estimated that Artificial Intelligence is most likely to transform the tasks of assessment, monitoring, and therapy. Overall, most papers focused on employing AI technologies for aiding mental healthcare workers, however, a portion of the papers test the employment of fully automated systems. The majority of studies displays promising results, which shows that these could become valuable tools for increasing professionals’ abilities within their work context. Regarding assessment, AI systems can classify patients, currently mainly through analyzing questionnaire, image, or text data. The systems can detect a series of mental health conditions such as suicidal tendencies, depression, and autism. It is expected that these systems could (1) speed up diagnosing patients, and (or) (2) find paths of further inquiry. A similar thing can be said for the task of monitoring, where systems can aid in estimating a patient's development and inform mental healthcare professionals of the expected treatment outcomes. Here, the reviewed papers explored ranged from general approaches, such as forecasting psychotherapy outcomes and detecting patients' mood, to more specific treatments, such as the monitoring of the treatment of alcoholism. This indicates that these systems could contribute to improvements in the delivery of treatment and the identification of variables associated with positive therapeutic results. It is expected that by mastering AI and using it in assessment tasks, mental healthcare workers can focus on the therapeutic process, since the assessment is performed primarily by the system. Furthermore, using AI in monitoring in supervision processes allows the supervisor and the supervisee to check their subjective perception against the objective record. This way, the use of AI can improve the professional development provided by supervision processes. Lastly, with respect to the task of therapy, AI systems can transform this task by providing live feedback regarding the client's emotional state as well as providing insight into variables regarding patient-therapist interactions, such as therapeutic alliance which could contribute to the training of professionals. Regarding perspectives toward the use of AI for training, stakeholders considered these tools as useful but are uncertain about their abilities to capture some important information, like the nuances of non-verbal communication. Some studies are already trying to capture these nuances, such as Singh and Goyal (Singh & Goyal, 2021), which used video data to detect depressed subjects achieving a precision of 64. Although this precision level is not high, it might be improved in future studies. One research paper also employed an AI chatbot for AIDS/HIV counseling, suggesting that these systems could become helpful as autonomous systems for therapy (Ardiana et al., 2020). However, such an application raises ethical concerns, such as the fact that AI is limited in the type of empathetic care it can provide. The remaining tasks, documenting and medical prescription, were only explored by articles that examined the perspective of individuals regarding the use of AI for those tasks. So far, no transformation in these tasks is expected in terms of AI integration. However, when dealing with AI systems in mental healthcare tasks, patients express their ideas and perceptions regarding these systems. They can reject, accept, or even prefer dealing with AI Systems. Consequently, those who reject the system because they perceive it ineffective or threatening do not cooperate in an effective and positive interaction. Thus, that perception makes the system weak. Contrariwise, those who accept or prefer to deal with AI systems cooperate and make the system effective. Therefore, pa perceptions of AI Systems impact how healthcare workers perform their tasks to use those systems properly with those patients, It can be expected that therapy assessment and monitoring may become grounded in stronger and more reliable indicators through the use of AI systems, making it possible for the professional to focus on the quality of the therapeutic interaction without missing relevant data. Moreover, professional development such as that promoted by supervision practice can be improved by introducing AI systems that help the professional in tasks that are highly attention-demanding but are not specifically therapy and treatment. In Fig. 6 , the AI tasks impacted and type of impacts are presented. 4.2 Limitations This study has some limitations. Firstly, the evaluation of the level of performance of the AI systems was fully based on what was stated in the research papers. Neither the quality nor the accuracy of the original claims was assessed. For instance, one of the papers (Ardiana et al., 2020) assessed their system using a usability study and concluded that the system helps in counseling based on the results that (1) a correct answer to information-related questions was given 71% of the time, and (2) that users rated the usability of the system positively. The relationship between whether a system's usability is good and the effectiveness of counseling was not clarified, nor was the minimum level of accuracy required for a system to be helpful in counseling. Another article (Appaji et al., 2022) developed a system that could correctly identify schizophrenia in 95% of the cases but added that the system is not ready for real-world application. These examples highlight the different standards set in terms of system performance and deciding on its effectiveness. Lastly, very few papers compared AI systems to human performance, such as Ni et al. (NiDrew et al., 2020), resulting in very little comparative insight into the performance of these technologies. For instance, perhaps 71% correctness could be considered good if shown that humans perform much worse on the same task, while 95% accuracy might be very poor if humans are close to 100% accurate. These examples highlight the different standards set to assess whether a system could replace a mental healthcare worker, or support them in, a particular task. Secondly, and in connection with the previous points, many studies include a small number of data instances, making it more difficult to generalize based on the results. Thirdly, the details added to the table were in accordance with the original papers. For this reason, it is important to mention that in the article by Dheeraj and Tene Ramakrishnudu (Dheeraj & Ramakrishnudu, 2021), there was an incorrect claim. Mental problems, such as addiction, were classified as emotions. It was noted that this information was questionable but the table was kept in line with the original piece for consistency. Fourthly, regarding the level of autonomy of the explored AI systems, while it is true that some of these systems can perform tasks independently, that does not imply that they should replace the mental healthcare worker. On one hand, this is due to the importance of the presence of the professional for a series of aspects surrounding their tasks, such as providing empathetic care to patients during their treatment. According to Moudatsou et al. (Moudatsou et al., 2020), individuals working in therapeutic contexts who possess higher levels of empathy achieve better results in their functions. However, AI systems do not have the same abilities for empathy as humans (Montemayor et al., 2022) On the other hand, due to the fact that the skills of AI and humans complement each other, highlighting the potential of hybrid intelligence (Dellermann et al., 2018). As stated by Kamar (Kamar, 2016), humans already play an important role in the training of these systems. An alternative argument could be made that AI systems not presented as fully automated may become so later on. An example can be seen in the assessment of autism, accuracy level of 95% was achieved in the best-performing model [5]. Therefore, even though mental healthcare professionals are mentioned as an important part of the process, these technologies might be applied to execute some of these tasks autonomously in the future. Finally, another limitation of this literature review is the disregard of publication bias. Since it would be time demanding and affect the authors’ ability of delivering a scoping literature review in a fast-evolving field, the required procedures to check possible publication bias were excluded. In future literature reviews that bias should be checked. 4.3 Conclusions Overall, AI shows promising results for application in mental healthcare. Currently, most developments in this field aim to support mental healthcare workers in their tasks, namely assessment, monitoring, and some on therapy. These observations highlight the importance of considering the social and economical implications of the implementation of these systems for mental healthcare and the professional's role in the context of these new technologies. Considering these results, the following propositions are presented: Proposition 1 Providing adequate training to mental healthcare professionals to increase their skills using AI systems in assessment and monitoring tasks improves the quality of the therapeutic process. The rationale for that proposition is that the use of AI enables them to focus on therapeutic and treatment functions instead of focusing their attention on other demanding tasks (for example assessment). Proposition 2 In light of AI’s application for supporting workers, it might be relevant to train individuals on the functioning of these new technologies, in order to guarantee the proper use of these systems and enable positive outcomes, such as the reduced burden on mental healthcare systems and increased support of mental healthcare professionals while avoiding some possible drawbacks. Negative outcomes of the application of these systems could include an increase in job losses and reduced quality of services caused by, for instance, a lack of empathetic care. Future studies should focus on the following topics: (1) To explore the application of Artificial Intelligence for tasks such as medical prescription and documentation, which were not applied by any of the research pieces present in this literature review; (2) It is also relevant to compare systems’ performance to that of human beings and to test their accuracy in hybrid contexts, in order to gain deeper insight into the benefit of the use of these technologies. Furthermore, it is important (3) to look into ways of safeguarding empathy in the context of AI-supported mental healthcare and to measure the implications of autonomous AI-driven therapy systems, to; (4) To study the consequences of the implementation of these technologies in real-world scenarios. Finally, it is crucial to research (5) how to implement these systems considering the work context of professionals, by, for instance, exploring possible training programs, their social impact on workers, and other related practicalities.
