The Department of Information and Communication Engineering Tongji University Shanghai 201804 China Climate change is one of the most pressing challenges facing the world today. The large amount of greenhouse gas emissions produced by human activities, especially the emission of carbon dioxide, is an important driving factor behind climate issues. Under the background of China’s “3060” decarbonization goal”, Chongming District in Shanghai is actively promoting the construction of a world-class ecological island and is committed to creating a carbon–neutral demonstration zone with global influence. However, Chongming District faces challenges as the mechanism of carbon-neutrality transition path remains unclear. The data related to evaluating carbon neutrality status are heterogeneous from multiple sources. It is difficult to effectively implement relevant evaluation and response measures, impeding the progress of its low-carbon transformation. In response to the aforementioned challenges, this paper will propose and discuss the potential methods based on the new generation of information technology, represented by big data and artificial intelligence. These technologies aim to facilitate the integration of diverse factors, including carbon, and explore the nexus among them, thus exploring pathways for low-carbon transformation, and ultimately achieving decarbonization goal in Chongming District. Hopefully, the research conducted in this paper will contribute to the efforts of China and the global community in addressing carbon-related challenges and advancing towards a more sustainable and low-carbon future. Keywords New generation of information technology Big data Artificial intelligence Deep learning Multi-element nexus 1 Introduction In the present era, climate change is one of the most pressing issues facing humanity. With rapid social, economic, and technological developments, the greenhouse gas emissions resulting from human activities, particularly carbon dioxide emissions, are increasing at an alarming rate, becoming a major driver of global climate change. As a responsible major country, China has put forward the “3060″ decarbonization goal (Wang and Zhang, 2020) and has called for localized research on the evolution mechanisms and patterns of carbon neutrality in typical regions. In the context of the “3060″ decarbonization goal, selecting Chongming District as a testing ground and breakthrough point for achieving carbon peak and carbon neutrality holds significant importance. On the one hand, as the only world-class ecological island in China, Chongming District relies on its unique geographical location and natural resources to embrace a low-carbon, green, and eco-friendly development approach. This strategy has led to significant progress in policy formulation and practical implementation, particularly in areas such as energy utilization, energy conservation, emission reduction, and low-carbon transformation (Li et al., 2020). On the other hand, when compared to other cities that are building low-carbon demonstration zones, Chongming District still lags behind in economic development, transportation, technological advancements, and several other aspects. It is confronted with many challenges on the road to achieve the decarbonization goal, including unclear paths, relatively insufficient infrastructure construction, and poor ability to comprehensively coordinate various elements, etc (Luo et al., 2011; Ma et al., 2018). However, being situated within the radiance of the Shanghai metropolitan area, Chongming District holds immense potential for low-carbon and eco-friendly urbanization and industrialization. In fact, its scale in constructing a world-class ecological island surpasses that of any other low-carbon city construction project. Therefore, if a successful low-carbon transition pathway can be established in Chongming District, it will provide valuable experience for the high-quality development of the Yangtze River Delta region and the entire country. It will also serve as a new model for green and low-carbon transformations in developing countries, contributing to the global decarbonization goal. With the development of information technology and the Internet, we have entered an era of data explosion. A massive amount of data is continuously generated, and as the scale of data expands, traditional data analysis and processing techniques are facing limitations and bottlenecks. These massive, multi-source heterogeneous data can bring rich information and value to evaluating the carbon neutrality status, but at the same time put forward new requirements for high-performance computing, storage technology and analysis technology. In recent years, the rapid developing new generation of information technology, such as artificial intelligence and big data, has shown their immense potential for applications in various disciplines and interdisciplinary research. Therefore, integrating new-generation information technologies like big data and artificial intelligence into the evaluation of carbon neutrality status is of great importance (Rabah, 2018; Misra et al., 2020; IoT and cloud, 2020; Zhang and Lu, 2021). Previous studies have indicated that big data and artificial intelligence technologies play a significant role in evaluating carbon neutrality status, particularly in data monitoring, carbon emission and absorption calculations, process forecasting, decarbonization pathway planning, and policy implementation (Chen et al., 2021). However, the majority of these existing studies have only focused on exploring the application potential of individual technologies within specific domains, such as the use of artificial intelligence in promoting carbon reduction in the energy industry. There is a lack of a comprehensive system that spans multiple domains and includes the entire process of data acquisition, storage, management, analysis, validation, and application. This paper delves into two aspects: big data technology and artificial intelligence technology. Firstly, we discuss the limitations of traditional methods in acquiring and processing carbon-related data. Subsequently, based on big data and artificial intelligence technology, we introduce a comprehensive evaluation framework which cover the entire process of data acquisition, storage, management, analysis, validation, and application. This framework has the potential to unveil the nexus among various elements, including social, economic, ecological and geographical aspects, and promote their integration with carbon related elements in Chongming District. By identifying and establishing the inherent correlations between different elements and carbon neutrality status, a more comprehensive and accurate system for evaluating carbon neutrality status can be established, which will ultimately help the realization of the decarbonization goal. 2 Harnessing the power of big data technology: Acquisition and management of heterogeneous multi-source data for carbon neutrality 2.1 The limitations of traditional approaches in acquiring and storing heterogeneous multi-source data In today's digital world, the application of big data continues to penetrate and expand across various fields, demonstrating unprecedented insights and innovative potential in the process of social, economic, and technological development, and bringing enormous opportunities. However, along with these opportunities, there also come a series of challenges. On the one hand, big data holds tremendous potential in uncovering intricate nexuses and patterns that may remain hidden in small-scale data. On the other hand, the characteristics of big data, such as large volume, high dimensionality, and heterogeneity, put forward new and higher demands for data acquisition and storage (Fan et al., 2014). Traditional data analysis methods face certain challenges in monitoring, evaluating and managing carbon neutrality status, which primarily arise from factors such as data disorder, isolation, and lack of collectiveness (Chunming et al., 2015). These limitations make it challenging to integrate data and conduct comprehensive analysis. Therefore, in order to enhance the monitoring, evaluating and management of carbon neutrality status in Chongming District, it is necessary to adopt new data acquisition technologies and methods to capture the hidden patterns, promote the integration, and conduct correlation analysis of diverse data and elements. Furthermore, traditional storage systems are not designed to handle these huge data, so they cannot effectively store and process big data. In the face of big data, traditional data storage systems present several challenges, including: read-write patterns, storage costs, proprietary hardware costs, complexity, data heterogeneity, applying data to programs, etc (Faridoon and Imran, 2021). In order to deal with these problems, new data storage and processing mode architectures are proposed (Casado and Younas, 2015; Chen et al., 2014; Mehmood et al., 2019). By adopting these new technologies, large-scale data related to carbon neutrality status can be effectively stored, retrieved and managed. The combination of advanced data storage capabilities and innovative data acquisition approaches provide data support for conducting in-depth analysis of the carbon neutrality status in Chongming District. 2.2 Multi-source heterogeneous data acquisition system In the era of big data, data acquisition is a fundamental step in conducting research related to data analysis, involving the retrieval of data from diverse sources, including private sources, as well as public sources (Chaulagain et al., 2017). So, it is crucial to employ various tools and technologies for data acquisition. With the widespread use of the Internet, the amount of data available online has experienced a rapid growth, and manual data retrieval becomes highly inefficient, leading to a decline in competitiveness (Khder, 2021). Based on the aforementioned situation, web crawling technology has emerged. Web crawling, also known as web scraping or web spidering, is an automated technique for extracting information from the internet. By simulating the behavior of a human browser, web crawlers automatically access web pages, extract data, and store it locally or in other target locations. It frees people from manual data retrieval tasks, enabling computer applications to efficiently and accurately gather web data (Lawson, 2015). The advantages of web crawling have made it widely used in both commercial and scientific research fields. Hillen (Hillen, 2019) conducted research on food prices using web crawling, demonstrating the immense potential of web scraping in the field of food price analysis. Vording (Vording, 2021) pointed out that high-quality and large-scale data obtained through web crawling can optimize decision-making in market pricing, trend analysis, and research and development. He (He, 2014) utilized web crawling techniques to acquire carbon information disclosed by companies on public platforms. By combining index methods and multiple linear regression models, she obtained the Carbon Disclosure Index (CDI) and explored its relationship with factors such as company size, industry sector, and company nature, making a significant contribution to China's decarbonization goal. These studies have made significant contributions by demonstrating the ability of web crawling to acquire diverse and heterogeneous data, which is valuable for subsequent analysis. Also, it is worth mentioning that the use of satellite remote sensing data for detecting and evaluating carbon dioxide level has been a recent focus of research. Previous studies have demonstrated the significant progress made in utilizing satellite remote sensing data for understanding climate change (Yang et al., 2013), inverting and estimating carbon dioxide concentrations (Hong et al., 2022), monitoring and evaluating wetland resources (Ozesmi and Bauer, 2002), and facilitating global biodiversity monitoring by involving experts from various fields (Pettorelli et al., 2018). Considering the above research results on data acquisition methods and the characteristics of Chongming District, we propose a data acquisition framework which contains web crawling technology and “Space-Sky-Ground” integrated monitoring system. The “Space-Sky-Ground” integrated monitoring system for data acquisition refers to a comprehensive approach that utilizes various data sources to capture information for the carbon neutrality status in Chongming District. In this system, “Space” represents the utilization of satellite remote sensing data to acquire macro-scale data. “Sky” refers to the use of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) data to capture medium-scale data within specific geographic areas. “Ground” involves the deployment of various ground-based sensors to collect smaller-scale data in proximity to the sensor installation sites. Fig. 1 shows the proposed data acquisition Framework. For the multi-source heterogeneous data acquisition framework, we will discuss the specific data that can be collected by each of the components below. Web crawling can help us access the following publicly available data on the Internet: • Chongming Statistical Yearbook and monthly bulletin. Including comprehensive social data of Chongming District (e.g. population size, GDP, major economic indicators, etc.), basic production and gross output value of industry and agriculture, living and production situation of different townships and green ecological indicators. • Data from public monitoring sites in Chongming District. Including daily weather conditions, air quality, and other data publicly released by monitoring stations. These data can serve as specific supplements to the statistical yearbook, effectively reflecting the changing trends of various elements and carbon emissions. • Company information data. Including the basic business information of companies (e.g. industry sector, economic scale, and geographic location, etc) as well as the enterprise's self-disclosed data (e.g. carbon emissions, energy consumption, and wastewater and gas emissions, etc.). These data can be utilized to establish the relationship between production patterns and carbon emissions for subsequent analysis. • Real-time Internet data. This mainly includes real-time data obtained from various websites, web platforms, social media, and other channels, capturing market trends, public engagement, carbon reduction policies, and other relevant information. These data can assist in understanding the current status of the public's practice of carbon emission reduction (Yang et al., 2021), and at the same time can be used as a complementary basis for evaluating the low carbon transition process (Chen et al., 2022). For the “Space” in the Space-Sky-Ground“ integrated monitoring data acquisition system, we can acquire the following data: • Data on topography of different areas of Chongming District. Previous studies have shown that differences in soil organic carbon stocks in different parts of the terrain, as well as differences in the intensity and rate of weathering under different terrain conditions, will have an impact on carbon cycling and carbon evaluation (Berhe et al., 2008). Therefore, it is necessary to use satellite remote sensing image data to obtain topographic data of different areas as an important reference for carbon evaluation. • Forest-related data. Forest can absorb and fix atmospheric carbon dioxide through photosynthesis, thereby playing a significant role in carbon sink. So these data can make an important contribution to estimating the forest carbon dioxide flux in Chongming District (Cho et al., 2021). • Land-related data. Chongming District is primarily dominated by agricultural industry, and the characteristics and changes in land use intensity and coverage types are closely linked to the total carbon emissions and trends (He and Zhang, 2022). • Wetland-related data. On the one hand, wetlands are a significant Terrian type in Chongming District. On the other hand, wetlands have a strong carbon sequestration capacity and are also a source of methane emissions (Oikawa et al., 2017). • Coastal organism data. Chongming District is surrounded by the ocean, and it possesses abundant “coastal blue carbon” resources, including salt marshes, mangroves, and seagrass beds, which have a strong capacity for carbon fixation and storage (Wylie et al., 2016). Leveraging remote sensing image enables the detection and evaluation of carbon distribution in different regions of Chongming District. For the “Sky” in the Space-Sky-Ground“ integrated monitoring data acquisition system, we can obtain the following data related to enterprises, agriculture, nature reserves and other parks (hereinafter referred to as ”parks“). • Airborne gas composition within the parks. The drone can accurately obtain the level of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide, in the air within the park area by carrying a variety of gas sensors. These data can be used to validate the accuracy of data derived from other indirect methods. • Infrastructure-related data within the parks. Due to the ability to transmit real-time video and image data, drones can perform real-time inspections of infrastructure in enterprises and agricultural parks, such as power supply networks, transmission pipelines, and fishery-lights complementary facilities. By collecting these data and establishing the relationship with greenhouse gas content in the air, it is possible to enhance the efficiency of infrastructure utilization and promote its development towards high efficiency and low carbon emissions. • Soil-related data with the parks. The interaction between crops and soil is mutual. On the on hand, the conditions of crops will affect the storage and content of soil organic carbon (Zhang et al., 2019). On the other hand, soil rich in organic carbon can reduce the application of fertilizers during the crop growth cycle, thereby reducing greenhouse gas emissions. At the same time, organic carbon resources can be developed and utilized to replace fossil energy. Therefore, the condition of soil and crops is closely related to the carbon cycle of the whole park ecosystem and should be treated as an important element for carbon evaluation. For the “Ground” in the Space-Sky-Ground“ integrated monitoring data acquisition system, we can obtain the following data of a specific monitoring point: • Basic environment parameters. Including temperature, humidity, light intensity, etc. Considering that Chongming District is mainly based on agricultural industries, these environmental parameters are closely related to agricultural production factors such as crop growth and soil conditions. • Production energy consumption and emission parameters. Including power consumption, wastewater discharge and composition, waste gas discharge and composition, etc. Firstly, as one of the major energy consumers in the production, electricity comes mainly from fossil fuels, the combustion of which releases large amounts of greenhouse gases. Secondly, agricultural and industrial production generates a large amount of wastewater containing various organic and inorganic compounds, the biochemical decomposition of which releases greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide and methane. Lastly, the content and composition of exhaust gases obtained by ground sensors can be used to supplement the data obtained by satellites and UAVs. Through the above data acquisition system, we have obtained various types of data relevant to evaluating the carbon neutrality status of Chongming District. To ensure the quality of the acquired data, we also need to clean and standardize the data (Rahm and Do, 2000; Gal and Rubinfeld, 2019). For non-image data, we can use the “Pandas” library in Python to perform operations such as handling missing values, handling outliers, removing duplicates, standardizing data formats, converting data types, and performing numerical normalization and standardization (Brownlee, 2020). For image data, such as satellite remote sensing data, Python also provides libraries like “GDAL” for data cleansing and standardization, performing operations such as data cropping, resampling, merging, splitting, and format conversion (Garrard, 2016). Based on the above analysis, web crawlers provide efficient support for obtaining social and economic data related to the carbon neutrality status of Chongming District released publicly on the Internet. At the same time, the “Space-Sky-Ground” integrated monitoring data acquisition method composed of satellite remote sensing data, UAV telemetry data and ground sensor data has achieved complementary advantages in obtaining various types of data related to the geography and ecology of Chongming District. Furthermore, by cleansing and standardizing the collected data, the accuracy and completeness of the data is significantly improved and the efficiency of data storage is enhanced. This whole system provides macro, local, and micro-scale data support for the carbon neutrality evaluation in Chongming District. 2.3 Multi-source heterogeneous data storage and management scheme The data acquisition system based on “Space-Sky-Ground” integrated monitoring and web crawling data acquisition system provides a rich and valuable data resource for monitoring and evaluating the carbon neutrality status in Chongming District. However, traditional relational databases have encountered bottlenecks in the storage of these unstructured multi-source heterogeneous data (Subramaniyaswamy et al., 2015). Traditional SQL data uses expensive mapping frameworks and complex algorithms to solve the problem that the data model cannot match the relational model. This is unacceptable when dealing with real-time, heterogeneous, and large-scale data required for evaluating the carbon neutrality status in Chongming District (Hecht and Jablonski, 2011). Therefore, a new storage strategy that is suitable for the characteristics of big data is required. Currently, in order to cope with the challenges posed by big data to storage management technology, significant progress has been made in the research on NoSQL (not only SQL) (Siddiqa et al., 2017). NoSQL, as a feasible solution, overcomes the problems of traditional relational databases, and has the advantages of fast reading and writing data, supporting massive storage, easy expansion and low cost (Khan and Mane, 2013; Han et al., 2011). Among them, Google developed Google File System (GFS) (Ghemawat and Gobioff, 2003) and Bigtable (Chang et al., 2008) based on large-scale distributed data management methods and distributed multi-dimensional array mapping technology. These two systems cooperate with each other in Google's infrastructure, providing efficient data storage and management capabilities for various Google services. In addition, the research and application achievements of GFS and Bigtable have contributed to the rapid development of distributed data management concepts, giving rise to systems such as the distributed file system Hadoop (Borthakur, 2008), the data storage solution for big data, HBase (George, 2011), and the distributed database Hypertable (Khetrapal and Ganesh, 2006). MongoDB, which belongs to the NoSQL category, is a good choice for storing and managing the big data related to the carbon neutrality status in Chongming District. MongoDB is an open-source NoSQL database that provides a flexible distributed data storage and management solution, focusing on document-oriented data, with high reliability, availability, scalability, and responsiveness (Plugge et al., 2015). MongoDB encompasses three key elements: Database, Collection, and Document. In this context, a Database serves as the physical container for Collections. Collections, in turn, consist of Documents that possess similar or related attributes. Users have the freedom to define the names of their Documents. Within a given Collection, Documents are not required to share the same set of fields or structure, and common fields can accommodate data of varying types (Chauhan, 2019).Due to the data used to evaluate the carbon neutrality status in Chongming District combines various elements such as society, economy, ecology, and geography, it possesses characteristics of heterogeneity and unstructured nature. Consequently, personalized storage formats need to be defined according to specific requirements. While traditional relational databases like SQL do not support fully customizable storage based on user needs (Győrödi et al., 2015), MongoDB offers a suitable solution. MongoDB, with its document-oriented approach, not only satisfies the requirement for customization but also provides robust querying capabilities comparable to SQL. Fig. 2 shows an exemplary utilization of MongoDB as a robust and flexible data storage solution. In summary, NoSQL provides innovative solutions for storing and managing large-scale data in the context of data. Among them, MongoDB database offers advanced technical capabilities for storing and managing heterogeneous carbon data from multiple sources in the context of integrating various elements in Chongming District. It is known for its scalable distributed architecture, flexible data storage model, and high-performance real-time querying and updating functionalities. Based on the data storage and management approach of MongoDB, it effectively supports the storage, querying, and real-time updating of carbon neutrality data in Chongming District. Together with “Space-Sky-Ground” integrated monitoring and web crawling, it forms a complementary system. This system provides ample data resources and robust data management methods. It serves as an innovative foundation and vital support for the application of artificial intelligence technology in unveiling the nexus of diverse factors. Furthermore, it enables in-depth analysis to evaluate the carbon neutrality status in Chongming District. 3 Exploring the potential of artificial intelligence technology: Evaluating carbon neutrality status and exploring low-carbon transition pathways 3.1 Limitations of traditional carbon evaluation methods In the context of global climate change, low-carbon emissions have become a well-established topic worldwide. Since the last century, international organizations and institutions such as the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) have been actively engaged in research on greenhouse gas emissions inventories Their efforts have aimed to facilitate carbon control and optimize carbon strategies worldwide in response to the challenges of climate change (IPCC, 1996; IPCC, 2006; ISO, 2018). Consequently, numerous subsequent studies have revolved around the theme of low-carbon emissions reduction.Lu et al. (Lu et al., 2011) developed a low-carbon evaluation framework for the implementation of low-carbon urban development in Tianjin, based on the city's carbon emission mechanism and key influencing factors, combined with expert consultations. They established a statistical table of weights for the low-carbon planning index system and an evaluation table for the current status and planning of low-carbon indicators, providing a basis for low-carbon evaluation in Tianjin. However, this low-carbon evaluation method has limited indicators and a relatively crude model, making it difficult to uncover the connections among different influencing factors and form an integrated evaluation system that incorporates multiple factors. Additionally, the involvement of experts is required in this evaluation system, which hinders the efficient establishment of a carbon evaluation system involving multiple factors, especially in the context of big data. Nosheen et al. (Nosheen et al., 2020) used the extended STIRPAT model to assess the energy consumption and urbanization of Asian countries on carbon dioxide emissions and environmental quality, and verified the feasibility of the method. Although statistical models such as STIRPAT provide a scientific basis for understanding and predicting carbon emissions and environmental quality, such statistical models mainly rely on predetermined influencing factors and linear relationship assumptions, which may make it difficult to capture the underlying complex nonlinear nexus of different factors (Vélez-Henao et al., 2019). Similarly, when utilizing remote sensing data for environmental parameter monitoring and analysis, the process of establishing physical models heavily relies on prior knowledge (Yuan et al., 2020), which introduces a high level of complexity. Previous research has made certain achievements in the evaluation of carbon emissions and environmental conditions. However, these methods still have certain limitations. when faced with large-scale, multidimensional and heterogeneous data from various sources, these methods and models exhibit low processing efficiency and struggle to capture the complex nexus and nonlinear patterns inherent in the data. Additionally, they require different domain expertise and experience for modeling in different application scenarios, lacking a unified and easily understandable modeling framework. Therefore, it is crucial to explore an approach that can capture and establish the hidden correlations among various factors such as social, economic, ecological, and geographical aspects. This approach should enable the comprehensive extraction of data value and accelerate the low-carbon transformation of Chongming District, leading to the successful achievement of decarbonization goal in a high-quality manner. 3.2 The application potential of artificial intelligence technology in evaluating carbon neutrality status In recent years, there have been remarkable breakthroughs in artificial intelligence technology. AI is not limited to a specific field but represents a revolutionary and transformative technology with the potential to empower various domains (Lyu y-g., 2020:). It has the capability to enhance and revolutionize every aspect of science and technology. At present, under the decarbonization goal of “3060″ decarbonization goal and ”Artificial Intelligence 2.0″, it is a natural and trendy choice to apply artificial intelligence technology to evaluating carbon neutrality status (Pan, 2016). Deep learning, as one of the most important branches of artificial intelligence technology, has surpassed human capabilities in various application domains and scenarios (Shrestha and Mahmood, 2019). Examples include AlphaGo (Granter et al., 2017) in the field of Go, ResNet (He et al., 2016) in image recognition, and Google's cancer detection models (Liu et al., 2017). Inspired by the success of deep learning in computer vision (Voulodimos et al., 2018), natural language processing (Young et al., 2018) and multimodal learning (Summaira et al., 2021), we believe that artificial intelligence technologies represented by deep learning models can facilitate the integration of diverse factors related to carbon neutrality in Chongming District. They can also uncover the underlying nexus and latent patterns that are difficult to predict based on prior knowledge. In the following discussion, we will focus on deep learning methods to explore and analyze the potential of AI technology in evaluating the carbon neutrality status in Chongming District. Fig. 3 shows a potential applications of AI technology in the evaluation of carbon neutrality status in Chongming District. 3.2.1 Deep learning models help to uncover the value of sensor data The “Space-Sky-Ground” integrated monitoring system provides abundant sensor data resources for evaluating the carbon neutrality status in Chongming, including satellite remote sensing images, UAV telemetry data, and ground-based sensor data. Currently, many researchers have carried out research on deep learning in processing remote sensing image data (Zhu et al., 2017). Zhang et al. (Zhang et al., 2019) used deep learning methods to effectively classify land cover and land use from high-resolution remote sensing images. Yuan et al. (Yuan et al., 2020) proposed that deep learning can be utilized to detect and simulate parameters in complex environments using remote sensing data, especially for those environmental phenomena that lack or are difficult to establish physical models. Similarly, deep learning techniques have also been applied to process UAV telemetry data. This includes the use of deep learning for processing UAV video imagery to identify and monitor human activities (Geraldes et al., 2019), as well as the development of an artificial intelligence system for disaster relief UAVs using semantic segmentation and task detection models (Speth et al., 2022). In addition, data fusion has been an important research area in the field of remote sensing (Zhu et al., 2017; Alparone et al., 2007; Schmitt and Zhu, 2016; Gómez-chova, et al., 2015). Currently, mainstream research focuses on two levels of fusion strategies: Feature-Level and Decision-Level. Feature-Level fusion involves merging different input data from various sources using a certain combination method and feeding them into deep neural networks for training, thereby extracting relevant features of interest. On the other hand, Decision-Level fusion combines the output of different models to obtain the final output (Zhu et al., 2017). Both of these strategies provide insights into fusing heterogeneous data from multiple sources and are of great reference value. Based on the above discussion, when evaluating the carbon neutrality status of Chongming District, we believe that the deep learning models provide a solution for mining the value of massive and heterogeneous sensor data. Due to the capability of deep learning models to automatically learn and extract various features from heterogeneous data sources, they can be utilized for processing satellite imagery and UAV telemetry data, as well as various ground-based sensor data. Considering the characteristics of sensor data, a feasible evaluation approach is as follows: Deep neural networks such as convolutional neural networks (Lecun et al., 2015) can be used to extract features related to the terrain conditions, land use, vegetation coverage, and water conditions in Chongming District from satellite remote sensing and UAV telemetry image. By using deep learning models like Transformer (Vaswani et al., 2017), specifically designed to handle time-series data, we can effectively analyze temperature and humidity variations across different time periods and regions, as well as evaluate atmospheric composition, including pollutant levels and carbon dioxide content. Furthermore, we can gain insights into human activities related to production, such as fertilizer management, wastewater discharge, and energy consumption. By this step, we are able to extract valuable features from diverse data. Ultimately, an encoder-decoder model such as Autoencoder (Tschannen et al., 2018) can be used to remove redundant information in high-dimensional feature data and acquire low-dimensional feature vectors that retain the main information. Through the above processing steps, it is possible to extract features from various data sources in Chongming District, including ecological environment and economic production. These features can then be used to capture and establish the nexus with data related to carbon emissions and carbon sequestration, which are crucial for evaluating the carbon neutrality status. 3.2.2 Large language model has the potential to extract the value of online data Web crawling offers a rich source of online data for evaluating the carbon neutrality status in Chongming District, encompassing data from government statistical yearbooks, corporate disclosure reports, and other relevant sources on the internet. These data exhibit characteristics such as wide-ranging sources, complex formats, low relevance, abstract and difficult-to-quantify content, making it challenging to directly employ deep learning models for processing and analysis. Recently, large language models represented by ChatGPT have made great progress and significantly improved the performance of many natural language processing tasks (Abdullah et al., 2022). Biswas et al. (Biswas, 2023) analyzed the potential contributions of ChatGPT in the research of global warming, providing support for the feasibility of using large language models in evaluating the carbon neutrality status of Chongming District. Therefore, we propose a method that utilizes large language models to extract the value of relevant online data. First of all, data such as government statistical yearbooks and corporate disclosure reports are usually presented in a structured format, and the application of large language models can help quickly identify and extract various information and indicators, and output them in a specified form. In addition, by inputting personalized prompt instructions based on specific needs (White et al., 2023), we can extract abstract information related to the decarbonization goals in Chongming, such as real-time emission reduction targets, mitigation actions, and public participation from various online platforms including government policy reports, news, and social media. This information can be condensed into concise textual outputs that retain the key information. Then, we are able to extract the desired content from the complex and diverse web data, thereby enhancing the efficiency and quality of data filtering and processing. Furthermore, for further analysis of these data, we can utilize deep learning models to extract features from the outputs of large language models. Specifically, numerical outputs can be processed using convolutional neural networks for feature extraction, while textual outputs can be handled using models like BERT (Devlin, et al., 2018) for text encoding and feature extraction. Through these operations, the heterogeneous and abstract web data from multiple sources are transformed into feature vectors that can be trained using deep learning methods. It is worth noting that large language models, such as ChatGPT, will sometimes provide false information (Tsigaris and Teixeira da silva, 2023:) and carry the risk of data leakage (Aiyappa et al., 2023). Therefore, it is important to carefully evaluate the generated results and avoid uploading sensitive and confidential data when using them. This is also why our proposed approach primarily focuses on publicly available data sources on the internet. 3.2.3 Enabling comprehensive evaluation of carbon neutrality through contrastive learning and graph neural networks The utilization of deep learning models and large language models enables the processing and exploration of sensor data and web data, providing a technological foundation for obtaining feature representations of diverse and heterogeneous data from various sources. However, it is important to consider that the mentioned deep learning models primarily rely on supervised learning methods, which require labeled signals, such as carbon emission data, to train the neural network and obtain feature representations. In the context of evaluating carbon neutrality status, the availability of such labeled signals is often limited or insufficient. This limitation diminishes the efficacy of supervised learning approaches in these cases. To address this limitation and mitigate the dependence on labeled data, the incorporation of unsupervised learning techniques becomes imperative. By introducing unsupervised learning methods, we can utilize the nexus within the data itself to extract informative representations. Graph neural networks (GNNs) are a type of deep learning model that operates on graph-structured data. By representing the three key elements of a graph, namely nodes, edges, and global context, as feature vectors and using deep learning methods, GNNs can effectively capture and model the features and relationships among nodes. This makes them applicable in various domains for analysis purpose (Zhou et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2019; Xv et al., 2020). The contrastive learning method, represented by MoCo (He et al., 2020), can be used to train models in the absence of labeled signals. By constructing positive and negative sample pairs, this method effectively brings similar samples closer together while encouraging dissimilar samples to be separated, facilitating meaningful feature representation learning. Drawing inspiration from successful applications of contrastive learning and graph neural networks (Yu et al., 2021; Xia et al., 2021; Cai et al., 2023), we propose a novel approach for comprehensively evaluating the carbon neutrality status in the Chongming District. Our approach combines the power of GNN and contrastive learning, and aims to overcome the challenges of training supervised learning models in scenarios with limited labels. When evaluating the carbon neutrality status of the Chongming District, we can construct “graphs” based on different application scenarios. These scenarios encompass both small-scale environments such as individual businesses and industrial parks, as well as large-scale settings including towns and villages. Additionally, to address the issue of insufficient data and missing data in different application scenarios, we can introduce some prior knowledge as constraints and convert the problem into an edge-level prediction task, thereby reducing the reliance on data volume and integrity (You et al., 2020; Borate et al., 2023). Below, we will present a general evaluation framework applicable to different scenarios, using enterprise applications as an example: Firstly, the data from different enterprises will be categorized and summarized based on a yearly or other time interval. For example, it can be divided into the following categories: • Enterprise business information such as enterprise size, industry classification, products produced, and geographical location. • Enterprise production process information including production parameters, material information, equipment details, and energy consumption information. • Enterprise emission information covering wastewater discharge, waste disposal, and various types of gas emissions. Each type of data and the relationships between them have a learnable latent representation vector. Using these representation vectors, we construct a set of graph data. These graph data are combined based on different time intervals and enterprises, forming a large-scale graph dataset for model training. Specifically, we can first create graph data for different time points of the same enterprise, treating them as positive samples. Then, we consider graph data from different enterprises and time points as negative samples. By using contrastive learning methods, our model learns to effectively capture the distinctive features of elements within the same enterprise and establish feature disparities across different enterprises. Additionally, to enhance the training, we can introduce a limited amount of graph data that contains carbon emission-related information. This data can include known carbon emission levels from specific years or data from enterprises that disclose their carbon emissions. By integrating such data, we introduce a novel framework that synergistically combines self-supervised and semi-supervised methods (Zhu et al., 2020; Sun et al., 2019), leading to the expected performance improvement. Furthermore, through training process, we can acquire feature representations that encompass fundamental information, production patterns, and carbon emission patterns of different enterprises. These representations unveil the nexus among these various elements, allowing us to establish meaningful correlation between them and carbon emission patterns. Ultimately, a comprehensive multi-factor evaluation framework for evaluating the carbon neutrality status of enterprises can be established. 3.3 Exploring low-carbon transition pathways with the assistance of artificial intelligence technology The application of artificial intelligence technology in evaluating carbon neutrality status enables us to facilitate the coupling of various factors inherent in multi-source and heterogeneous data and establish their nexus to carbon neutrality. Many of these nexuses are challenging to model using traditional approaches or discover and interpret through prior knowledge. However, artificial intelligence technology provides a solution to capture and establish these nexuses, thereby assisting professionals from diverse domains in exploring low-carbon transition pathways. Specifically, the inherent connections among these elements offer researchers fresh inspiration and valuable insights. They serve as a complement to the existing knowledge in the field of carbon evaluation and provide a foundation for exploring novel research avenues. By comprehensively considering the factors involved across diverse data sources, researchers can delve into the intricate connections and underlying mechanisms that related to carbon neutrality status evaluation. This exploration will unravel the influential factors, key drivers, and limiting constraints, shedding light on the complex dynamics that underlie low-carbon transformation. Meanwhile these emerging research directions can foster increased scholarly exchanges and collaborative efforts. By harnessing the power of artificial intelligence techniques to analyze diverse data, interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary research and collaborations can be pursued. This enables a profound exploration of the interconnections and interactions between carbon neutrality and various academic disciplines, including society, economy, ecology, geography, and more. Furthermore, stakeholders including governments, businesses, and social organizations committed to the decarbonization goal can use models developed by artificial intelligence techniques for carbon emission trend forecasting, production demand forecasting, low-carbon technology prediction, policy impact assessment, and social engagement evaluation. This big data-driven artificial intelligence technology framework will be applied and verified in the practice of low carbon transition in Chongming District based on the project “Research on Intelligent Monitoring, Evaluation and Response Technology for Carbon Neutrality Status in Chongming District”. For example, the carbon emissions of a region or an enterprise predicted by the artificial intelligence model will be compared and verified with the results projected by the carbon evaluation experts using the corresponding professional methods, and the artificial intelligence model will be further verified and optimized based on the subsequent measured data and the professional opinions of the experts. In addition, potential nexus between elements captured by the AI model will be verified and analyzed by experts in different fields through research and experiments. The newly discovered elements and relationships that are verified to be informative and valuable will be treated as important considerations for subsequent carbon monitoring, evaluation and response. In summary, the application of artificial intelligence technology fosters the establishment of a more comprehensive and inclusive carbon neutrality evaluation framework. It empowers decision-makers and participants from diverse stakeholders by providing precise data and robust model support, enabling them to explore low-carbon transition pathways with greater precision. The feasibility and performance of AI models will be further verified and improved by cross-validating with expert research results in actual practices. This, in turn, guides the formulation of effective low-carbon policies and the implementation of impactful carbon reduction initiatives. Ultimately, it serves as a driving force towards the achievement of the decarbonization goal. 4 Conclusion This paper addresses the challenges and obstacles faced by Chongming District in evaluating the carbon neutrality status and promoting low-carbon transition. To tackle these issues, we propose a solution based on next-generation information technologies, with big data and artificial intelligence at the forefront. Our approach involves the creation of a comprehensive data acquisition framework that combines web scraping and “Space-Sky-Ground” integrated monitoring system. Additionally, we explore the potential applications of artificial intelligence techniques, including deep neural networks, large language models, graph neural networks and contrastive learning, to handle various data patterns effectively. By implementing these strategies, we can effectively acquire diverse and heterogeneous data sources, enabling us to capture the nexuses between different elements and establish meaningful connections among them. This integration of carbon neutrality and its associated elements fosters a more comprehensive evaluation framework in Chongming District, promoting a holistic understanding of the carbon neutrality status. Hopefully, our innovative approach will provide valuable insights for establishing Chongming District as a carbon–neutral demonstration zone and achieving the committed “30-60” decarbonization goal. Abstract Artificial Intelligence is increasingly being discussed as something essential and pressing in all aspects and areas of society. Its potential use in education is no exception. Artificial Intelligence, in particular, and technologies, in general, are unavoidable elements to be considered in the teaching-learning process at all levels of education and training. There are many initiatives, essentially exploratory in nature, for the application of Artificial Intelligence in this process. Therefore, it is imperative to understand how they can be used for this purpose and how they relate to pedagogical methods. In the present study, and within this context, we address how Artificial Intelligence can be used in software to support cognitive and motor development and stimulate reasoning. We propose a reference model for techniques for this purpose. Concrete cases of existing applications are presented to better illustrate the potential of Artificial Intelligence in education. 2021 The uthors. E-mail address: vsantos@novaims.unl.pt 1058 Vitor Santos et al. / Procedia Computer Science 219 (2023) 1057â€“10662 Vitor Santos et al. / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2021) 000â€“000 1. Introduction Artificial Intelligence (AI) based technologies for teaching are spreading and being used more and more because of their advantages. [2,16,33]. The establishment of the Beijing Consensus [29], which is the first AI and education document adopted by UNESCO member states, has brought to the attention of education leaders and policymakers worldwide the recognition of the urgency to discuss and define the future of education. As a result, AI in Education (AIED) - the intersection of the AI and education domains - has become a strategic priority in many countries [30]. However, there are barriers to its effective and widespread use. For example, Wang and Cheng (2021) identify barriers in secondary schools in Hong Kong, findings that can be generalized in the sense that they are not culturally dependent. If we look at the actual situation in most of the various schools and training centers spread throughout Portugal, we see that its use is not yet as widespread as one would expect. In this paper, we refer, in particular, to what concerns the use of Artificial Intelligence techniques to support the cognitive and motor development of children and adolescents and stimulate their reasoning. There are different strategies for building Artificial Intelligence, and it is possible to use each one or a combination of them to address different specific problems. In solving some types of problems, only a few strategies are possible. In other problems, there are several alternative paths. Artificial Intelligence is a vast area of computer science composed of different specialty subfields. These domains include Automatic programming, Planning; Learning; Reasoning; Natural language; Problem-solving, Search, Genetics and Evolution, Knowledge representation, Vision, Simulation and social modeling, Speech, Affective computation, Demonstration of theorems; Artificial life, among others. Regardless of the area or subarea, it is possible to identify three base approaches for building intelligent systems: the computational or symbolic, the connectionist, and the biological [9]. The Symbolic or Computational approach is based on a computational metaphor, in which intelligence is defined by the sum of processes that simulate reasoning and computational structures. In the so-called connectionist approach, intelligence is considered an emergent property of the interactions of a large number of elementary processing units, usually neurons or artificial lymphocytes, that simplistically replicate the functioning of their biological counterparts. The biological approach is based on the computer simulation of Darwin's theory of natural selection of species. The "intelligence" emerges from the evolution and learning of a species of artificial individuals in each context. Physical and motor development can be understood as the development of a child's or adolescent's motor skills. In children, everything referring to the act of crawling, walking, running, grasping objects, sucking, eating, drinking, etc. In adolescents, it is the biological part of the body that transforms throughout life [11]. Regarding cognitive development, in the context of this text, we refer essentially to Jean Piaget's theory of cognition development [18], i.e., the set of brain/mental capacities necessary to obtain knowledge about the world that involves thinking, reasoning, abstraction, language, memory, attention, creativity, and problem-solving skills, among other functions. Activities that stimulate reasoning are understood as all activities that directly or indirectly encourage and promote the development of reasoning [25]. Good examples are games (chess, checkers, go, ...), hobbies (crossword puzzles, sudoku, ...), puzzles (Cluedo, ...), curiosities (history, science, ...), and challenges (competitions, self-overcoming, ...). We seek to answer whether technologies based on Artificial Intelligence can help in physical and motor development and stimulate reasoning. It is known that, with respect to physical and motor development, they have an enormous potential to complement the work of a teacher/tutor, for example, obtained by participating in games that require increasing motor coordination, agility, and speed. Regarding the stimulus to reasoning, for example, by making games more "intelligent," hobbies and puzzles more dynamic and challenging, they contribute relevantly to the learner's facing increasing difficulties and thus receiving an evolving stimulus adjusted to the learner's evolution [3]. This paper presents a proposed reference model for using AI techniques to stimulate reasoning and cognitive and motor development. We better illustrate the potential of AI in education by presenting some cases in which, using the application of Artificial Intelligence in well-known contexts, platforms are obtained that enhance physical and motor development. Methodology We used the Design Science Research (DSR) methodology for this work. DSR is an approach with growing relevance in information systems research based on the construction of an artifact (in this case, a reference model) that aims to ensure answers to the questions posed by the study problem [19]. Since we intend to design and implement an artifact, we consider this to be the most appropriate methodology for its elaboration, implementation, and critical analysis of the results. The artifact is the central element of the Design Science Research (DSR) and must be well tested, understood and documented to ensure its pragmatic validity. The evaluation is a central phase of the process, in which the usefulness, quality and effectiveness of the artifact are demonstrated, using well-executed evaluation methods. The sequence of steps provided in the methodology is illustrated in Fig. 1. Fig. 1. DSR sequential activities [19]. In the form of a reference model, the artifact to be proposed will be materialized by the collection and analysis of AI application cases in stimulating reasoning and cognitive and motor development. After this phase, we will validate it through interviews with experts. With this collected data, we will process it, incorporate the identified improvements, and conclude. 3. Artificial Intelligence technologies in teaching It is always tricky to predict the future. However, it is possible that technologies currently in use will see their use expanded and that technologies of growing importance, such as Artificial Intelligence and Virtual Reality, will be progressively integrated into schools. There are countless cases of Artificial Intelligence being applied to support teaching and education, allowing teachers novel ways of teaching-learning and increasing the efficiency of the whole process [28]. The Internet has enabled a large proportion of children to access quality teaching platforms and content. These collaborative platforms and teaching aid applications allow access to school material and communication; and support knowledge sharing between school institutions in all areas and different languages [8]. They can be used on all computer operating systems, mobile devices, and the Internet [4]. An example of context for the use of AI techniques is known as MOOC (Massive Open Online Courses). This system allows several students to have access to numerous courses, making it possible, for example, for a teenage boy from Bangladesh to attend a digital circuits course remotely and learn other subjects that do not exist in schools in his/her country. Another technology related to mobile devices is E-books (electronic books). All material is available 24 hours a day, there is a text search functionality, and the portability of texts is an advantage [6]. Furthermore, the availability of specialized periodicals and scientific and literary texts, libraries, music, films online, despite the controversy related to copyright and intellectual property and the consequent impact and challenges posed to the sustainability of markets, will definitely contribute to broadening and disseminating knowledge [23]. Besides the existence of virtual libraries, museums, and countless sites for sharing music, videos, films, or series, there are multiple thematic sites and ad hoc offers focused on authors, geographies, and even works. Artificial Intelligence will increasingly have a decisive say. Noteworthy are automatic translation systems, which are already fundamental in breaking down language barriers, the support systems for the development and stimulation of reasoning in children and teenagers (intelligent tutors, games, ...), and the support systems for motor development. In this last case, a good example is the Nintendo Wii, which through movement sensors, helps improve the motor 1060 Vitor Santos et al. / Procedia Computer Science 219 (2023) 1057â€“10664 Vitor Santos et al. / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2021) 000â€“000 activities of students, namely those with Autism and Down Syndrome. Another instance is the game Wii Fit, which can help individuals with difficulties in movement and balance through a platform because it offers instant feedback on the movements performed on the platform. In addition, technologies for automatic translation from sign language to spoken language and from spoken language to sign language will remove traditional accessibility barriers for mute and/or deaf students. 4. Artificial Intelligence use cases in teaching 4.1 Physical and motor development There are many examples of the use of AI, in association with other types of technologies, to support physical and motor development. It is easy to find illustrative cases in the education of children and young people, in sports, and the support of people with special needs, from dexterity support (fine motor skills), to training and preparation of high competition athletes or intelligent software with self-adaptation of interfaces for special users [21,22]. Usually, AI techniques appear together with other important technologies. In particular with the so-called Virtual Reality and IoT (Internet of Things) technologies [7, 27]. The first is a rapidly expanding and already relatively advanced technology that allows the simulation of real-life or fictitious environments. It has already been consolidated in applications in several areas, such as education, health, and entertainment. There are several types of Virtual environments: The "fully immersive" ones where everything is virtual objects; the "Augmented Reality" ones where immersion in the real world is affected by the addition of virtual elements; and the "non-immersive" ones where the virtual environments are seen through windows (the screens). The second, IoT, constitutes a set of emerging technologies that can be defined as a network connecting various technologies through the Internet and allowing communication and the exchange of information between different devices and systems. With the spread of Artificial Intelligence techniques, the progressive introduction of IoT-based intelligent systems can be expected [14]. However, it cannot be said that the education sector is at the forefront of adopting smart IoT technologies. A school that uses smart devices promotes a more advanced level of personalized learning [20]. These devices that use Wi-Fi to receive instructions and send data can help students utilize key school resources, create more innovative lesson plans, secure campuses, and improve access to information. Several examples and application cases can be considered. One example is wearable technology on students in a school that automatically counts students as being present, late (they are on school premises but not in their class), or absent (they are not on school premises) when the bell rings. With that information, the system will determine the information for the parents and provide links to the elements of the subject matter that the student missed. These same wearable devices can also help determine when the class is too tired or becomes inattentive and in need of a break, and the smart boards will record all the notes taken in a class. The inclusion of smart microphones in this solution will even allow it to recognize when a teacher mentions that there is a homework assignment due and update the students' calendars accordingly. An excellent example of using IoT to support students' physical and motor development is the use of performance monitoring sensors in physical education (see example in Fig. 2). These sensors collect data that can be analyzed by AI systems and teachers and be translated into adaptive practices, such as changing the pace of practice and training for better energy management and increased performance. These types of applications can also be considered game-changers, as they provide a large number of educational games that provide exciting features and possibilities in teaching and learning and thereby aid cognitive development. 4.2 Reasoning stimulus Also, with regard to stimulating reasoning, there are multiple examples of the use of Artificial Intelligence, either, for example, by applying 3D systems or by applying natural language processing [10,13]. Next, we analyze three relevant cases that we consider significant insofar as they allow the use of AI in stimulating reasoning. Chess In recent years, technological advances have made it possible to investigate better which factors are related between chess and human cognitive abilities. The first to study and relate chess with human intelligence was the French psychologist Alfred Binet, who is considered the father of intelligence tests. In 1894, he conducted studies where he asked chess players to describe how they reasoned during a chess match [5]. Play helps develop skills considered relevant to cognitive development. These skills include logical thinking, concentration, strategy, patience, memory, mental and physical control, and the perspective of future scenarios, which are useful for decision making. Artificial Intelligence techniques in chess games date to the 60s/70s. Even then, using techniques from Game Theory and "Alpha-Beta pruning" search tricks, computers managed to rank among the top 100 in the world at the tournament level. In 1982 the Belle Chess Computer, which included special circuits for motion generation and evaluation, achieved a score of 2250, with beginners having about 1000 and the world champion at 2750. In 1987 Hitech System's system, capable of evaluating 10 million positions per move, defeated the world champion. In 1990 Deep Thought 2, with a capacity to evaluate 500 million positions per move, was among the top 100 globally. In 1995 Deep Blue (1024 specialized parallel chips) could analyze one billion positions per second. Today, an advanced Artificial Intelligence system, such as Google's Alpha Go Zero, can learn and master the game of chess in 24 hours to the point of defeating world champions [12,32]. Cluedo Cluedo (also known as Clue) is a mystery game for three to six players created by Anthony E. Pratt of Birmingham, England. The game was first manufactured in 1949 in the United Kingdom. The game's objective is to determine who murdered the game's victim (Dr. Black), the location of the crime, and what weapon was used. Each player assumes the role of one of the six suspects and tries to deduce the correct answer by strategically moving around a game board representing the rooms of a mansion (see Fig. 3) and collecting clues about the circumstances of the murder from the other players. It is possible to establish deductive reasoning starting from the clues, which can be reproduced by an AI system, leading to discovering the culprit. The material from which artificial life is produced is inorganic, and its essence is information. Computers are test tubes in which new organisms are produced [24]. When the primary purpose of a game is to teach/train, the players should have increasing challenges that allow them to evolve. So it is expected that when they mature in their way of playing, their "opponent" will do the same. On the other hand, each player has a different "game strategy," meaning that the "opponent" must follow a different strategy for each case. For this purpose, Artificial Life techniques can be a good idea [15,26]. Let us imagine, for example, an aim training game where it is intended that the player, by trying to shoot a given type of duck (e.g.,), can improve his intelligence, strength, and agility via the game (see Fig. 4). Reference Model for using Artificial Intelligence techniques to stimulate reasoning and cognitive and motor development Based on the literature review and the cases described, it was possible to ascertain two critical elements. One is to realize the multiplicity and dispersion of techniques and areas, and the other is the lack of aggregation and the usefulness of having a reference model for the use of AI techniques in the teaching context. With the analysis of the cases, elements were possible to build a reference model for this purpose. This circumstance highlights the need for a reference model, as shown in Table 1. Table 1. Q6 - Maybe it is better to use other matrices as a basis and adapt them. Perhaps give examples of tools that fit each case. An analysis of the answers obtained determines that the proposed reference model is pertinent, although it needs to be developed further in some particular situations. We, therefore, understand the need to provide more detail, particularly explanatory, about it. It is also verified that the reference model is useful and unanimously recognized. Regarding completeness, there is flexibility to include other tools, and it is indicated that there is room for development in this area for future work. At the same time, the reference model is simple to use, although it includes some terms with which not all potential reference model users will be familiar. Thus, several suggestions for improvement were made, and ways of introducing them into the proposed reference model were indicated. 7. Conclusions As Niemi (2021) mentioned, AI has the ability to change the landscape of learning while recognizing the need to specify the application scenarios of AI in education further, particularly in stimulating reasoning and cognitive and motor development [17]. Vitor Santos et al. / Procedia Computer Science 219 (2023) 1057â€“1066 1065 Vitor Santos et al. / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 9 This paper sought to discuss how Artificial Intelligence can be used in systems to support cognitive and motor development, stimulate reasoning and suggest concrete ways to implement these strategies. Tangible examples were presented in which the application of Artificial Intelligence promotes physical and motor development and stimulates reasoning. Based on the study and rigorous analysis of these examples, a proposal for a reference model for the use of Artificial Intelligence techniques in stimulating reasoning and cognitive and motor development was presented. Although there is still a long way to go, it is already clear today that Artificial Intelligence can play a vital role in systems that support cognitive and motor development and stimulate reasoning. However, we realize that the link between pedagogy and technology is often absent from the debate about AI-driven teaching tools. It is, therefore, possible to foresee that, in the future, this role may become more relevant and that new forms and even more ambitious projects will be born. Regarding future work, we can mention two distinct areas. On the one hand, the application of the proposed reference model and the observation of the results obtained through this application. On the other hand, throughout the texts we used as references for this work, we can see, either implicitly or explicitly, that there is a growing popular belief that AI will one day surpass human intelligence. Although it is not part of this work's objectives, we believe it is pertinent to mention the importance of examining whether this common belief translates into negative psychological and behavioral consequences when individuals evaluate that AI performs better than them in cognitive and intellectual tasks. This effort would be to continue the existing clues in the work of [31]. References [1] Aartun, V. I. (2016). Education Still Needs Arti PROCS 44499 S1877-0509(23)00393-9 10.1016/j.procs.2023.01.384 A Reference Model for Artificial Intelligence Techniques in Stimulating Reasoning, and Cognitive and Motor Development Vitor Santos a Henrique Mamede b Clara Silveira c Leonilde Reis d a NOVAIMS da Universidade Nova de Lisboa, Portugal NOVAIMS da Universidade Nova de Lisboa Portugal b INESC TEC, Departamento de Ciências e Tecnologia, Universidade Aberta, Lisboa, Portugal INESC TEC Departamento de Ciências e Tecnologia Universidade Aberta Lisboa Portugal c Escola Superior de Tecnologia e Gestão, Instituto Politécnico da Guarda, Guarda, Portugal Escola Superior de Tecnologia e Gestão Instituto Politécnico da Guarda Guarda Portugal d Escola Superior de Ciências Empresariais, Instituto Politécnico de Setúbal, Setúbal, Portugal Escola Superior de Ciências Empresariais Instituto Politécnico de Setúbal Setúbal Portugal Artificial Intelligence is increasingly being discussed as something essential and pressing in all aspects and areas of society. Its potential use in education is no exception. Artificial Intelligence, in particular, and technologies, in general, are unavoidable elements to be considered in the teaching-learning process at all levels of education and training. There are many initiatives, essentially exploratory in nature, for the application of Artificial Intelligence in this process. Therefore, it is imperative to understand how they can be used for this purpose and how they relate to pedagogical methods. In the present study, and within this context, we address how Artificial Intelligence can be used in software to support cognitive and motor development and stimulate reasoning. We propose a reference model for techniques for this purpose. Concrete cases of existing applications are presented to better illustrate the potential of Artificial Intelligence in education. Komandorska 118-120, 53-345 Wroclaw, Poland Abstract Undoubtedly, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is going mainstream. More and more AI agents come into existence to augment human agents in their work by synthesizing a gigantic body of knowledge in a conversational interface (e.g., ChatGPT), generating art from a provided description (e.g., Stable Diffusion), creating software code based on a provided description (e.g., Codex), just to name a few. It becomes evident that at some point an AI agent will similarly help human managers in their daily operations, and, when it reaches the level of artificial general intelligence (AGI), unlock completely new levels of performance and sustainability. The authors used the critical review method and identified a research gap concerning the development of a generalized, numerical model of an organization and its environment that could be applied in machine learning pipelines, and effectively support managers in the key management functions.
