Introduction The rapid advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AI) has enabled organizations to leverage its capabilities in various aspects of management. The integration of AI techniques into management functions has already shown significant potential to make managerial functions more efficient and effective in areas of, among others, decision- making [1], demand forecasting [2], workforce scheduling [3], social network analysis [4], employee attrition analysis [5], production process optimization [6], and anomaly detection [7]. * Corresponding author. E-mail address: piotr.sliwa@ue.wroc.pl 4796 Piotr Åšliwa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4795â€“48042 Piotr Åšliwa, Grzegorz Krzos / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 Management that utilizes AI presents a great potential for sustainability as it can directly and indirectly affect three areas: environment, economy, and satisfaction of current and future generationsâ€™ needs. The main task of the AI-based methods applied to managerial functions is to optimize their processes which are abundant in enterprises [8]. Generally, AI algorithms are believed to make certain predictions more accurately than human agents. For example, improved predictions of consumer behavior and demand for manufactured products can enable companies to produce just as much as the market needs instead of creating surplus (stock) products stored in warehouses. Such an application of AI optimizes the use of environmental resources and costs [9]. Another example of using AI in sustainable management is the optimization of purchasing green energy from its producers in terms of dynamically changing demand for green energy in the enterprise. AI algorithms can efficiently analyze the price and amount of energy consumed and stored versus market price to optimize energy self-sufficiency and, therefore, reduce the environmental and carbon footprint of the company's activities [10]. It appears that opportunities for enhancing sustainability are embedded within various managerial processes in organizations. Despite the growing utilization of AI in management functions, they were by far mostly approached with specific, tailor-made AI models for isolated problems they were built to address. However, there is a rapidly growing interest in development of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) - highly capable AI with broad knowledge that can rival or even surpass human agents in previously-human-only tasks, including management of organizations [11]. Even such an advanced synthetic agent is expected to be a part of the digital world (as opposed to the â€œrealâ€� world humans and organizations live in) so, in the spirit of the â€œgarbage-in garbage-outâ€� notion rooted in data science [12], it will be necessary to provide the digital agent with equally accurate, valid, and complete digital data - a digital representation of the real organization, its environment, and phenomena occurring within them. This paper draws inspiration from the recent success of large language models, such as GPT, LLaMA, or BERT, which have demonstrated the potential of Machine Learning (ML) algorithms (a subset of AI algorithms) to synthesize vast amounts of information and provide a user with easy access to the knowledge via a conversational interface. Notably, the large language models derived their success from the abundance of digitalized knowledge that they could be trained with [13]. A similar approach, utilizing mathematical models of an organization and its environment along with ML algorithms, could allow a user to grasp phenomena occurring in the organization and its environment. Yet, it is important to note that data required by managerial functions, e.g., soft skills, emotional intelligence, or implicit knowledge, cannot always be effectively expressed with words, and requires more abstract digital representation. Consequently, there is a growing need for identification of mathematical models that can provide a holistic representation of an organization, encompassing both its internal structure and its interactions with the environment, which can be then used as foundations for a generalized ML model. The aim of this paper is to identify the link between the key management functions and the theory of ML modeling that could lead to automation of the key management functions. To achieve this, the authors critically reviewed a body of literature of the three themes, found in the Scopus and Web of Science databases, augmented with Google Scholar searches (limited to highly cited articles): â€¢ management functions, â€¢ business applications of machine learning, and â€¢ organization and its environment in organizational studies. 2. Management functions The purpose of this chapter is to provide a review of the existing management literature on the functions of management in organizations that could be addressed with ML. The chapter examines the key management functions and highlights the relevance of these functions in contemporary organizations. The review of the literature is organized into the following sections: planning, organizing, leading, and controlling [14], and summarized in Figure 1. Piotr Åšliwa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4795â€“4804 4797 Piotr Åšliwa, Grzegorz Krzos / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 3 Figure 1. Functions of a manager. Source: Own elaboration based on [14]. 2.1. Planning Planning is the process of setting goals and determining the best way to achieve those goals [14]. Drucker emphasized that planning is a vital function of management as it sets the direction for the organization and aligns its activities with its objectives. Mintzberg [15] challenged the conventional notion of planning as a linear, top-down process and proposed that planning should be a continuous, learning-oriented activity. In the context of planning as described by Drucker and Mintzberg, the ability to forecast future events is crucial. The process of setting goals, devising strategies to achieve them, and allocating resources all require a level of foresight about potential future outcomes. They bring an anticipatory dimension to the planning process, emphasizing the need to make informed predictions about future conditions. Furthermore, Mintzberg's notion of planning as a continuous, learning-oriented activity necessitates an ongoing assessment of future scenarios to adjust plans and actions in a dynamic manner. 2.2. Organizing Organizing involves defining and grouping tasks, assigning authority and responsibilities, and allocating resources to achieve organizational goals [14]. Organizing is essential for establishing a clear organizational structure that facilitates coordination and communication between different departments and units. Galbraith [16] introduced the concept of organizational design, emphasizing the importance of creating structures that enable organizations to adapt to their environments. With his notion that the optimal structure is one that best facilitates environmental adaptability, organizing can be conceptualized as an optimization problem of an efficient assignment of tasks, delegation of authority, and allocation of resources within certain constraints. 2.3. Leading Leading entails influencing and directing actions of organizational members to achieve the goals [14]. The literature on leadership is vast and encompasses a wide array of perspectives, including trait theories [17], behavioral theories [18], contingency theories [19], and transformational leadership theories [20]. One of the most significant contributions to leadership literature is Burns' [21] distinction between transactional and transformational leadership. Transactional leaders focus on maintaining the status quo by rewarding or punishing employees based on their performance, while transformational leaders inspire and motivate employees to exceed their potential and achieve higher levels of performance. Especially in the latter case, leadership is a complex 4798 Piotr Åšliwa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4795â€“48044 Piotr Åšliwa, Grzegorz Krzos / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 process that extends beyond hierarchical models and relies heavily on human interactions. It is seen as a dynamic process that emerges from interactions, not just a trait inherent to certain individuals. This viewpoint underscores the complexity and sophistication of leadership, highlighting that it operates as an adaptive, collaborative system, and hence necessitates an equally dynamic and multifaceted approach to modelling [22]. 2.4. Controlling The term "control" is often defined as the process by which managers ensure that resources are obtained and used effectively and efficiently in the accomplishment of the organization's objectives [23]. Controlling involves monitoring of organizational performance, comparing actual results with planned outcomes, and taking corrective action if necessary [14]. Drucker highlighted the importance of control systems in providing managers with feedback on the organization's progress toward its goals. Kaplan and Norton [24] introduced the Balanced Scorecard, a widely adopted performance management tool that measures organizational performance across multiple dimensions, such as financial, customer, internal processes, and learning and growth. In addition to the Balanced Scorecard, there exists an abundance of other tools that aid in performance management. For instance, Key Performance Indicators [25] provide a general framework with quantifiable measurements that reflect the performance level of an organization in achieving its objectives. Total Quality Management [26] is a management approach to long-term success through customer satisfaction. The Economic Value Added [27] metric, on the other hand, offers a perspective on financial performance by determining the company's economic profit. In this context, controlling can be seen as a structured, to some extent â€œmechanicalâ€� process. 3. ML applications and problem formulation In recent years, the application of machine learning (ML) techniques to address a wide range of specific, managerial tasks has increased significantly. Several studies have demonstrated the power of ML algorithms in various domains, including but not limited to finance [28], marketing [29], and human resources [30]. This chapter aims to review some of these cases and outline the importance of formulating a problem in numerical form, specifically as vectors, in order to solve it with machine learning. In finance, machine learning has been applied to tasks such as credit scoring, fraud detection, and portfolio optimization. One notable example is the study by Kraus and Feuerriegel [28], which explored the application of ML algorithms for predicting stock prices. The authors used various ML techniques, such as random forests, support vector machines, and deep learning, to forecast the stock prices of various companies. They transformed the problem into a numerical form by representing the stock prices as vectors and using historical price data as input features. The study demonstrated that ML algorithms can significantly outperform traditional time-series models in predicting stock prices. In marketing, ML techniques have been employed to improve customer segmentation, predict customer churn, and optimize advertising campaigns. A study by Ngai et al. [29] investigated the use of ML algorithms for customer relationship management. The authors identified several key data mining methods used in customer relationship management which represented the problem in numerical form (e.g., as vectors): neural networks, decision trees, logistic regression, clustering, association rules, self-organizing maps, and genetic algorithms. These techniques were employed to analyze customer data and predict their behavior in order to develop a competitive CRM strategy that acquired and retained potential customers while maximizing customer value. In the realm of human resources, ML has been used for employee selection, retention, and performance prediction. Chien and Chen [30] applied ML algorithms to predict employee turnover based on pre-hire assessments. The authors represented the problem in numerical form by analyzing human resource data using a data mining framework, which employed decision tree algorithms to extract rules between applicants' profiles and their work Piotr Åšliwa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4795â€“4804 4799 Piotr Åšliwa, Grzegorz Krzos / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 5 behaviors. Their results indicated that ML algorithms could effectively predict employee turnover and offered better accuracy compared to traditional linear models. ML excels in uncovering complex patterns, relationships, and trends that may not be apparent with traditional methods, even when their amount is excessive. However, as discernable in the aforementioned studies, the common theme is the importance of formulating a problem in numerical form, specifically as tensors (a generalized form of mathematical vectors and matrices), to effectively apply ML techniques. This involves converting the domain model (along with both input and output data) into a series of features represented by numbers. 4. ML and management functions in an organization The review of literature on the management functions revealed that the realm of organizational management is fraught with intricate, multidimensional, and intertwined issues. These complexities span across the different functions, from planning to organizing, leading, and controlling, each requiring its unique blend of decision-making, people management, and resource allocation. Despite this overwhelming intricacy, a consistent pattern seems to emerge: these management functions can be viewed as processes - sequences of tasks carried out by a manager. In this context, in which both the organization with its environment and the tasks of management functions are transformed into sequences of numerical tensors (as the input and output of an ML model, respectively), the sequence-to-sequence models [31] (and autoregressive models in particular) present a powerful opportunity. These models, known for their ability to make predictions based on past data, can be pivotal in predicting future trends, behaviors or events. Temporal dependence is a natural part of most managerial scenarios, in which the managerial agent needs to predict future events based on the past ones - like sales forecasting, inventory management, or understanding customer as well as employee behavior, among others. Notably, it is directly accounted for by autoregressive models which can naturally translate to these managerial scenarios and could potentially predict a sequence of future events (including the managerâ€™s tasks) based on a sequence of past or alternative events (in the case of a simulation of different scenarios). In the case of autoregressive models (and sequence-to-sequence models in general), the whole domain model (input and output data) must be transformed into time-series data. This involves restructuring the data into a sequential order of instances, with each instance capturing the state of the system at a specific point in time as depicted in Figure 2. Figure 2. The transformation of a domain model (1) to an ML model (2), and then an autoregressive (sequence-to-sequence) ML model (3). Source: Own elaboration. 4800 Piotr Åšliwa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4795â€“4804 6 Piotr Åšliwa, Grzegorz Krzos / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 5. An organization and its environment in organizational studies 5.1. Background Numerous studies in management literature have investigated various aspects of organizations that managers strive to cope with in their pursuit for the common objective - maximizing value by maximizing revenue and minimizing costs, including environmental and societal. A cornerstone to all subsequent managerial models, Taylor's model of scientific management [32], aimed to maximize productivity through the systematic analysis, measurement, and planning of work processes, advocating for the application of scientific methods over traditional 'rule of thumb' approaches, with emphasis on time studies, motion studies, job specialization, and fostering cooperative relationships between workers and managers. Porter [33] analyzed the competitive forces shaping industries and proposed strategies for organizations to gain a competitive advantage. Mintzberg [34] developed a classification of organizational structures based on different configurations of coordination mechanisms. Schein [35] studied organizational culture and its impact on employees' behavior and the overall effectiveness of the organization. Noticeably, the models tend to focus on a single (or a small group) of organizational elements. It is crucial to consider the interplay between various levels of organizational analysis to gain a comprehensive understanding of organizational dynamics [36]. These levels, namely micro-, meso-, and macro-levels, serve as distinct (although they are known to be interrelated in multiple areas) lenses through which researchers and practitioners can examine organizational behavior and processes. The micro-level focuses on individual behaviors, attitudes, and interactions, emphasizing the role of employees, managers, and leaders in shaping organizational performance [37]. The meso-level, on the other hand, examines groups, teams, and departments within organizations, delving into group dynamics, organizational culture, and interdepartmental coordination [38]. Finally, the macro-level investigates the organization as a whole, encompassing its structure, strategy, and overall performance, as well as the impact of external factors such as political, economic, social, and technological forces [39]. A robust analysis of organizational functioning requires a nuanced understanding of these levels and their interactions, as events and decisions at one level can significantly influence the others [36]. In recent years, there has been a growing recognition of the importance of integrating multiple levels of analysis in organizational research [38]. A comprehensive model that combines micro-, meso-, and macro-levels of analysis has been proposed in the extant management literature, emphasizing the interdependence of these levels and their dynamic interaction within organizations. This multilevel framework has been instrumental in shedding light on the complex relationships among individual, team, and organizational factors that drive organizational performance and adaptability. Additionally, this model has led to a more nuanced understanding of the role of context in shaping organizational behavior, challenging traditional linear perspectives and paving the way for a new generation of research that embraces the intricacies of organizational phenomena. Despite the advances in multilevel research and the development of models integrating micro-, meso-, and macro-levels of analysis, there remains a scarcity of studies that comprehensively combine all levels of analysis and encompass all types of elements, such as people, tangible and intangible resources, relations, etc. Bertalanffy's General System Theory [40], on the other hand, laid the foundation for a unifying framework to study the organization and behavior of systems across different disciplines. Bertalanffy recognized that systems, whether they are physical, biological, or social, share common properties and can be analyzed using similar principles. The General System Theory aimed to provide a holistic approach to understanding the organization and interdependence of system components, both internal and external, drawing from the functional-systemic perspective [41]. While Bertalanffy acknowledged that systems, including physical, biological, or social, possess shared characteristics and can be assessed through similar principles, the General System Theory primarily aimed to offer a holistic approach to understanding the organization and interdependence of system components, rather than proposing a specific numerical model for an organization and its environment that encompasses all elements such as people, tangible and intangible resources, relations, etc. Piotr Åšliwa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4795â€“4804 4801 Piotr Åšliwa, Grzegorz Krzos / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 7 5.2. Organizational networks Models of organizational networks come closest to providing a numerical representation of an organization that includes both the organization's internals and its environment and can be presented in a mathematical form. The network paradigm is an interdisciplinary approach that focuses on complex, interdependent relationships among various entities, such as stakeholders, suppliers, and customers [42]. Researchers have recognized the importance of such relationships manifesting in resource sharing, knowledge exchange, strategic alliances, etc., both internal (within an organization) and external (with actors from outside of the organization), which are known to have a significant impact on the organizationâ€™s performance and are the foundation of network models. Borgatti and Halgin [43] explored the concept of organizational networks and presented a comprehensive framework for analyzing and interpreting these networks. The authors, employing the meso-level of analysis, argued that organizations can be viewed as networks comprising nodes (individuals, teams, or departments) and ties (relationships, interactions, or flows) between these nodes. They developed a mathematical model based on graph theory to study the structure and behavior of organizational networks, focusing on social ties rather than multimodal connections. Key features of their model include nodes representing actors and ties representing relationships; the differentiation of events and states to describe relationships; various centrality measures to evaluate node importance; network density as an indicator of interconnectivity; and path length analysis to gain insight into network structure and navigability. This model enables researchers to quantitatively study organizational networks by examining social ties and their impact on network structure, behavior, and performance, while not accounting for multimodal connections that may also be present in such networks. 6. Research gap There is a notable research gap in the existing management literature when it comes to developing a generalized (i.e., without assumed dependencies between its elements), numerical (i.e., with each element in a numerical form) model that encompasses an organization and its environment, and includes people, tangible and intangible resources, relations, etc., that change in time. Such a model is believed to enable the application of ML techniques (which are known to excel at finding dependencies between numerical elements) to solve complex organizational problems of the key management functions and optimize aspects of organizational management in a holistic manner by considering the dynamic interactions between elements of the organization and elements of its environment. While organizational network models represent a promising approach for capturing the complex dynamics of organizations and their environment, no article describing a generalized, numerical model that incorporates multimodal elements was found during the review. Development of such a generalized, numerical model of an organization and its environment is believed to pose significant challenges, including: â€¢ Representation of people: Modeling individualsâ€™ characteristics, such as skills, experience, and motivation, in numerical form, as well as capturing the interactions between the individuals and their impact on organizational performance. â€¢ Representation of resources: Quantifying the organization's tangible and intangible resources, such as financial capital, technology, or knowledge, and modelling their allocation and utilization within the organization. â€¢ Representation of relations: Translating interpersonal, interorganizational, person-organization, resource- resource, person-resource, and any other abstract form of a relationship into numerical terms. This implies devising metrics that encapsulate the nature and strength of these relationships, which may include aspects such as communication, collaboration, conflict, influence, trust, formal and informal connections within the organization and between different resources, etc. Furthermore, the model would need to account for changes in 4802 Piotr Åšliwa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4795â€“48048 Piotr Åšliwa, Grzegorz Krzos / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 these relationships over time and the effect they have on the overall performance and strategic outcomes of the organization. â€¢ Integration of organizational dimensions: Combining different dimensions of the organization, such as structure, culture, and strategy, as well as different perspectives such as intra-organizational and inter-organizational, into a unified numerical model that reflects the complex interdependencies and dynamics of organizational systems. â€¢ Modelling of temporal dependencies: Capturing temporal dependencies among numerous variables. This involves tracking the evolution of elements like employee performance, resource allocation, and organizational dimensions, which are influenced by both current and historical states. The model should account for delay effects, feedback loops, and non-linear time dependencies, making it a complex task to accurately predict future states based on past and present data. â€¢ Presentation: Providing an easily accessible and understandable interface for a user (i.e., a management practitioner) to the knowledge about the organization and its environment synthesized by the model, so the user can draw valuable and actionable conclusions. â€¢ Ensuring robustness and reliability: Creating a model that is robust and reliable over time and under a range of conditions, considering the inherent uncertainty and changeability in organizations and their environments. This challenge involves validating the model using real-world data and ensuring it is flexible enough to accommodate changes in the organization and its environment. 7. Discussion In this paper, we have critically reviewed the management literature to identify the key management functions managers of organizations deal with in managerial processes, the requirements for a model to be applicable in ML pipelines, and finally reveal a research gap concerning the development of a generalized, numerical model encompassing both an organization and its environment. The findings of the review highlighted the scarcity of generalized, numerical models of an organization and its environment. The objective for the novel model is to be applied in a ML pipeline to solve complex managerial problems, and effectively support managers in the key management functions by enhancing decision-making processes, reducing costs (which include environmental and societal), and improving overall organizational performance and sustainability. While there has been significant progress in modelling various dimensions of organizations, most studies have primarily focused on non-numerical models, or considered only selected aspects of the observed socio-economic reality, without an attempt to generalize the models. A promising approach is the model of organizational networks, which can potentially serve as the foundation for the generalized, numerical model of an organization and its environment. Organizational networks capture the complex interactions and relationships between different actors within and outside the organization, providing a comprehensive view of the organization's structure and dynamics. Notably, the network models are rooted in mathematical concepts, like graph theory, which makes them easier to translate into a purely numerical form, understandable by ML algorithms. Future research aiming to build AI-supported managerial processes (i.e., with ML techniques) should focus on developing novel methodologies for representing organizations and their environments numerically, flexible enough to be able to accommodate various dimensions and complexities of organizational systems, identified on the course of managerial processes. The authors hope that such AI-supported management will have an increasing impact on sustainable business operations and the AI-supported sustainable management will become a tool creating a global competitive advantage of modern economies while minimizing negative environmental and societal effects. However, it is essential to acknowledge the limitations of this review. One major limitation is the number of articles reviewed. The scope of the review was restricted, and a more comprehensive review of the literature might yield additional insights and reveal further research gaps. Future research should consider conducting a systematic review or meta-analysis to provide a more extensive and in-depth understanding of the existing literature on Piotr Åšliwa et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4795â€“4804 4803 Piotr Åšliwa, Grzegorz Krzos / Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 9 numerical models of organizations and their environments. Another important limitation is inherent to the supposition laying in the foundation of this research, that ML techniques can indeed automate tasks in the management functions and therefore make the process more efficient. While the abundance of applications supports the notion, it is still plausible that ML cannot solve this class of problems. Notably, ML techniques often struggle with problems that involve high degrees of human intuition, interaction, creativity, and subjective decision-making, which are all integral parts of the management functions. It could be suggested that a blend of ML techniques with more traditional, human-driven approaches might serve better in overcoming the challenges associated with management of an organization. Komandorska 118-120, 53-345 Wroclaw, Poland Undoubtedly, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is going mainstream. More and more AI agents come into existence to augment human agents in their work by synthesizing a gigantic body of knowledge in a conversational interface (e.g., ChatGPT), generating art from a provided description (e.g., Stable Diffusion), creating software code based on a provided description (e.g., Codex), just to name a few. It becomes evident that at some point an AI agent will similarly help human managers in their daily operations, and, when it reaches the level of artificial general intelligence (AGI), unlock completely new levels of performance and sustainability. The authors used the critical review method and identified a research gap concerning the development of a generalized, numerical model of an organization and its environment that could be applied in machine learning pipelines, and effectively support managers in the key management functions. The relationship between artificial intelligence, big data, and unemployment in G7 countries: New insights from dynamic panel data model Hasraddin Guliyev a ⁎ Natiq Huseynov a Nasimi Nuriyev b c a Azerbaijan State Economic University, International Magistrate and Doctorate Center, Nasimi, Baku AZ1007, Azerbaijan Azerbaijan State Economic University International Magistrate and Doctorate Center Nasimi Baku AZ1007 Azerbaijan aAzerbaijan State Economic University, International Magistrate and Doctorate Center, Nasimi, Baku AZ1007, Azerbaijan b Azerbaijan State Economic University, UNEC Business School, Sabail, Baku AZ1001, Azerbaijan Azerbaijan State Economic University UNEC Business School Sabail Baku AZ1001 Azerbaijan Azerbaijan State Economic University, UNEC Business School, Sabail, Baku AZ1001, Azerbaijan c Istanbul University, Department of Economics, Beyazit Campus, Fatih, Istanbul 34126, Turkey Istanbul University Department of Economics Beyazit Campus Fatih Istanbul 34126 Turkey bDepartment of Economics, Istanbul University, Beyazit Campus, Fatih, Istanbul 34126, Turkey ⁎ Corresponding author. This study investigates the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) and big data technologies on unemployment in the G7 countries using a dynamic panel estimation approach. The analysis covers the period from 2005 to 2020 and incorporates various control variables related to unemployment rates, along with AI, big data, data science, and machine learning Google Trend Index (GTI). The Arellano–Bover/Blundell–Bond (1998) system estimator is employed to ensure robust results, particularly in cases involving multiple lags of the dependent variable. The most noteworthy results highlight a negative association between AI, big data technologies, and unemployment. These technologies enhance productivity, leading to increased capital accumulation and the creation of new jobs. This validates the "displacement effect" for AI and big data technologies, implying that while certain jobs may be automated, the net effect is job creation. Consequently, implementing AI and big data technologies in economic processes can effectively reduce unemployment rates and boost wages by creating new job opportunities. Keywords Artificial intelligence Big data Unemployment rate Dynamic panel data model JEL Code F22 C23 O17 Introduction In recent decades, the rapid development and widespread adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) and automation have sparked profound inspiration and significant transformations across various industries. These advancements have revolutionized sectors such as medical diagnoses, autonomous transportation, and advanced manufacturing. According to Francis Gurry's observations, AI represents a new digital frontier that will fundamentally reshape our way of life and work [1]. Moore's [2] law, associated with the decreasing size and increasing power of computers, arises from the observation that the processing power of a chip doubles roughly every two years because the shrinking size of transistors allows them to populate the chip more densely. Moore's law is, however, not without its dark side. For example, as we have moved from generation to generation, the power consumed by each transistor has not fallen in direct proportion to its size, so both the total power consumed by each chip and the power density have been increasing rapidly. A few years ago, it became vogue to observe, given current trends, that in a few generations the temperature on a chip would be hotter than that on the surface of the sun. Thus, over the last few years, in addition to their concerns about improving performance, architects have had to deal with using and managing power effectively [3]. However, the transformative impact of AI extends well beyond the realm of computer hardware. Big data technologies, machine learning, computer vision, neural networks, and other innovations have simplified everyday tasks and even influenced human behavior patterns. As a result, AI has empowered cognitive machines and modern information technologies, leading to a powerful transformation in both personal and professional domains. While AI has the potential to enhance productivity in numerous industries, it also raises concerns about the displacement of human labor and the revolutionizing of occupations. The emergence of groundbreaking technological innovations has been a topic of consistent engagement for economists and policymakers. The effects of artificial intelligence on the economy, particularly in relation to unemployment, are widely discussed. It is anticipated that the economic impact of artificial intelligence may vary across different regions, influenced by the specific economic activities and technological readiness of each region. There are two main streams of opinion regarding the effects of artificial intelligence on unemployment. The first perspective, known as the "replacement effect," optimistically asserts that AI lowers the unemployment rate by enhancing complementarity between human and intellectual capabilities. Proponents of this viewpoint argue that AI is a new technology that fosters productivity, reduces labor requirements, and drives economic expansion, thereby generating employment opportunities in other sectors. In contrast, the opposing viewpoint emphasizes the "displacement effect" and predicts a rise in unemployment. According to this perspective, although new jobs may be created in the modern age, they are primarily performed by robots, "brilliant machines," or cognitive systems, potentially leading to a jobless economy [4,5]. In the existing literature, researchers have primarily relied on descriptive and comparative analyses to explore the connection between AI and unemployment. However, a comprehensive econometric model to determine this relationship has yet to be suggested. One of the main obstacles is the lack of systematic data to accurately measure the utilization of AI and big data technologies. Consequently, researchers have turned to alternative data sources such as Google Trends data to enhance unemployment modeling. The Google Trends Index (GTI) monitors patterns of words or phrases entered the Google search engine. Previous attempts to incorporate GTIs into predictive models have shown promising results [6–8]. Taking this perspective into account, the present study aims to employ GTIs associated with AI in G7 countries to establish the relationship between AI, big data technologies, and the unemployment rate. Firstly, this study proposes a comprehensive analysis that focuses specifically on G7 countries, distinguishing itself from previous studies. Secondly, it pioneers the utilization of a dynamic panel data estimation method to examine the impact of artificial intelligence on unemployment. By employing this innovative approach, the study seeks to provide valuable insights into the complex dynamics between AI, big data technologies, and unemployment, shedding light on the potential consequences for the labor market. Literature review In recent years, there has been a notable expansion in the literature concerning the impact of AI on unemployment [9,10–12]. Many contributions in this area consider AI as a component of a broader automation process [13]. Broadly speaking, the literature can be categorized into two main approaches: those supporting a 'replacement effect' of jobs by AI and those supporting a 'displacement effect'. The first part of the literature validates the 'replacement effect' and highlights various aspects of this phenomenon. According to these studies, the application of AI has a negative impact on the labor market, leading to unemployment as a result of job replacement. Early academic works exploring the negative impact of AI on employment can be traced back to Leontief [14], who predicted that AI would replace almost the entire workforce in the coming decades, resulting in widespread unemployment. Ngo et al. [15] found that 48 % of technology specialists believe that robots could perform the most standardized and automated tasks. Consequently, in the era of AI, traditional jobs, except for those requiring highly specialized skills, are at risk of unemployment. Susskind and Susskind [16] argue that high-tech unemployment will further increase in the age of artificial intelligence, with traditional industries being gradually replaced by routine tasks performed by technology. Frey and Osborne [17] developed a model that revealed 47 % of more than 700 occupations are susceptible to being replaced within the next two decades. David [18] pointed out that the jobs at high risk of substitution by AI, irrespective of gender differences, account for as much as 55 %. Graetz and Michaels [19] found that robots have had a greater impact on reducing responsibilities for low-skilled workers compared to medium-skilled and high-skilled workers. Furthermore, studies by Felten et al. [20] and Fossen and Sorgner [21] showed a positive association between high computerization risk and the likelihood of occupation change or unemployment. Chang-jun et al. [22] suggest that universities play a crucial role in enhancing professional skills and cultivating desirable personality traits that can help graduates reduce the risk of being replaced by AI. Georgieff and Milanez [23] examined whether occupations identified as having a high risk of automation in 2012 experienced a net loss of workers seven years later. They found that these occupations displayed weaker employment growth compared to other jobs, and in some cases, even experienced a modest decline in employment levels. Ma et al. [24] demonstrated that the development of AI significantly affects the skill structure of employment, and regional innovation plays a significant mediating role. They observed that with increased innovation, industrial upgrading, and technological progress, the influence of AI on middle-skill employment gradually weakens, while high-skilled employment exhibits a U-shaped change under the influence of an innovative environment and technological progress. The second part of the literature presents the "displacement effect," suggesting that AI has a positive impact on the labor market, leading to a decrease in unemployment. Scholars argue that while artificial intelligence may have a short-term impact on the job market, the substantial increase in production efficiency will ultimately result in the creation of more jobs and employment opportunities in the long term. Nobel Prize-winning economist Boden [25] asserts that AI development is replicable and predicts that, despite transitional challenges, there will be a considerable increase in job creation—albeit in different forms—eliminating long-term concerns about unemployment. Supporting this theory, the McKinsey Global Institute Research [26] predicts a demand for 250,000 data scientists by 2024. Additional studies provide further evidence for the displacement effect. Dauth et al. [27] examine the effects of robot adoption on the German labor market and find that it redistributes jobs across industries without decreasing overall employment levels. Gries and Naudé [28] integrate artificial intelligence into an economic growth model, incorporating limitations on total demand. Their findings suggest that AI does not directly lead to increased unemployment. Acemoglu and Restrepo [29] investigate the relationship between AI, automation, and work, highlighting the improvement in productivity driven by AI and automation, which is further supported by increased capital accumulation. This, in turn, leads to the technical advancement of existing work with more skilled workers, creating new jobs. Webb [30] observes a decline in employment and wages for jobs highly exposed to automation technologies, while Aghion et al. [31], using French data, find a positive impact of automation on employment at the firm and industry levels. Koch et al. [32] analyze a panel of Spanish manufacturing firms and report a net increase of 10 % in jobs due to robot adoption, while firms that did not invest in robots experienced job losses over the same period. However, it is important to note that at the aggregate level, automation does not lead to net job destruction. Felten et al. [33] propose an "AI Occupational Impact" measure and find that while artificial intelligence has a small positive effect on wages, it does not significantly impact employment. Acemoglu et al. [34] analyze data on online vacancies and find no correlation between AI exposure and employment or wages. Despite the various aspects in which artificial intelligence and unemployment are discussed in the literature, empirical studies remain limited. Therefore, this study aims to address three critical research gaps. Firstly, there is a lack of empirical papers that focus on examining the relationship between artificial intelligence, big data technologies, and unemployment. While previous research has explored the futuristic aspects of AI, this study takes a step further by developing an empirical econometric model. Secondly, there is a shortage of systematic and big datasets on AI usage for investigating the relationship between AI and unemployment. Therefore, this study utilizes a comprehensive yearly dataset covering the period from 2005 to 2020, encompassing panel data from G7 countries. The dataset related to unemployment and the control variables used was obtained from the World Development Indicators (WDI) and OECD database, as well as the GTIs dataset was sourced from Google Trend to acquire a comprehensive and systematic dataset. Methodology and empirical model Research variables and dataset This section examines the model variables that focus on the impact of artificial intelligence and big data technologies on unemployment in the G7 countries. The response variable, representing the unemployment rate as a percentage of the total labor force, signifies individuals who are unemployed but actively seeking employment. To isolate the effects of the main variable of interest, a set of control variables is evaluated. Theoretical models and existing literature suggest that variables such as inflation rate, population growth, government size, and foreign direct investment (FDI) are essential control variables. The inflation rate reflects the annual percentage change in the economy's overall price level, as measured by the consumer price index. The theoretical literature indicates a negative relationship between inflation and unemployment [35]. The Phillips curve theory establishes a stable relationship between inflation and unemployment dynamics, stating that inflationary growth leads to increased job creation and reduced unemployment [36]. The total population within the age range of 15 to 64 represents individuals with full legal status or citizenship and serves as a midyear estimate. Population growth can positively affect employment by stimulating consumer demand, driving economic activity, and creating new job opportunities. Moreover, a larger labor force can contribute to productivity gains, innovation, and entrepreneurship, fostering economic growth and reducing unemployment rates. The relationship between population growth and unemployment is influenced by various factors, including overall economic conditions, labor market policies, education and training systems, technological advancements, and government interventions. Effectively managing unemployment in the context of population growth requires a comprehensive approach that addresses both the demand side (creating sufficient job opportunities) and the supply side (equipping individuals with the necessary skills and qualifications). Government size, expressed as a percentage of GDP, refers to cash payments for operating activities in the provision of goods and services. Fiscal actions can influence labor supply and unemployment, even with output growth. Alternatively, if reductions in government purchases lead to increased private-sector output and higher productivity, GDP can still grow despite an increase in unemployment. Recent research reflects this ambiguity: While Monacelli et al. [37], Auerbach and Gorodnichenko [38], Ramey [39], Holden and Sparrman [40] conclude that an increase in government purchases leads to lower unemployment, a string of empirical studies indicates that enormous government spending will likely increase unemployment. Abrams [41], Christopoulos et al. [42], Feldmann [43], Brückner and Pappa [44] find that increased government purchases lead to higher unemployment. Labor productivity, measured as output per worker and comprising GDP and the total employed population, does not exhibit a particularly noticeable relationship with unemployment. Basu et al. [45], for instance, emphasize the negative impact of productivity on unemployment resulting from technological shocks. In contrast, Gallegati et al. [46], using a pure wavelet method, suggest a positive effect, but only in the long run. Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) refers to net inflows of funds used to acquire a long-term managerial stake in a company operating in a country other than that of the investors. The literature indicates that FDI inflows generate additional jobs [47,48]. Therefore, an inverse relationship between FDI and unemployment is expected. The main variable of interest captures the volume of the GTIs related to AI and big data technologies. The four most popular search terms considered for big data and artificial intelligence are: “Artificial Intelligence”, “Big Data”, “Data Science”, and “Machine Learning”, respectively. Four different scenarios were estimated due to the high correlation among these search terms. Consequently, the variables, variable description, data source and predicted signs of variable are described in Table 1 based on both the empirical model and the literature. Econometric method and empirical model This section decides the econometric method and empirical model for the variables we examine. Because unemployment rates are always influenced by historical values, dynamic panel models are more appropriate. Dynamic panel-data models include p lags of the dependent variable as covariates and contain unobserved panel-level effects, fixed or random. By construction, the unobserved panel-level effects are correlated with the lagged dependent variables, making standard estimators inconsistent [49]. Arellano and Bond [50] derived a consistent generalized moments (GMM) estimator method for this model. The Arellano and Bond estimator can perform poorly if the autoregressive parameters are too large or the ratio of the variance of the panel-level effect to the variance of the idiosyncratic error is too large. Building on the work of Arellano and Bover [51], Blundell and Bond [52] developed a system estimator that uses additional moment conditions; y i t = ∑ j = 1 p α j y i , t − j + x i t β 1 + w i t β 2 + ν i + ϵ i t i = 1 , … , N t = 1 , … , T i where the α j are p parameters to be estimated, x i t is a 1 × k 1 vector of strictly exogenous covariates, β 1 is a k 1 × 1 vector of parameters to be estimated, w i t is a 1 × k 2 vector of predetermined or endogenous covariates, β 2 is a k 2 × 1 vector of parameters to be estimated, ν i are the panel-level effects (which may be correlated with the covariates), and ϵ i t are i.i.d. over the whole sample with variance σ ϵ 2 . The ν i and the ϵ i t are assumed to be independent for each i overall t . This estimator is designed for datasets with many panels and few periods. This method assumes no autocorrelation in the idiosyncratic errors. It requires the initial condition that the panel-level effects be uncorrelated with the first difference of the first observation of the dependent variable. Blundell and Bond [52] indicate that the lagged-level instruments in the Arellano–Bond estimator come to be weak as the autoregressive process turn into too persistent or the ratio of the panel-level effects νi to the variance of the idiosyncratic error ϵ i t grow to be too larger. Construction on the study of Arellano and Bover [51], Blundell and Bond [52] suggested a system estimator that application moment conditions in which lagged differences are used as instruments for the level equation and the moment conditions of lagged levels as instruments for the differenced equation. The additional moment conditions are acceptable only if the initial condition E[νi∆yi2] = 0 holds for all i . The empirical model we propose builds upon existing literature but incorporates some modifications. Inspired by the methods employed by Dornbusch et al. [53], we combine the Phillips curve [35] and Okun's law [54]. However, unlike previous studies, our approach incorporates artificial intelligence and big data technologies as controlling factors for unemployment. Hence, our model can be represented as shown in Eq. (1). (1) U N i , t = α 0 + β 1 U N i , t − 1 + β 2 U N i , t − 2 + β 3 I R i , t + β 4 P G i , t + β 5 L P i , t + β 6 G S i , t + β 7 F D I i , t + β 8 G T I i , t + ε i , t Where UN is unemployment rate, IR (Inflation rate), PG (Population Growth), GS (Government Size), LP(Labor Productivity), FDI (Foreign Direct Investment), and the GTI is Google Trend Index that this variable takes on different values for every search term in different scenarios. While, countries denote (i), time denotes (t), constant (α0), coefficients (β1 to β6) and error term (εi,t). Empirical findings Descriptive analysis The empirical study utilizes a panel dataset consisting of G7 member countries from 2005 to 2020. The timeframe of the study corresponds to the years when the global interest in artificial intelligence and big data searches experienced a notable increase. The selected countries include Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States. This choice is motivated by two key factors: firstly, these nations possess advanced technology and complex economies, and secondly, they ranked highly in the Global Innovation 2019 rankings, indicating significant innovation performance. Firstly, we start to investigate the global trends in job creation associated with Data Science, Machine Learning, Big Data, and Artificial Intelligence in this study. Fig. 1 illustrates the global trendline for these technologies from 2005 to 2020. Based on the calculations of GTIs in Fig. 1, it is observed that the search term “Machine Learning” has garnered the highest level of global attention, and it has been receiving more searches compared to “Data Science” and “Artificial Intelligence” since 2014. Although the search term “Artificial Intelligence” experienced a decline until 2014, it regained popularity after mid-2016. Conversely, the search terms “Data Science”, “Machine Learning” and “Big Data” did not receive significant attention until 2012 but started to gain traction afterward. Table 2 displays the correlation matrix, which highlights the relationships between these search terms. In Table 2, calculated Pearson's correlation coefficients indicate data science has a stronger positive correlation with machine learning ( ρ =0.980) and AI ( ρ =0.815); however, it has a moderate positive correlation with big data ( ρ =0.697). Furthermore, machine learning Services have a stronger positive correlation with big data ( ρ =0.731) and AI ( ρ =0.844). In addition, big data has a moderate positive correlation with AI ( ρ =0.448). Many economic, science, and technology development and rising trends in the world are directed by the G7 countries. As a result, it would be interesting to see in Fig. 2 which of these search terms the G7 countries use the most. Machine learning is a more popular search topic in Japan and Germany, as shown in Fig. 2. Furthermore, in France, big data is a popular search topic, and AI searches in Google are similar level in Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States. Empirical results In this section, we estimate the econometric model in Eq. (1). The F-test for fixed effects confirms the presence of fixed effects across all scenarios in Table 3 . Hence, disregarding fixed effects is not justified. To account for these fixed effects, we can incorporate them as dummy variables or employ a first-difference approach using dynamic panel GMM estimators. All scenarios presented in Table 3 consider the unemployment process with a consideration of past unemployment levels, reflecting a form of "memory." The Sargan [55] test and the p-values for the Arellano-Bond [56] test for AR(2) demonstrate that the instruments used in the models are well identified, and the residuals do not exhibit autocorrelation. Consequently, all the models exhibit robustness when utilizing estimation methods like the Arellano-Bover/Blundell-Bond [51,52] GMM-system estimator. The results of the Pesaran [57,58] CD cross-sectional dependence test indicate the absence of cross-sectional dependence across all scenarios. In the estimation process, robust standard errors are employed to account for heteroscedasticity, and the variables included in the model exhibit statistical significance, at least at the 5 % level. Table 3 also reveals that the process of adjusting unemployment is still inflexible, as current unemployment shows both positive and negative associations with previous unemployment. Government size and population growth have a positive impact on unemployment across all scenarios, while inflation, labor productivity, and FDI exhibit negative effects. The main findings highlight a significant negative correlation between artificial intelligence, big data technologies, and unemployment. In Scenario 1, an increase in the search volume (GTI) related to artificial intelligence in G7 countries leads to a reduction in the unemployment rate by 0.011 percent. Similarly, in Scenario 2, an increase in the search volume related to big data results in a decrease in the unemployment rate by 0.007 percent. Additionally, increased search volumes for data science (Scenario 3) and machine learning (Scenario 4) separately contribute to a reduction in the unemployment rate by 0.005 percent. Consequently, all scenarios confirm the existence of the "displacement effect." These new technologies, such as AI and big data, do not contribute to increased unemployment. On the contrary, they generate new job opportunities and decrease unemployment. Conclusion This study analyzes the impact of artificial intelligence and big data technologies on unemployment in the G7 countries. It utilizes an empirical model based on dynamic panel data estimations. The dataset covers the period from 2005 to 2020 and includes control variables related to the unemployment rate, as well as key variables such as AI, big data, data science, and the machine learning Google Trend Index (GTI). The study examines the relationship between artificial intelligence, big data technologies, and unemployment across four scenarios, each associated with specific GTIs. The Arellano–Bover/Blundell–Bond [51,52] system estimator is employed to test all scenarios, providing robust results, especially when multiple lags of the dependent variable are incorporated. Diagnostic tests confirm the validity of the econometric model, and all variables within the model are found to be statistically significant. The findings reveal consistency with economic theories, with inflation findings aligning with Phillips [35] and labor productivity results corresponding to Basu et al. [45]. Each scenarios validates the Phillips effect, which relates to the relationship between inflation and unemployment. In addition, all scenarios underscore the importance of labor productivity. Additionally, the study highlights two critical determinants, the government size and foreign direct investment, which are strongly recommended in the literature as controls in the dynamic panel data model for our scenarios. Across all cases, government size and foreign direct investment are both significant and negatively correlated with unemployment, findings supported by Feldmann [43], Craigwell [47], and Karlsson et al. [48]. Specifically, expanding the public sector in the economies under discussion absorbs unemployment, with net FDI inflows supporting this process. The most significant findings indicate a negative relationship between artificial intelligence, big data technologies, and unemployment. AI and big data technologies enhance productivity, which is further bolstered by increased capital accumulation. The infusion of a larger labor force into current businesses results in technological improvements and the creation of new jobs, validating the 'displacement effect' for AI and big data technologies. The impact of AI on employment has been a subject of extensive debate and concern. While AI has indeed led to automation and the displacement of certain jobs, its overall impact on employment is more nuanced. AI technologies have the potential to generate new job opportunities, particularly in the development and maintenance of AI systems and related technologies. Moreover, AI can augment human capabilities and enhance productivity, leading to the creation of new roles and the reassignment of tasks. However, there is a need for workforce retraining and upskilling to adapt to the evolving job landscape. To ensure a seamless transition and minimize adverse consequences, proactive measures such as investing in education and training programs, fostering entrepreneurship, and promoting the responsible use of AI in the labor market are crucial. In addition, striking a balance between harnessing the benefits of AI for productivity and economic growth while addressing potential job displacement and ensuring the workforce is equipped with the skills needed for the AI-driven economy of the future is essential. As a result, G7 and other high-tech countries can effectively leverage artificial intelligence and big data technologies in economic processes to reduce unemployment. Consequently, with new job opportunities created through innovative technology, it could become possible to manage unemployment rates and wages effectively. To align with the WHO World Report on Vision recommendations to integrate eye health as part of universal health coverage, eye health services must be prioritised in national health policy planning and budgeting. 1,8,10 In addition to national organisations, public-private partnerships with for-profit and non-governmental organisations (NGOs) can play a pivotal role in funding progress. 115 In partnership with the government and the Brien Holden Vision Institute, Pakistan's largest NGO, the Pakistan Layton Rahmatulla Benevolent Trust Hospital, supported optical stores within secondary and tertiary hospitals, to increase patient uptake of prescribed spectacles. 114,116 In Tanzania, a sevenfold increase in patients receiving eye care was achieved thanks to funding from government and
