168751 Singapore † Joint-first authors Global eye health is defined as the degree to which vision, ocular health, and function are maximised worldwide, thereby optimising overall wellbeing and quality of life. Improving eye health is a global priority as a key to unlocking human potential by reducing the morbidity burden of disease, increasing productivity, and supporting access to education. Although extraordinary progress fuelled by global eye health initiatives has been made over the last decade, there remain substantial challenges impeding further progress. The accelerated development of digital health and artificial intelligence (AI) applications provides an opportunity to transform eye health, from facilitating and increasing access to eye care to supporting clinical decision making with an objective, data-driven approach. Here, we explore the opportunities and challenges presented by digital health and AI in global eye health and describe how these technologies could be leveraged to improve global eye health. AI, telehealth, and emerging technologies have great potential, but require specific work to overcome barriers to implementation. We suggest that a global digital eye health task force could facilitate coordination of funding, infrastructural development, and democratisation of AI and digital health to drive progress forwards in this domain. Introduction Global eye health is defined by The Lancet Global Health Commission as the degree to which vision, ocular health, and function are maximised worldwide, thereby optimising overall wellbeing and quality of life. 1 In addition to being a substantial source of morbidity around the world, vision impairment also has an important influence on economic productivity, with an estimated global productivity loss from visual impairment amounting to US$410·7 billion in 2020. 2 Improvements in eye health also support access to quality education, empowering more individuals to seek employment, and in turn reducing inequalities. 1,3 However, worldwide, over 2·2 billion people have near or distance vision impairment, with half of these cases preventable or treatable. 2 Relative to higher-income countries, rates are estimated to be eight-times higher in low-income countries and four-times higher in middle-income countries. 2,4 Globally, leading causes of visual impairment include uncorrected refractive errors, cataract, age-related macular degeneration, glaucoma, and diabetic retinopathy. Moreover, many more patients rely on continuous eye care services to prevent visual loss or have conditions such as dry eyes or conjunctivitis associated with substantial morbidity despite their sparing of vision. 5 Over the last three decades, global public health initiatives have made considerable progress in eye health, including a substantial reduction in cases of trachoma, vitamin A deficiency, and onchocerciasis (river blindness). 6,7 There has been a reduced age-standardised prevalence of avoidable blindness (–15·4% [95% CI –16·8 to –14·3]), although avoidable moderate and severe vision impairment showed no change over the same period (0·5% [–0·8 to 1·6]). 2 However, the absolute number of cases has increased for both avoidable blindness (10·8% [8·9 to 12·4]) and avoidable moderate and severe vision impairment (31·5% [30·0 to 33·1]). Further action is needed. Evolving priorities for global eye health There have been several major global programmes and initiatives to identify the major challenges and provide a roadmap to improve and maintain global eye health. The Lancet Global Health Commission defined grand challenges in global eye health through a prioritisation exercise, to guide action and research. The process involved diverse stakeholders in over 118 countries, representing clinical practice, eye care system management, research, policy making, and patients affected by eye health problems. 8 Key identified global and regional challenges included improving condition-specific treatment approaches, integration of eye health into the broader health system at all levels, improving access and equity to eye care services, and building resource capacity. 8 WHO has adopted similar recommendations. Achieving universal health coverage—ensuring all people can receive the high-quality health services they need, without experiencing financial hardship—is a WHO strategic priority. 9 The WHO World Report on Vision recommends making eye care an integral part of universal health coverage. 10 The adoption of the World Health Assembly Resolution 73.4 in 2020 requires all countries to strengthen eye care within and across their health systems, 11 and two new global targets for eye care have been endorsed: increasing the effective refractive error coverage by 40% and the effective cataract surgical coverage by 30% before 2030. 12 The first UN General Assembly resolution on eye health: Vision for Everyone—Accelerating Action to Achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) was unanimously adopted by all 193 countries of the UN on July 23, 2021. 13 It is the first agreement designed to tackle preventable sight loss adopted by the UN, enshrining eye health as a part of the UN's SDGs. The resolution creates new expectations for international financial institutions and donors to provide targeted finances, especially to support developing countries in tackling preventable sight loss. Additionally, the UN now incorporates eye care in its work. The resolution sets a target for eye care for all by 2030—with all countries providing full access to eye care services for their populations, and making eye care part of nations’ journeys to attain the SDGs. Bringing together these major initiatives, 2030 IN SIGHT is the eye health sector's strategic plan for the next decade. 14 It synthesises recommendations from The Lancet Global Health Commission on Global Eye Health, the UN, and WHO to advocate for the elevation of vision as a fundamental economic, social and development issue; integrate eye health in wider health-care systems and activate patient, consumer, and market change; and ultimately to achieve universal health coverage and the UN's SDGs. Embracing technology is one of the ten key working points incorporated into 2030 IN SIGHT, and technological solutions are highlighted by The Lancet Global Health Commission on Global Eye Health for their potential to improve delivery and coverage of eye care services. Although extraordinary progress has been made over the last decade, there remain considerable challenges which present an opportunity to improve the lives of billions of people by improving global eye health. In this Review, we specifically explore the opportunities and challenges represented by digital health and artificial intelligence (AI) in global eye health. Potential of AI and digital health in global eye health Digital health is used as a term to describe the multidisciplinary, innovative space encompassing medicine and technology. WHO recommends the assessment of digital health tools on the basis of benefits, harms, acceptability, feasibility, resource use, and equity considerations. 15 Digital health innovation includes AI, telemedicine, virtual reality, and wireless communication technologies; all potentially integrated into clinical diagnosis, management, and prognosis. The development of digital health and AI applications has accelerated in the last 10 years (figure 1 ), and WHO has emphasised that these new tools could transform eye health, ranging from facilitating and increasing access to eye care to supporting clinical decision making with an objective, data-driven approach. 16,17 AI AI has shown great potential in automating tasks requiring clinical expertise, particularly in ophthalmological diagnosis. Deep learning has emerged since the 2010s as an AI technique facilitating analysis of unstructured data, such as language, images, and video. 18 In ophthalmology, deep learning is most commonly applied to diagnostic medical imaging: principally fundus photography and optical coherence tomography. 19 Algorithms trained with deep learning have shown expert or supra-expert level diagnostic accuracy for diabetic retinopathy, age-related macular degeneration, glaucoma, retinopathy of prematurity, refractive error, cataract, and anterior segment diseases; and many have been accepted by regulatory agencies such as the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and European Union Medical Device Regulation. 19–21 A plethora of models are available for many conditions, all offering different strengths and limitations such as differential sensitivity, specificity, and computational requirements. Deciding which to use requires careful consideration. 19 Similar techniques have also been used on ophthalmological data in other contexts, such as to gauge the health of anatomically removed systems in oculomics (eg, heart, kidneys), or to identify personal characteristics (eg, sex and ethnicity). 22,23 Natural language processing is another form of AI which also depends on deep learning, and underlies efforts to automate initial clinical encounters, such as with chatbots (eg, ChatGPT, discussed here), interpretation of clinical notes, and data gathering from patient records. 24 In high-income countries, the specific applications of currently available AI technology range from diagnosis, risk assessment, prognosis, oculomics, decision making, and disease screening, to health policy and planning. 25 The deployment of AI systems in low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs) in eye health is not as widely available to date but includes screening for diabetic retinopathy, myopia, and retinopathy of prematurity using fundus photographs. 26–29 Although other validated digital health technologies have large potential in LMIC settings, this requires addressing key organisational and financial challenges, discussed here. More generally, AI could facilitate a reorientation of eye health service provision to be centred on primary care. An example of real-life deployment of AI-assisted diabetic retinopathy screening in primary care settings in Rwanda, a central African LMIC, showed higher adherence to referrals generated by an AI system when compared with conventional grading by a human. 30 AI-assisted diabetic retinopathy screening facilitated by the Cybersight AI telehealth platform (Orbis International, New York, USA) enabled immediate diabetic retinopathy grading for referral recommendation, and also facilitated same-day ophthalmologist review and immediate eye health counselling (figure 2 ). 30 Another example is Automated Retinal Disease Assessment (ARDA), used to screen over 200 000 patients for diabetic retinopathy in India and Thailand. 31 The ARDA team have described successfully overcoming a range of unexpected challenges which provides a useful roadmap for future projects. 31 Such systems could reduce the burden on stretched specialist clinics, and also improve prompt delivery of patient-centred care. 30,32 These prior examples of successful deployment would benefit LMICs most considerably as they possess the fewest ophthalmologists per capita. 33 Telehealth, virtual reality, and augmented reality Telehealth in ophthalmology describes platforms and mechanisms of delivering care to patients remotely. 34 Although efforts were already underway to increase remote consultations as a proportion of patient interactions, the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated implementation of telephone and video. 35,36 The capabilities of telehealth are further increased by innovative means of conducting diagnostic tests and delivering treatment to patients remotely. These means include home-based tests, such as for visual acuity or visual fields, 37,38 which have been deployed successfully within LMICs. 39 Other tests requiring more expensive hardware could also improve coverage of eye care by facilitating examination in remote hubs or within primary care settings—rather than in stretched or inaccessible centralised ophthalmology clinics—with subsequent asynchronous remote-viewing of findings by humans—eg, trained graders or specialist physicians. 40 Patient education is also possible on telephone and video platforms, but certain aspects of management depend on physical contact, and therefore still require face-to-face interaction. 32,41 Telehealth can engage communities by improving their access to health care; its potential is amplified by integrating other emerging technologies to increase functionality, such as with AI and remotely delivered test platforms. 38,42,43 Telehealth can also be enhanced through immersive virtual reality (an entirely simulated environment) and augmented reality (an augmentation of the natural environment with superimposed elements). Both augmented and virtual reality have been used to improve diagnosis, education, and management. 44,45 However, costs are currently prohibitive, and further research is required to establish efficacy and cost-effectiveness. 45 As these extended reality technologies mature, there is potential for disruptive innovation to improve clinical practice and medical education. 46 Costs might impede deployment at scale in LMICs, but smaller investments in this technology could be leveraged in the future to optimise remote training of eye specialists to serve less privileged communities, or to improve the capacity and capability of centralised but peripheral clinics through real-time communication with domestic or international specialist centres. Emerging technologies: 6G, wearables, big data, internet of things, and AI assistants Most digital health solutions depend on wireless, long-distance connectivity: the internet. Existing telemedicine programmes are limited by available internet options in LMICs, particularly cost-effective technologies such as WiFi (IIEE 802.11) and CDMA450 cellular technology, or delay-tolerant networks which transmit information in pulses. 47 Advancements in the internet such as 5th generation telecommunications (5G) use higher frequency millimetre waves than existing networks to provide lower latency, higher capacity, and improved transmission speed. 48,49 However, while more advanced telecommunication technology offers the potential for more advanced digital health applications, the requirement for densely packed, expensive small-cell base stations might continue to exclude populations in rural or lower-income areas. In addition, 6th generation telecommunications (6G) are being developed which might ameliorate the limitations imposed by the computing power of mobile devices. 6G is posited as an enabling technology for intelligent wearable devices, for health monitoring. 50 However, 6G is affected by similar accessibility issues as 5G—these infrastructural challenges in the context of global eye health are elaborated on here. Greater internet connectivity, and prevalence of internet-connected devices, has given rise to the concept of an internet of things. As these devices now outnumber people, and wireless telecommunication technology continues to improve, the notion of devices communicating without human input is both feasible and likely. 51 An intelligent internet of medical things is also feasible as connectivity improves, enabling health care to integrate relevant information from appropriate devices. 50,52 The wealth of information collected through devices’ sensors could be transmitted through internet of things networks to improve efficiency and efficacy of health care. Location data could be leveraged to improve appointment scheduling at a macro level, adjusting appointments as patients arrive early or late, as well as at a micro level, perhaps directing patients to different phases in the ophthalmological consultation based on current availability of visual field machines, acuity charts, and clinicians. 53 Investigation results could be uploaded automatically to electronic health records, integrated with automation to flag concerning features. 53 Broader health data, collected by phones and other wearable technology, could be transmitted to electronic health records too, and management plans could integrate wearable devices to improve monitoring and treatment adherence. 53 As big data are generated and processed at a personal level, cybersecurity is of paramount importance. Emerging blockchain technology could prove useful in this domain, as it facilitates data sharing with costless verification, immutable transaction records, and asymptotic security. 54,55 Blockchain frameworks consist of a growing chain of blocks, linked to their immediate predecessor by a cryptographic hash value. To generate another block in a transaction (eg, to add data to a patient record), a consensus protocol must be fulfilled, with rules defined to ensure changes are verified. 54–56 Architectures can be designed to restrict access to appropriate parties only: such as to train or apply AI models from multiple sources of confidential data, maintain electronic patient records, or supply chain monitoring. 29,56 Few clinical applications of blockchain technology have been reported, 56 but a deep-learning algorithm for detecting high myopia and myopic macular degeneration successfully used a blockchain-based platform for securely transmitting data, transferring the deep-learning model, and testing the model in independent Singaporean and Chinese health-care centres. 29 Recently, data available on the internet has been leveraged by natural language processing models such as ChatGPT (OpenAI, San Francisco, CA, USA)—a large language model (LLM) chatbot platform which uses reinforcement learning from human feedback on top of a pretrained large language model. 57,58 These platforms are being trialled in a wide variety of settings, including to pass medical examinations and provide advice to patients online. 59–61 LLMs fine-tuned with clinical data exhibit even greater promise. 62 Patients and practitioners could benefit from rapid, interactive access to medical information with ease and at no personal cost. 62 Accessibility to close to cutting-edge natural language processing could be democratised through imitative models: small open source LLMs can be fine-tuned on answers generated by state-of-the-art parent models to develop daughter models with comparable performance to the parent model, using a fraction of the computational resources, energy, and time to train. 62 However, performance in specialist examinations is lower than at medical student level, suggesting that clinical applications might require domain-specific training. 63 Moreover, the accuracy and reliability of the information provided by these platforms is not validated, and no regulatory structures exist. Patients’ opinions on the trust they would place in an AI chatbot are mixed. 64 Autonomous deployment is precluded by inaccuracy, lack of an uncertainty indicator, and uninterpretability, but further research and development could produce tools capable of improving consultation capacity, patient education, and triage. 63,65 The versatility of these models facilitates rapid assimilation of information from diverse, multimodal sources, which could contribute to eye disease risk prediction and diagnosis using electronic medical record data alongside investigation results. Challenges impeding digital health integration Regulatory barriers to clinical deployment of digital health tools Much work is required to convince governance bodies to accept new digital health tools, as well as for physicians and other health-care professionals to incorporate them into their clinical practice—especially for diagnostic and management innovations. 66 Moreover, autonomous deployment of AI systems presents unique medicolegal issues which are being debated around the world as tools become more sophisticated. 65 There are therefore very few examples of AI algorithms currently used in routine clinical work, despite the plethora of validated models in the literature. 67,68 Inventors and researchers are hampered by an unclear, challenging roadmap to the deployment of novel digital health tools. Validation, safety testing, and multidisciplinary planning are all critical requirements, but these vary with the nature of the tool. Robust testing and governance are already well-defined for more established technologies: the barrier affecting AI and digital health is not that there are too many rules, but rather that existing rules are not compatible with these emerging applications and tools. Regulators are working with innovators to reduce the barriers to implementation: examples include a British Evidence Standards Framework for Digital Health Technologies which differentiates the regulatory requirements for evidence in proportion to the risk associated with the function of the digital tool in question. 69,70 Similarly, the International Medical Device Regulators Forum provides a framework for patient and public health risk categorisation for Software as a Medical Device (SaMD) based on the intended clinical task. 71 This has guided downstream policies such as the US FDA SaMD clinical evaluation framework on the safety, effectiveness, and performance of SaMD. 72 Some researchers have found it useful to use existing clinical governance frameworks to show ethical considerations of deploying new technologies in the clinic. 73 Establishing clear international regulatory standards could enable technologies to be implemented worldwide with less delay. Researchers should place an emphasis on high-quality research to improve the veracity of claims regarding safety and efficacy. 41,67 In addition to clinical validation, multidisciplinary research is required to establish the appropriateness of deploying novel technologies at scale. Economic modelling is of paramount importance to show the cost-effectiveness of new initiatives, and requires detailed consideration specific to the disease, population, and technology of interest. 74–76 These analyses are no less important when considering deploying systems internationally, including in LMICs. Where possible, independent teams should conduct these studies, as conflicts of interest are well demonstrated as a source of bias in cost effectiveness analysis. 77 Health-care providers are also wary of relying on black box algorithms for decision making, and although significant research into explainable AI has improved our understanding of how deep-learning models work, further work is required to reduce the opacity of their processes. 78,79 Health-care infrastructural limitations Resource limitations, especially in LMICs, are another major barrier to implementation. Remote areas often lack the necessary infrastructure to adopt new technologies, due to insufficient equipment, poor internet and electricity coverage, and absence of robust telecommunication networks. 26,80 This is compounded by scarce funding, with support impeded by bureaucracy, budget restrictions, and high staffing turnover. 81 Furthermore, there is a worldwide shortage and maldistribution of ophthalmologists for patient assessment and treatment. 6,82,83 The low human resource capacity with essential skills—particularly in digital health literacy—is especially pronounced in LMICs where access to education is restricted, and this impedes the adoption of innovative solutions. 16,84 Committed investment of financial and human capital—perhaps with altruistic input from specialists in higher income countries—is required to overcome these limitations, with successful case studies including AI-assisted diabetic retinopathy screening in India, Rwanda, and Thailand. 30,31 In addition, the challenges in integrating these technologies into existing clinical workflows highlight the need for evaluation of workflow analysis, usability assessments, and human-computer interaction. 31,85 Implementation of digital health solutions with a lower barrier to entry in terms of technological and technical requirements is a promising solution. 37,86,87 Smartphone-based fundus photography used in an automated AI diabetic retinopathy screening programme in India showed high sensitivity of 95·8%, 99·1% and 99·3% in detecting diabetic retinopathy, sight-threatening diabetic retinopathy, and referrable diabetic retinopathy, respectively. 86 The use of fully automated non-mydriatic retinal cameras requiring minimal operator training has also been proven feasible in outpatient clinics. 88,89 These automated systems could serve as initial tools to triage patients in high-volume mass-screening programmes without a requirement for highly skilled personnel to operate technically complex and expensive equipment. Classification by AI algorithms bypasses the additional step of image grading by a qualified ophthalmologist or grader, featured in asynchronous store-and-forward telehealth models. 75,90,91 This enables efficient triage of patients to avoid saturating the scarce pool of ophthalmologists, with sight-threatening diabetic retinopathy referred more urgently. AI systems could also assist with administrative tasks such as appointment scheduling and inventory management. These systems have the potential to relieve strain on scarce resources in LMICs, reduce delays to diagnosis and to treatment, and facilitate effective provision of care with prioritisation of those in greatest need, maximising outcomes at the population level. Financial costs AI systems often depend on expensive hardware, such as retinal fundus cameras for image data acquisition, graphics processing units for running deep-learning algorithms, and stable high-speed internet connectivity. The short-term and long-term costs entailed by initial development, implementation, and maintenance of these systems represents a substantial barrier to entry for LMICs. 92 Costs can be prohibitive: IDx-DR, the first US FDA-approved AI system for diabetic retinopathy screening, provided negative marginal revenue for service providers. 93 However, these systems could be cost-effective if implemented optimally: cost-minimisation analysis of the national diabetic retinopathy screening programme in Singapore showed that a semi-automated model (ie, initial AI triage followed by secondary human assessment) was the least expensive arrangement operating with acceptable performance, compared to fully automated and traditional human assessment models. 76 There is a critical requirement for cost-utility analyses of AI systems specific to intended implementation sites, to better understand and justify the resources needed to support real-world implementation. 94 Cybersecurity risk Implementation of digital technology could introduce potential vulnerabilities for penetration and manipulation of confidential patient data. Strengthening of cybersecurity protocols and ethical development is required to mitigate these risks. Examples of cybersecurity measures include user authentication, audit trails, data encryption, and secure data transmission mechanisms. 95 Privacy-preserving digital technology is being developed specifically to minimise cybersecurity risk as innovation continues. Federated machine learning allows data-private multisite collaboration, distributing model training and aggregating model weights without sharing individual patient datasets. 96,97 Another privacy-preserving alternative to data sharing is generative AI—leveraging architectures such as transformers or adversarial networks to synthesise new images to boost the volume and diversity of existing datasets without using more confidential data from patients. 98 The emerging incorporation of blockchain technology also facilitates the secure and auditable exchange of confidential data, safeguarding data integrity and immutability. 54 For example, Tan and colleagues proposed a proof-of-concept permissioned blockchain-enabled platform that enabled the secure sharing of model results and large datasets among three separate sites from two different countries in the development of deep-learning algorithms for myopia detection. 29 These methods could be coupled with blockchain technology to augment AI algorithms without compromising patient data confidentiality and ownership regulations. In general, privacy-preserving mechanisms entail a risk of accentuating biases, affecting minority groups the most in terms of model performance. These competing interests must be balanced in research and development. 99 Creating larger public datasets, representative of the global population, with patient consent could ameliorate issues of bias and privacy, but after many years of AI development, the availability of large datasets of sufficient representation remain few. 100 Curating these datasets is labour-intensive, requiring patient consent, data acquisition, labelling, and quality checks. Nevertheless, existing examples of such datasets prove that they are feasible provided that there is political will and sufficient investment. 100 LMICs might be incentivised to contribute to dataset curation by having first access to the data and subsequently trained models, but this must be carefully balanced against the aim of fostering openness to improve research worldwide. Ethical concerns Ethical AI development requires a priori consideration of the populations the new system is intended to operate on: it cannot be assumed that systems developed using data from one population could be transferred to another without a performance decrement. Overfitting during model training might limit performance, particularly if individuals come from populations unseen during training. 101–103 In 2021, publicly available ophthalmological datasets did not feature patients from 172 countries, representing 3·5 billion people (42% of the world's population). 100 Algorithmic biases could perpetuate inequalities affecting marginalised groups who are often under-represented in training datasets used to develop these systems. 81 Hence, validating algorithms on external test datasets and in real-world settings with representative demographics is essential to facilitate generalisability and clinical translation before implementation. 104 Successful examples exist: AI deep-learning algorithms deployed in diabetic retinopathy screening programmes in Zambia and in an Indigenous primary health-care service in Australia had clinically acceptable performances in detection of referrable and vision-threatening diabetic retinopathy. 26,105 However, bias arising from sensitive variables inclusive of age or gender might be difficult to eliminate. 106 Furthermore, social determinants of eye health shaping conditions of daily living, such as educational and job opportunities, diet, and social exclusion, influence health outcomes and must also be considered when building AI systems, although such data might not be available on a consistent basis. 1,107 Technical limitations of contemporary digital technology and AI AI and digital technology are not panaceas in global eye health. These technologies cannot replace all aspects of health care and are best framed as assistive tools to augment clinical management. Although diagnostic and management decisions might be clinically appropriate with adequate ocular imaging and ancillary tests, certain aspects of management require physical interaction or surgical intervention, and therefore face-to-face appointments cannot be abandoned. 32,41 Even if algorithms were clinically flawless, practical limitations would preclude autonomous deployment without clinician oversight and interaction. For instance, many fundus photographs generated in screening clinics could be ungradable due to either operator error, poor equipment, or media opacities such as cataract—these will all lead to unnecessary referrals. Engineering unbiased and generalisable models is made more difficult by the limited availability of large, standardised datasets. 100 The process of collecting data for such datasets is a considerable undertaking. In addition to consenting vast numbers of patients from a representative diversity of geographical regions in the training population, data must be collected and labelled accurately by experts. Sufficient patient data must also be associated with clinical data, without making individuals identifiable. Data should be hosted publicly with the use of standardised terminologies, to facilitate reproducibility and external validation efforts. 108 Furthermore, datasets should be reported transparently to enable researchers to gauge their strengths and weaknesses to deal with them appropriately. 100 Take the example in the development and implementation of AI algorithms in myopia, which entails overcoming challenges described here (figure 3 ). For childhood myopia, it is important to consider the influence of clinical and lifestyle risk factors (eg, near work, outdoor time, lifestyle habits) on myopia progression. However, there might be recall bias in the collection of these questionnaire-based input data. Furthermore, feature bias could be introduced into datasets as these risk factors can be influenced by the disparity in socioeconomic status and educational resources globally. 109 These biases within datasets might limit the generalisability of AI models. For adult myopia, there exist doubts in the predictive prognostication of AI due to few effective options and variations in treatment. 20,109 The challenge in collating large-scale and high-quality image datasets is further compounded by technical challenges specific to myopia. For example, it is highly challenging to capture good quality retinal images (eg, fundus photographs, optical coherence tomogram macula) in highly myopic eyes. Furthermore, various pathologies related to pathologic myopia are often present concurrently, resulting in ambiguity in interpretation for labelling and annotation of pathologic myopic lesions. 109 Future directions Establishing a global digital eye health task force with country-level representatives from every region in the world could facilitate organised coordination of efforts and progress toward integrating these digital health tools into eye health systems. Parallels can be drawn from the American Academy of Ophthalmology Telemedicine Task Force, established in 2018 to develop frameworks for standards of data security and workforce training. 110 The International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness (IAPB) Technology Taskforce has developed an eye health technology guide targeted at eye care providers and governments. 111 It provides an overview of commercially available innovative devices and technology that enable improved access to eye care services. The IAPB Technology for Access Framework provides a structured guide for nations to assess if any given new technology is appropriate for implementation in their specific setting, in order to have a sustainable effect. 112 Components of the framework include technology readiness in terms of efficacy and safety; systems integration in terms of regulatory frameworks, human resources, and referral pathways for continuity of care; and operating environment in terms of local suitability, service accessibility, and economic sustainability. 112 Global representation empowers nation leaders to influence policy and resource allocation, while tailoring systems to the specific environments feasible in individual countries. 113,114 Bringing different countries together allows for ambitious but realistic targets to be set to improve standards worldwide, while respecting variability in nations’ priorities, capabilities, and challenges. For example, optimal referral criteria depend on individual nations’ health economic status; low-threshold criteria might result in over-referral exceeding resource capacity, whereas high-threshold criteria risk missing patients who require treatment. 26 Members from LMICs can also tap into invaluable lessons learned from real-life use cases in regions with similar geographical and logistical challenges, to guide development and implementation of similar digital technologies. To align with the WHO World Report on Vision recommendations to integrate eye health as part of universal health coverage, eye health services must be prioritised in national health policy planning and budgeting. 1,8,10 In addition to national organisations, public-private partnerships with for-profit and non-governmental organisations (NGOs) can play a pivotal role in funding progress. 115 In partnership with the government and the Brien Holden Vision Institute, Pakistan's largest NGO, the Pakistan Layton Rahmatulla Benevolent Trust Hospital, supported optical stores within secondary and tertiary hospitals, to increase patient uptake of prescribed spectacles. 114,116 In Tanzania, a sevenfold increase in patients receiving eye care was achieved thanks to funding from government and NGOs such as Helen Keller International and ORBIS International. 117 The inaugural Toolkit for Glaucoma Management—a practical guide to support integrated glaucoma care services and strengthen sustainable health systems—was developed by sub-Saharan African ophthalmologists, with the support of international organisations including the IAPB and funding from NGOs, Light For The World, and the Else Kröner-Fresenius-Stiftung. 118 Eye health financing includes prioritising coverage of specific types of eye care services and patient subgroups, while striking a balance between operational costs and reimbursements. 119 Existing research on economic analyses of digital health tools and artificial intelligence in ophthalmology is scarce and mostly restricted to diabetic retinopathy screening in high-income countries, while many other diseases exert a higher burden of disease in the rest of the world. 2,75,76,94,120 There is a pressing requirement for greater understanding of the cost-effectiveness and resources required for new digital health tools, in the unique settings of countries with different resource capacities. 1,15,74,76 The push for democratisation of AI in health care should focus on lowering the barrier to entry and empowering LMICs. Existing efforts include publicly available open datasets and automated machine learning (autoML) platforms which reduce or eliminate the need for coding expertise to develop models. 100,121 Some autoML platforms provide cloud-based hosting for large databases and graphics processing units, abrogating the requirement to purchase expensive hardware. Furthermore, it is important to ensure the interoperability of digital platforms for data exchange and standardisation of terminologies and classifications for collaboration as well as standardisation of data terminologies and imaging formats. 95,122 A 2022 systematic scoping review of existing AI applications in LMICs found that none of the studies reported datasets accessible to the public in full, and only a few described the used AI algorithms in detail. 16 There is a need for standardised reporting of AI technologies which is transparent and comprehensive, as outlined by published guidelines such as Developmental and Exploratory Clinical Investigations of Decision support systems driven by Artificial Intelligence (known as DECIDE-AI), which aims to ensure new technologies are critically analyzed and reproducible in other similar settings. 16,123 There is also a need to integrate education on AI into medical training, to equip physicians with the knowledge to appropriately integrate AI into clinical practice. 124–126 More importantly, there is a need for a standardised approach to harmonise and enhance existing AI educational resources which are few and unevenly distributed. 124,125 For example, the Regional Protocols for the Formulation of Public Telehealth Policies for Latin America, sponsored by the Inter-American Development Bank, prioritised training and development of telehealth among local health-care personnel. 115–117,127 Recruiting and upskilling local community nurses and optometrists can further boost the capacity of the existing health-care workforce. 81,128–130 These educational efforts could be emulated in initiatives to boost familiarity and competency with newer digital health tools such as artificial intelligence in ophthalmology. Concurrently, governments must take care to avoid a brain drain of these trained personnel from LMICs which could further perpetuate the observed divide with high-income countries. Conclusions Improving eye health remains a global priority as a key to unlocking human potential by reducing the morbidity burden of disease, increasing productivity, and supporting access to education. As global eye care progresses into the next decade, collective action is necessary to leverage emerging digital health and artificial intelligence technology. Further research should focus on scalability and sustainability, to progress beyond pilot studies or one-off initiatives, towards effective, feasible, and sustainable applications with potential for international adoption. Emphasis should be placed on the assessment of human factors in addition to model accuracy parameters, such as usability evaluation, end-user trust, human-computer interaction, and socioenvironmental factors. Clinicians and researchers in LMICs should be involved with research in the field to deliver technological solutions as efficiently as possible. Democratisation of AI and digital health technology is key to maximising uptake, whereas on the ground health-care professionals are best placed to identify logistical barriers. Cultivation of demand-driven research in under-represented regions will generate impactful innovations and valuable data relating to the epidemiology of eye disease, effectiveness of novel technologies in improving eye health, and economic implications of technological interventions. 131 Governmental and non-governmental organisations must collaborate to overcome barriers to implementation, particularly regarding resource scarcity. With multistakeholder collaboration, there is great potential to develop effective, efficient, and equitable solutions by harnessing artificial intelligence and digital health technology. Search strategy and selection criteria We searched Google Scholar, Embase, MEDLINE, and Scopus, from Aug 1, 2022, to April 30, 2023, using the following terms: “AI”, “artificial intelligence”, “augmented reality”, “blockchain”, “cataract”, “cornea”, “cybersecurity”, “deep learning”, “digital”, “digital health”, “eye health”, “global health”, “global south”, “internet of things”, “large language model”, “LIC”, “LMIC”, “machine learning”, “macular degeneration”, “ocular”, “ophthalmology”, “refractive error”, “regulation”, “resource poor”, “retin*”,“telehealth”, “virtual reality”. The reference lists of initially identified papers were also scrutinised. Papers published in English, French, or Mandarin Chinese were reviewed. Final inclusion depended on originality and relevance to the subject matter of this Review. Contributors DS-WT formulated the direction of the article. TFT and AJT led the manuscript writing. Variables from feature importances Non-programme year Programme year Panel A: Financial development factors Broad money High Low Financial institutions High Low Gross savings High Low Financial markets High Low Credit private sector High Low ATM High Low Panel B: Financial market volatility and stability VIX Low High Note: Broad money is the sum of currency outside banks expressed as a percentage of GDP; Financial institutions represent financial institutions in terms of depth, access and efficiency; Gross savings denote the gross savings of a nation’s income less consumption plus net transfer as a percentage of GDP; Financial markets stand for financial market in terms of depth, access and efficiency; Credit private sector denotes the domestic credit to private sector as a percentage of GDP; ATM represents the number of ATMs per 100,000 adults; VIX represents the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE) Volatility Index. Table 4 Predictors of an IMF bailout (debt, macro factors and government quality). Variables from feature importances Non-programme year Programme year Panel A: Debt indicators NFL IMF nonconcessional Low High NFL IMF concessional Low High External debt long term GDP Low High Total debt service to GNI Low High Panel B: Macro indicators Inflation Low High Lending interest rate Low High Panel C: Government quality indicators Unemployment to total labor force Low High Personal remittances received GDP Low High Grants Low High Corruption score Low High Government consumption expenditure High Low Gini index Low High Note: NFL IMF nonconcessional represents net financial flows, IMF non-concessional in current USD; NFL IMF concessional represents net financial flows, IMF concessional in current USD; External debt long term GDP denotes external debt stocks with maturity exceeding a year; Total debt service to GNI represents total debt service as a percentage of gross national income (GNI). Inflation is measured as the percentage change in the consumer price index; Lending interest rate denotes the lending rates of banks as a percentage; Unemployment to total labor force stands for unemployment as a percentage of the total labor force; Personal remittances received GDP denotes personal remittances received as a percentage of GDP; Grants is measured as grants received as a percentage of revenue; Corruption score represents the control of corruption; Government consumption expenditure represents general government final consumption expressed as a percentage of GDP; Gini index represents the Gini coefficient, a measure of inequality. Table 5 Predictors of an IMF bailout (agricultural, energy and trade factors). What can artificial intelligence and machine learning models tell us about why countries knock at the door of the IMF? Elikplimi Komla Agbloyor Conceptualization Data curation Formal analysis Investigation Methodology Software Visualization Writing – original draft a b Lei Pan Conceptualization Investigation Software Visualization Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing c ⁎ 1 Richard Adjei Dwumfour Investigation Data curation Software Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing c Agyapomaa Gyeke-Dako Investigation Supervision Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a a University of Ghana Business School, Ghana University of Ghana Business School Ghana University of Ghana b University of Stellenbosch Business School, South Africa University of Stellenbosch Business School South Africa University of Stellenbosch c School of Accounting, Economics and Finance, Curtin University, Australia School of Accounting, Economics and Finance, Curtin University Australia Curtin University ⁎ Correspondence to: School of Accounting, Economics and Finance, Curtin University, Kent St, Perth, WA 6102, Australia. School of Accounting, Economics and Finance, Curtin University Kent St Perth WA 6102 Australia 1 We would like to thank one anonymous referee for the valuable comments, which helped to improve the quality of the article. We are also grateful to seminar participants at Department of Finance and Tax, University of Cape Town research seminar series for helpful comments. We thank Kwaku Oppong Adomako for providing excellent research assistance. All remaining errors are our own. This paper examines the factors that predict an IMF bailout. In doing so, we use a large dataset from 1993 to 2021 with 6550 observations and 138 features and adopt recent advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence models such as tree-based, boosting and artificial neural network techniques. We find that apart from traditional indicators such as debt and macroeconomic factors; agricultural, energy, health and social factors are strong predictors of an IMF bailout. These factors have hitherto not received much attention in the literature. JEL classification F3 F4 Keywords Artificial intelligence Machine learning IMF bailout Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The International Monetary Fund (IMF) was set up in 1945 with 44 member countries after the world had experienced two world wars. Countries that experienced balance of payments (BoP) problems could borrow from the IMF to help stabilize their economies. The IMF functions as the international lender of last resort. Over the years, the Fund has provided financial support to countries experiencing macro fundamental problems through bailout mechanisms. According to Iseringhausen et al. (2019), any member country or government that faces financial trouble, whether low-income, middle-income or rich, can go to the IMF for a bailout. Without a bailout from the IMF in recent times, many of these countries would have struggled to keep their economies afloat due to the effects of COVID-19 pandemic and the Russian-Ukraine war. To help overcome BoP challenges and debt crisis, the IMF offers different forms of support such as concessional and non-concessional instruments, surveillance (i.e. policy monitoring and advice), capacity building (in the form of managing public finance and regulatory reforms), and the provision of interest-free loans and other forms of lending facilities. Several studies situated in the context of emerging markets and developing countries, support a positive picture of the likelihood for a country to seek IMF support (Dicks-Mireaux et al., 2000; Dreher and Walter, 2010; Iseringhausen et al., 2019). However, some countries hesitate seeking an IMF bailout because of IMF conditionalities and the negative effects that some countries have suffered after entering into an IMF program (Bird and Rowlands, 2017; Dreher, 2006). For instance, African countries generally had a bitter experience with the IMF due to the painful structural adjustment programs that were implemented in the 1980s and 1990s. Some of these conditionalities included a freeze on public sector employment and wage increases which led to unrest in the labor front, and a freeze or withdrawal in subsidies on food, water, electricity and agriculture. In addition, the IMF has faced massive criticism based on its institutional structure, its level of transparency, and its impact on maintaining the stability of countries that have utilized an IMF program (Dreher, 2006). There is extensive literature that examined the determinants of the likelihood of a country seeking an IMF lending program. For instance, studies have focused on weak economic indicators 2 2 Namely, high debt service ratio, the BoP deficits, low GDP and declining growth rates. (Bird et al., 2004; Ifrah et al., 2021; Iseringhausen et al., 2019); distorted current account balance (Bird and Rowlands, 2017; Joyce, 1992; Knight and Santaella, 1997); and the mismanagement of fiscal and monetary policy instruments (Bird, 2007) – as the main reasons that force a country to seek an IMF bailout program. In particular, Joyce (1992) use a logit model and find that countries that seek IMF program normally have higher shares of government expenditure, severe current account deficits and smaller reserves. Similarly, Bird et al. (2004) using a Poisson regression model find that repeated users of IMF support have more capital outflows and larger current account deficits. In addition, they also find that these countries normally have lower reserve holdings, investment rates and income per capita. On the other hand, some studies have argued that the credibility of the IMF support program amidst unresolved adjustment policy problems, structural and BoP problems of most participating countries, as well as non-compliance with the conditionality measures are factors that restrain a country from going to the IMF for support (Goldstein and Montiel, 2017; Przeworski and Vreeland, 2000). For instance, Przeworski and Vreeland (2000) use the Heckman selection model and find that most countries seek the IMF program because of foreign reserves crisis. The study also find that countries that stay in the program experience low economic growth. Earlier studies also find no evidence that the IMF program improved balance of payments (Connors, 1979; Reichmann and Stillson, 1978), even though some studies find some improvements (Bird, 1996). Despite these conflicting evidence, countries repeatedly seek for an IMF bailout. The question therefore remains as to: why do countries seek an IMF bailout? The world has seen some of the worst global conditions in recent decades. The COVID-19 pandemic, rising global interest rates, record high inflation rates, the strengthening of the US dollar has posed challenges for many economies. Especially for low-income countries in Africa, there has been an intense debate as to whether countries should seek support from the IMF to secure their ailing economies as a result of these global conditions. Due to their poor economic performance, most of these economies have had credit downgrades and are unable to access international capital markets. Despite these challenges, the political will to seek help from the Fund is a major consideration given the perceived negative political capital for incumbent governments; this usually affects the timing with which these countries seek for help. However, forces beyond a country’s control may force it to seek an IMF bailout. Therefore, this study seeks to understand the factors that lead countries to seek support from the IMF. This is important especially for policy makers because knowledge of these existing factors can help them decide the appropriate timing to seek for assistance. Going too late for assistance may worsen the existing economic conditions of the country. This may prolong the time to have an agreement with the Fund or not have the desired agreement or in a worse-case scenario not get an agreement. Indeed, when the economic conditions are worse, the IMF may impose some strict conditions in a bid to have some stability in the Fund’s financial resources. Our study is, therefore, important to help identify the key factors that leads countries to seek for IMF support. Our main contribution lies in the use of new techniques that are better at predicting outcome variables. Specifically, we use machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) models such as tree-based, boosting and neural network techniques. The advantages of these models compared to traditional estimation techniques are that: (i) whether a country seeks an IMF bailout is probabilistic in nature and is a prediction problem which machine learning and artificial intelligence models are better at compared to traditional econometric methods (see Amini et al. (2021)); (ii) ML and AI models can detect non-linearities in the dataset without being explicitly programmed to do so (see Amini et al. (2021) and Gu et al. (2020)). Indeed, many of the variables such as a country’s debt-to-GDP ratio, foreign currency reserve, BoP, inflation, interest rate and oil price may change in a non-linear fashion in relation to the probability of seeking IMF support and may also interact in unpredictable ways when a country is in financial distress. Thus, our approach allows us to identify and untangle the complex, high-dimensional, and interactive effects that exist between the features that predict a country seeking IMF support. The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 describes the dataset and presents the methodology used in this study. Section 3 presents and discusses the empirical findings. Section 4 concludes. 2 Data and methodology 2.1 Data The data for the different types of programs accessed by IMF member countries was obtained from the IMF. The sample period is from 1993 to 2021. We obtained the other features (variables) from the World Development Indicators (WDI) and Bertelsmann Stiftung over the same time period. 3 3 The detailed sources of the data and the list of countries are reported in Tables A.1 and A.2 in the Appendix, respectively. Given that the number of years that a country seeks an IMF bailout represents a small proportion of the sample, we use sample overweighting and underweighting approaches in an attempt to improve the predictability of our algorithms. Specifically, we used the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) which allows us to overweight the minority class (IMF bailouts). We also explore underweighting techniques such as the RandomUnderSampler from imblearn. 2.1.1 Train/validation/test data split We split the data into train, validation and test sets to enable us judge the performance of our machine learning models on unseen or test data. We employ a Train/Validation/Test ratio split of 60/20/20. In addition, we perform Cross Validation using the K -Folds method and a K of 10 on the training data. Consequently, the training data is split into 10. The artificial intelligence/machine learning models trained or learnt on 9( K −1) folds of the data and evaluated performance on 1. Thus, instead of 1 performance metric, we had K or 10 metrics. High cross validation scores are an indication that our models will perform well on unseen data, are stable and have low variance. 2.1.2 Data pre-processing We perform outlier treatment for all the variables in our data set. We first of all compute the inter-quartile range (IQR). The first quartile is represented by the 25th percentile and the third quartile is represented by the 75th percentile. We remove values that are 1.5 times outside this range. We also treated for missing values in the data set using the median filler. 2.2 Machine learning algorithms We adopt various machine learning algorithms to predict the factors that explain why countries seek an IMF Bailout. The algorithms include Logistic Regressions, Bagging, Random Forest, AdaBoost, Gradient Boost, XGBoost and Artificial Neural Networks. Our model selection is based on the models that have the highest Recall score, the models that are consistent based on the other evaluation metrics (mainly Precision and the F1 scores), and finally based on models that have the least over-fitting. Machine learning models are known to quickly overfit the data. The consequence of overfitting are that the machine learning models perform extremely well on the training data but have lower performance on unseen data or test data. 2.2.1 Hyper-parameter tuning We select the final models for our prediction after tuning the models. Tuning is important to boost the predictability of our models. Hyper-parameter tuning represents the process of trying to improve the performance of our machine learning models by searching for the best parameters. These parameters cannot be learned from the data and are specified by the programmer. We tune parameters such as the learning rate, the number of estimators, the tree depth, max features, maximum sample size, gamma, scale pos weight, the number of neurons and dropout rates. 2.2.2 Model performance evaluation We use the confusion matrix to help us evaluate the performance of our algorithms. The confusion matrix gives us the number of True Positives, 4 4 This represents our prediction of those who would take an IMF bailout and actually did. True Negatives, 5 5 This represents our prediction of countries who would not take an IMF bailout and indeed they did not seek a bailout. False Positives 6 6 This represents our prediction of countries those who would seek a bailout but they did not. and False Negatives. 7 7 This represents our prediction of those who would not seek a bailout but actually did. Based on the metrics from the confusion matrix, we compute the Accuracy ratio, the Recall Score, the Precision Score and the F1 Score. We measure the performance of our models using the Accuracy, Recall, Precision and F1 Score. We do not rely on the Accuracy Score because the data set is imbalanced. The Recall score tells us the percentage of actual IMF bailouts that we are able to predict. Recall is defined as: (1) Recall = True Positive True Positive + False Negative The Precision Score on the other hand tells us what percentage of our predictions of countries going to the IMF are actually correct. Precision is defined as: (2) Precision = True Positive True Positive + False Positive Finally, we examine the F1 Score which is a harmonic mean of Precision and Recall. The F1 score is defined as: (3) F1 = 2 × Precision × Recall Precision + Recall The F1 score ranges between zero and one. A value of one represents perfect recall and prediction. 2.2.3 Feature importances Finally, we examine the feature importances that the machine learning algorithms suggest are important for predicting a country seeking an IMF bailout. The feature importances are a ranking of the features (independent variables) that the machine learning algorithms identify as explaining an IMF bailout. Due to the fact that the algorithms provide a ranking of the features, we are able to determine most important factors that explain why countries seek an IMF bailout. 3 Results and discussion In this section, we present the results from our empirical experiments. We first present information on the characteristics of the data at our disposal. This is followed by results from our model building. We then present results from our hyperparameter tuning which is aimed at improving model by searching for the best parameters. Finally, we present and discuss the results from the feature importances. 3.1 Data characteristics Fig. 1 shows that for the entire data (6550 observations and 138 features), 25% of country years represented years in which countries were in an IMF programme. On the other hand, 75% of country years (4880 observations) represented years in which countries were not in an IMF programme. Consequently, we have a clear class imbalance in our dataset. This provides strong support for our use of class imbalance techniques. Table 1 shows the data we have in the training, validation and training data set. The class distribution on the training, validation and test data are also quite similar and similar to the overall distribution of 75%/25% in the overall data. 3.2 Model building Fig. 2 presents results from using the original data. The original data does not include a treatment for class imbalance. We see that Random Forest produces the highest cross validation (CV) score whilst Ada Boost produces the lowest CV score. The performance across the models are similar but mostly below a CV of 80%. Using the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) to balance the data by increasing the size of the minority class (IMF programme years), in Fig. 3 we see an improved performance (higher CV scores) compared to the original data. Here as well, Random Forest has the highest CV score whilst Adaboost has the lowest CV score. Most of the CV scores are above 90%. Using the Random UnderSampler from imblearn to balance the data by decreasing the size of the majority class (non-IMF programme years), in Fig. 4 we see an improved performance (higher CV scores) compared to the original data. Logistic Regression has the highest CV score whilst Adaboost has the lowest CV score. However, we observe that the performance using over-sampling is better than using under-sampling. Consequently, we performing hyper-parameter tuning using the over-sampled data. 3.3 Hyper-parameter tuning: best parameters Table 2 shows the best parameters for our machine learning algorithms. These parameters are the ones we used in estimating our algorithms. Fig. 5 shows the evaluation metrics after running these models. We settle on the Random Forest because it has some of the highest evaluation metrics and is stable and consistent across both the validation and test data. The feature importances are therefore based on the Random Forest. 3.4 Features importances Fig. 6 shows the feature importances based on the Random Forest classifier. Fig. 6 displays the top 25 factors that predict an IMF bailout. Taking an IMF non concessionary loans is the biggest factor predicting an IMF bailout. This is followed by exchange rate movements, broad money, contributing family workers, and long-term external debt to GDP. To help us explain the feature importances, we group the top features into various categories and examine whether the feature is high or low in a programme and non-programme year. From Tables 3 and 4 we see that IMF bailouts are associated with low financial development. In addition, financial market volatility, represented by the Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index (VIX), is a strong predictor of an IMF bailout or programme. In terms of macro factors, as expected, high debts and low reserves predict an IMF bailout. Interestingly, accessing IMF loans (both concessional and non-concessional) are strong predictors of a bailout. This suggests that some countries become regular “customers” of the IMF. Furthermore, high inflation and interest rates are associated with a higher likelihood of a bailout. High unemployment is also associated with IMF bailouts. In addition, countries that rely heavily on grants and remittances are more likely to need an IMF bailout. Corruption, low government expenditures and high income inequality are also associated with a higher likelihood of an IMF bailout. From Table 5, we find that agricultural, energy and trade factors are associated with an IMF Bailout. In particular, high levels of agriculture and low information and communications technology (ICT) exports are predictive of a bailout. Low energy consumption and high natural resource rents are also found to be predictive of a bailout. Energy consumption is an indicator of economic activities and thus we observe low energy consumption in bailout years. In addition, the association between high natural resources and a bailout is suggestive of a natural resource curse. In terms of trade factors, high levels of international trade taxes and import duties are shown to be predictive factors of a bailout or IMF programme. From Table 6, we observe that the quality of healthcare is a strong predictor of a bailout. For instance, the levels of tuberculosis, HIV, and malaria are all associated with a bailout. Furthermore, the life expectancy is found to be a strong predictor of a bailout. In addition, sanitation, the quality of drinking water, the number of women in parliament and high age dependency are found to be associated with a bailout. 4 Conclusion Using a large data set (6550 observations and 138 features) and employing recent advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence, we contribute to the debate as to the factors that predict the likelihood of a country needing an IMF bailout. Our study uncovers many factors that can predict why a country seeks an IMF Bailout. These factors include traditional factors such as high levels of external debt, unemployment, financial market volatility, foreign exchange reserves, tax policy and so on. We also uncover new factors such as the structure of the economy (agrarian), energy factors, trade factors, health related factors, and social factors. Though these factors have not been employed in the extant literature, we find that they are useful at least in a predictive sense in identifying countries that are likely to need an IMF bailout. Overall, our findings suggest that low financial development, high financial market volatility, high levels of debt, poor government quality (e.g. corruption, unemployment, income inequality), high levels of agriculture, services such as ICT imports, poor health services quality, and social factors such as poor sanitation, access to clean water, and gender diversity are strong predictors of a bailout. In addition, accessing previous funds from the IMF (whether concessionary or not) is found to be a strong predictor of a bailout. This suggests that countries become “regular” customers of the IMF. Our work contributes to the financial fragility literature as it provides a way of identifying countries that are vulnerable and may need an IMF bailout. It also provides development financial institutions (DFIs) and countries with a framework to monitor the financial health of countries and pointers or levers to improve their financial resilience and reduce the probability of financial distress or needing an IMF bailout.
